documents.commentText:
Logically speaking no substance should be put on the Schedule 1 list where someone who has it would be put in prison, kept from family and possibly children, unless there is adequate scientific researching proving the EXTREME dangers and lack or medical use for that product. By adequate research I mean that there should be conclusive proof in MANY peer reviewed and replicated tests and experiments. Even then only the most dangerous substances should be added to the Schedule 1 list for 2 reasons. Number one it is not the governments job to play parent. America is a free country and adults own their bodies, the government does not own their body and should only be able to tell people that they can't do something to their own body except in the most extreme cases. Number two, once the substance is on the schedule 1 list it makes it extremely difficult to continue research into possible medical uses. Unless ALL possible uses have been thoroughly tested and found ineffective than it should not be listed as a substance with no medical use. 
Based on the scientific literature available, it is clear that Kratom does not have anywhere near enough research to make any decision on it whatsoever. Until much more research is done a free society should demand that this substance remains legal and open. There are few death associated with it, and all of those included many variables that make it impossible to pinpoint Kratom as the cause. The evidence that it is addictive is extremely weak and the most common narrative expressed by users is that it is not addictive. It also shows promise in helping people with pain and opiate addictions. PLEASE DO NOT MAKE KRATOM ILLEGAL WITH SO LITTLE RESEARCH!!!

documents.commentText: My name is Lauren Moquin.  I am a 53-year old legal professional and fitness, yoga, and martial instructor. I have been prescribed numerous medications that do not help this affliction.  I have substituted the use of kratom tea and support a locally owned tea bar  which is a safe place where no alcohol or smoking is permitted and socializing is encouraged.  Kratom and the tea bar are a god-send.  Kratom is a non-addictive, healthy, coffee-like herb that can help alleviate the suffering of millions and should remain available to the citizens of our nation and not be classified as a class one drug.  We simply have too many of our citizens suffering addiction, anxiety, pain, etc to be denied the benefits of a non-addictive herb by the DEA. And as a tax-payer, I would prefer those DEA dollars be spent on research into reclassifying medicinal 'drugs' such as psilocybin which research is showing is amazing useful in treating PSTD.   I tried Kratom tea for the first time in October of this year (2016) after researching the benefits to those suffering like me. I have had amazing results by drinking a couple cups of kratom tea several times a week.  It has calmed me considerably and I have no compulsion to drink alcohol.  A further benefit of kratom use is that I have not needed any of the prescription medications I relied upon, including blood pressure and anti-anxiety meds, depression meds since beginning its use.  I desire to have access to kratom for as long as it continues to soothe and normalize me.  I am also aware that kratom is an alternative to strong prescription opioids and in recovery from alcohol and other addictions so I expect that my fellow US citizens will be able to benefit from the use of kratom rather than continue suffering because of wrongly placed classification by the DEA.  And the economic benefits of more tea bars is a plus.  Therefore, I strongly oppose the classification of kratom as a class one drug.

documents.commentText:
I first heard about the dietary supplement Mitragyna speciosa (Kratom) in 2006 while I was studying Neuroscience at the University of Pittsburgh. I later went on to receive a doctorate in Naturopathic Medicine at Bastyr University in Kenmore, WA. I was provided significant research based training on botanical and nutraceutical therapies. I also received a Masters in Science in Acupuncture and Chinese Herbal Medicine. I am well read in many herbal traditions throughout the world along with an understanding of the ethnobotanical uses of Kratom. These traditional uses and experiences are very valuable until we are able to catch up with the scientific understanding. It is important to note that there have not been any deaths associated with Kratom outside of the United States and that the ones in the United States were associated with combined illegal or prescription drug usage. I will also mention below about how I believe the whole plant will always be safest and that extracts on the market have likely been adulterated. 

When I was first introduced to Kratom as an undergraduate student, I was intrigued about how plant alkaloids could affect the central nervous system. Kratom, had quite a few alkaloids of course and so it was interesting to try and understand. What I came to realize was whole plant medicine creates a complex alchemy of activity that is not always a simple sum of its individual parts. When one isolates one substance from a plant and concentrates it, it becomes a pharmocologic substance with completely different activity than the whole plant and its associated chemicals (The Chinese herbal system classifies different preparations as entirely different herbs altogether). An example is cocaine VS the entire coca leaf. 

I experimented eating Kratom first in an extract concentrated form. I felt that it was simply stimulating and mood elevating much like the effects of coffee. If I took too much I might get nauseous but I personally have never vomited from it. Kratom should not be mixed with alcohol as it will amplify the effects usually in more of a negative fashion. Alkaloids typically are conjugated in the liver then go out through the urine. With low to moderate dosing, liver toxicity seems very minimal (supported by animal model studies). It is possible that the high concentration of epicatechins (antioxidants similar to those found in green tea) may have some protective effects on the hepatocytes as well. This has not yet been proven of course which is why we need time to properly research this plant. 

The extracts, over time, became increasingly more "toxic" in the sense I felt they were too stimulating with increased side effect including nausea, headache and insomnia. I decided that if I was going to use Kratom, I would only use the whole plant. I read a recent article: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27752985 stating that these extracts may have been adulterated with higher concentrations of 7-hydroxymitragynine. This makes sense as 7-hydroxy only occurs in small amounts in whole plant and its activity is likely modulated by multiple other alkaloids including mitragynine. 

When I currently use Kratom, I only use it in a whole plant form in a tea preparation. The effects are mild and I have never personally experienced any withdrawal symptoms even with regular usage. At my peak of use I went 6 months straight drinking about 1tbsp of dried leaf material in a tea every day. I abruptly stopped two months ago and have had no physical withdrawal symptoms. I thought about not having it for about 2-3 days after I abruptly discontinued but this was more of a psychological withdrawal than outright physical.

I have personally used Kratom for chronic pain related to a neck injury I suffered in my late teens. In addition, I have been depressed and anxious off and on for much of my life. I later realized that Kratom too has some mild serotonin modulation through the 5HT2A receptor system. These antidepressant effects often last several days after one dosage. Recently, Kratom has helped me be better able to participate more in my busy life with more clarity of thought and mind and less pain/depression/anxiety. I experience no negative side effect with occasional usage of this plant (2-3x/week on average). 

I have recommended Kratom medicinally in the past to those with chronic pain that have not responded well to conventional treatment. None of them have become addicted. Most of them had benefit from it. A few reported that it was ineffective. Some people are sensitive to it in that micro dosing of plant material (less than 1 tsp) is needed for desired effect but any more would cause nausea, insomnia or other negative effects. 

In my medical opinion, a list of reasonable safe medicinal usages of this plant include: chronic pain, fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue, lyme disease, dysmenorrhea, anxiety and depression.

documents.commentText:
This is a comment against the DEA proposal to include kratom (and its components including mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine) in the list of schedule I drugs.

Kratom saved my sons life!!!

Approximately six years ago, when my son was in his early 30s, he suffered major trauma to the entire left side of his body in a tragic accident.  Physicians were not optimistic of his surviving at all.  He spent a considerable amount of time in intensive care, and he had three surgical procedures during the first week  with more to follow over the next two years.  As soon as he reached the emergency room, my son began to receive powerful opioids in attempts to control the pain, which was so great that the medications were insufficient.  He remained on morphine and other opioid analgesics through his hospitalization.  When released from the hospital, these medications were continued for his pain.  Although they did not control his pain well at all, they left him in an almost comatose condition.  He could not take care of himself at all, and the pain continued non-stop.  He became quite depressed due to the apparent futility of his condition  pain that was not being controlled by the prescriptions, his inability to function, his inability to work, his inability to interact with friends and family, and his having to be on the dole from the government.  Yes, there were times that he was suicidal.  It was terrifying as his father for me to see him like this  and to know that, at any time, he could have chosen to end his young life.

In one of his rare lucid moments, he began to search (online) for information regarding alternative treatments, and he discovered kratom  story after story, testimony after testimony of lives having been saved and full functionality having been restored through the use of this product (a leaf from a tree in the coffee family) for various medical conditions, one of the primary ones of which was both acute and chronic pain.  This product has been used successfully to treat a variety of conditions for centuries in the orient, where the tree is found.

My son bought some kratom, and the results were nothing short of miraculous!!!  He was able to eliminate the use of all prescription opioids after months of use without even experiencing symptoms of withdrawal!!!  He found that his mental state improved rapidly, and he was able to begin to take care of himself, get exercise, and, fairly quickly, begin to look for employment.

Now, approximately six years later, his life is radically different.  He started his own business several years ago, which grew from a one-person operation to a total of seven employees, who have been paid twice the minimum wage and received full benefits!!  Only three years after the start-up of the business, the companys CPA said that she never had seen a new business grow so rapidly  ever!  The taxes paid by the business amounted to hundreds of thousands of dollars each year!
At the present, the action of the DEA against the sale of kratom has taken its toll on my son and on the millions of others who have relied upon kratom for their well-being.  The businesses across the United States that have been legal sources of kratom have stopped selling it because they cannot afford to take the chance of possible prosecution at the worst  or being stuck with stock that they are not permitted to sell at best.

My son, who had continued to use kratom for relief of his pain and depression, now largely is unable to work due to his inability to obtain kratom easily.  He refuses to return to prescription opioids because of their various dangers  including their deprivation of functionality and almost certain addiction.

The DEA is depriving my son and his family of his life!!!  Without having access to kratom, he is much less functional  totally.  His company that has been so successful under his leadership has fallen apart, and the employees have lost their jobs.  Tax payments by the company have fallen to a tiny fraction of what they have been until this fall.

We (and our sons wife) are very afraid that we are losing our son once again.  At best, losing him to depression and loss of ability to function.  At worst, we are facing the possibility that his depression might lead to the threat of suicide (which he threatened in the time soon after his accident!).  WE NEED HELP!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  WE NEED KRATOM TO REMAIN LEGAL AND AVAILABLE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Sincerely,

Brenda P. McMahan (Age: 63)
Retiree

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I am writing to you today to urge the DEA to reconsider its stance on Kratom (mitragyna Speciosa)  and reverse the decision to schedule Kratom as a controlled substance. Over the last 7 years I have interacted with hundreds of individuals whose lives have been positively impacted by Kratom. The scientific and medical research suggests many useful benefits of Kratom, and if it were made a scheduled drug this would greatly limit the future research that could be done on this amazing plant. I believe that Kratom does not pose an imminent threat to public health, and the few negative effects that individuals have reported are far overblown and exaggerated. I do not personally know a single person whose life or health has been endangered due to Kratom. When compared to many other products freely available to the public, Kratom falls very far down on the list of potentially hazardous products. We live in a day and age where there are many, very serious threats to public safety, including opiate and prescription drug abuse, resulting in 35-40+ deaths per day. It would far better serve the public to invest more resources into fighting current, and very real, threats such as opiates, as opposed to scheduling a substance that does not pose a large risk, at all. If Kratom were to be scheduled, it would do FAR more damage than if it were to remain legal, and would require resources we simply don't have to be put into enforcing these laws, which will only put innocent people in jail and ruin the lives and families of thousands. Please consider this, and every other piece of evidence out there, when making your determination.  Lives are at risk here, but not for the reasons the DEA may believe. Show us, the public, that we can still trust and have faith in our government to make rational decisions that serve the public, and not private interests. Prohibition has been a costly and failed battle over the last 100+ years. We need to find a better option that doesn't destroy lives and families, create black markets, turn innocent people into criminals, and benefit corporate interests at the expense of the public our government is supposed to represent.

documents.commentText: I took kratom for about two years to help elevate my mood. I experimented with the dosage and found a ceiling effect (i.e. I could only take a certain amount to get the effect, doubling the amount does nothing.) The effects are similar to coffee (elevates mood, gives energy, kept me very regular). I initially tried kratom because I wanted to get off of my SSRI Rx, which I would describe as a dangerous drug. Since then kratom has been made illegal in my state. I live in Wisconsin which is always at the top of the list for alcohol consumption, abuse, deaths, DUIs, etc but remains legal. Kratom doesn't get you high and it isn't a drug anymore than chamomile tea is. Actually, I would describe it as a tea...a plant you can put in hot water and drink.if you tried it you might not understand what all the fuss is about (both for and against it.) Thank you for reading.

documents.commentText:
I never thought I would be writing the DEA, but this issue is of the utmost importance to me. I am writing to you as a former heroin addict. I thank God every day that I am not involved with heroin anymore. However I know that I could not have gotten completely sober without as much as a transitionary month long period where I used Kratom to wean off of heroin. I am aware that Methadone and suboxone are the other alternatives to my own approach, but these two drugs are dangerous and addicting opiates just like heroin is. I have multiple friends who have gone the route of methadone or suboxone maintenance and the problem for me with those routes is the cost and the amount of time it takes to be completely off of every single opiate. Opiate maintenance is a godsend for many while a money drainage for others who cannot afford it. It took me one month and $40 to get off of heroin without much difficulty. Most people on methadone that I personally know have been in the program for a year on average. There is no reason it should be this way.  Heroin is cheaper than ever right now with the epidemic and it frightens me because I know that the cheap price and extreme potency of heroin is where it draws it's power from. I understand how weak my argument is because I am only using personal anecdotes so I will present another one. 

       Prescription opiates and illicit opiates are on record for killing hundreds if not thousands of Americans every single year. I challenge you to find one death strictly involving Kratom. I am not trying to be arrogant.  If you do find one please publish your findings  so I can admit to being at fault.  Many Americans use kratom as a substitute for dangerous narcotics whether it be for chronic pain or maintenance. If you really want to fight the opiate epidemic take this into account before banning Kratom. The average dose of kratom is 4-6 grams. The iron law of prohibition has shown in the past that criminals only respond to prohibition by smuggling smaller more potent chemicals. This is taking place right before our eyes with the fentanyl/carfentanil overdoses being reported across the nation with more and more frequency. Instead of dragging more heroin into the country these criminal organizations are just putting stronger substances in their own heroin. 

      I say with utmost sincerity that I would rather have your organzation spending my tax dollars on going after drugs that  professionals have on record  actually  killing  people opposed to kratom.  If kratom were to be banned then that would imply time and money spent on kratom busts. The time and the money is much better spent busting people for selling drugs that have been proven fatal.  Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,


It seems that many people are benefiting from kratom, and banning it would worsen their lives. To make kratom a schedule 1 drug is even a bigger disgrace for a number of reasons.

First, the idea that "the... substance has no currently accepted medical treatment use in the U.S." is completely false. It has improved the livelihood of many people who were suffering from addiction and chronic pain. 

Second, to lump together a plant with substances such as heroin, LSD, mescaline, psilocybin, bath salts, and methaqualone is outrageous. 

Lastly, this all appears to be benefiting "big pharma," who use lobbyists and donations to sway public officials. This is not an American ideal.

While I'm not a kratom user or kratom advocate, I strongly believe that this substance needs additional research before banning it outright. Please do the right thing.

documents.commentText:
I am a 50-year-old father, husband, and small business owner. I have a very close and wonderful family with two high achieving teenage boys in high school. I own a very successful local business that employs 7 people full time. 

I also suffer from moderate depression and anxiety. I have used western medicine and tradition talk therapy over the years to manage my symptoms. Due to side-effects, harsh withdrawals, and a natural disposition toward naturopathic remedies I found that most pharmaceutic solutions are not a long-term solution. It was easier to just deal with the symptoms and the reduced quality of life.

I found Kratom last year, and it was a massive relief. Taken in small to moderate doses it completely eliminated my symptoms. The mood enhancement allowed me to let go of the struggle and concentrate more on the important things in life like family and work. My business has thrived since I started taking Kratom and all those around me have benefited.
I DO NOT take this herb to get high, but rather to balance out a serious propensity toward an uncontrollable anxiety and depression. Taken once a day about 4-5 days a week is all I need. I am responsible in my dosages and take care to take a break every week as to not increase tolerance. When I stop I do not experience much withdrawal with the exception of some occasional sleeplessness. 

The few times I took more than my usual dosage I has the unpleasant experience of nausea. This passed after an hour or so, and was a reminder that there is no way for me to overdo it.

While I feel that this herb should be regulated like any other substance for ingestion, I do not believe that it should be scheduled with other very hard drugs with no medical uses. To cut-off the possibility for further research and force the use of the drug underground will have adverse effects on the possibly millions of individuals who are now using it responsibly. Disallow any adulteration of the leaf and make the minimum age to buy be 21.
 
Thank you for your consideration allowing public comment on this very important issue.

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE THINKING?

documents.commentText: I am a 42 year old husband and father of 2. In 2005 I was diagnosed with a degenerative disc disease in my lower back which caused me constant pain and discomfort. It make working very difficult and exercise nearly impossible. I had to take a desk job that required no heavy lifting and over the course of a few years I gained 70lbs. My docotor, a spine and scoliosis specialist prescribed me various drugs including oxycodone and tramadol. After a while my tolerance built to the oxycodone and I had to take more to get the same effect. I developed chronic constipation and a dependence on oxycodone.I realized I was headed towards addiction so I began looking into other options. I had tried physical therapy, injections, massage therapy, hydrotherapy and on and on but none worked well enough to get me off of painkillers. In 2010 I found kratom while doing some online research. I ordered some from a reputable vendor and tried the recommended amount in a tea. It gave me quite a bit of relief and I thought if I used I could lower my dependence on other medications. Within a month I found that I didn't need painkillers at all. Kratom gave me enough relief from the constant ache that I was able to ween myself from all prescription pain meds. I was able to start excercising and lost 75lbs within 18 months. I began coaching my eldest son's soccer team and could stand long enough to play bass guitar in a band again. My energy returned to what it was before my diagnosis and I felt as if I had my life back. I still have to do physical therapy and I visit a massage therapist. Kratom does not completely eliminate the feeling in my lower back but it takes it from a dull, aching pain to a mild discomfort. If kratom is banned I don't know what I'll do. I don't want to go back on painkillers and I don't want to stop being active. I don't want to go back down the road to dependence, obesity and isolation. Please do not ban kratom.

documents.commentText:
I am a practicing attorney who has seen first hand how the Government's thoughtless scheduling of controlled substances has destroyed lives. I have further seen how it has created a black market that directly enriches criminals and terrorist organizations. If an adult would like to consume Kratom to improve his health and well-being the Government should not ban the substance. Criminalizing Kratom would create a black market for the product on the dark web where there will be no regulation or oversight of what is being sold to consumers.  

Prohibition does not work. The US attempted to prohibit the consumption of alcohol and it had deadly results. The prohibition of alcohol led to dangerous moonshine that blinded and killed people as well as the rise of criminal bootlegging and large organized crime. Heroin is a schedule 1 controlled substance yet its use is at an all-time high. Further, deaths from heroin/opiates are at a record high because the scheduling of heroin led to it becoming an underground product sold by criminals with no oversight. These criminals add adulterants such as fentanyl to the heroin they sell on the street, which leads to unnecessary deaths. 

I have read many studies regarding the use of Kratom to help  individuals recovering from heroin addiction. Outlawing Kratom will take away this tool for recovery and it will absolutely lead to unnecessary deaths. 

The Federal Government should not be regulating morality. It is reasonable to restrict sales to minors or even to require an FDA warning against consumption but to outlaw the plant or its derivatives is beyond reason.  

Kratom has been used for decades by individuals in the US and hundreds of years outside the US. As far as I am aware only 15 deaths have listed Kratom use as a possible cause. 14 of those 15 cases involved the mixing of Kratom with illegal substances. However, even if one considers all 15 of these deaths to be somehow related to Kratom use it would not justify the banning of the substance and would absolutely not be a reason for an emergency scheduling of the substance. Alcohol kills more people in a single day that Kratom ever has. Tobacco products kill more people in a day that all kratom involved deaths on record in the US. The Government is willing to tax and build wealth off of the death of tobacco and alcohol users so this reasoning for a ban is flawed. 

Moreover, both alcohol and tobacco use pose dangers to non-users. Second-hand smoke kills and causes asthma. Alcohol leads to violent crime, drunk driving, and otherwise but non-users in harm's way.  This is not the case with Kratom. Someone taking a kratom tablet does not give off any second-hand smoke to injure those around him. 33% of traffic fatalities are the result of alcohol consumption. Conversely, Kratom ingestion has not been connected to a single traffic fatality in the US. 

This country has a drug problem. The problem is the crisis of imprisoning people for using substances that are scheduled arbitrarily and unsuccessfully. There is no reason for Kratom to become a controlled substance. It cannot be justified. 

The criminalization of Kratom use would serve no purpose but to enrich criminals, terrorists, and private prisons. 

I urge the Federal Government not to pass any laws scheduling or outlawing Kratom.

Thank you for your consideration in this matter.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
IF A MAN WANTS TO KEEP WORKING BUT SUFFERS FROM PAIN


There are not many options left for the man that lives in pain.
You take whatever it takes to keep moving; then keep moving. You cannot afford to miss work. So, you dont. This is where the problem lies if one is taking opiates. Three weeks of horrible pain and your tolerance is built up. Then to start your day requires abnormal amounts of drugs. . 
    I want to get the treatment for my pain that is the reason for the pain clinic I was going to. The system is so broken that I cannot get the care I need or deserve.
    I have found a plant that helps me almost as much with my pain and I am able to function much better.  
I may not be able to continue the course of action I have chosen because the plant I use to control my pain is called Kratom. It is much less destructive to me than taking opiates. A hell of a lot safer for me than trying to kill the pain with alcohol. Does alcohol work? Yes, but it does not leave me functional in the least. Have I taken too much Kratom? Yes, I got very sick to my stomach. That was it!
     Does this plant help with pain? I know it helps my pain. I chose to try it because I read over and over again, of people just like me (IN PAIN) and they claimed it helped them. Does it kill all of the pain? No, but neither do the prescription meds. Does it help me function? Yes! I have become a very independant person thanks to being able to kill my pain enough to work and to even play a little.
   Ive had several problems with my back and shoulders.  My arm/shoulder now hurts so bad I can barely sleep some nights. I cannot reach straight out in front of me and pick up a coffee cup. It hurts months on end. If I try to do any tree work using a hand saw I am in unbearable  pain.  I also have DDD and even sciatic nerve pain from time to time. I have had cluster headaches since I was 4 or 5. I broke my skull when I was 7. Life long allergies; allergy shots for over a decade of my childhood. Rheumatic fever when I was ten.
      I worked climbing, trimming and removing trees for 25 years. I served my country for 3 years, Airborne! I have 2 children that are grown and productive individuals. I have accomplished much in my life and have a lot of life left. At times my headaches were so frequent that I did not want to live any longer. Think, major brain freeze that lasts for two to three hours with someone stabbing an ice pick into one of your eyeballs and you come close to what a cluster headache is. The last cycle ended around 2001 and every now and then I feel a twinge like one may be coming on, but Thank God they have not yet. They will be back one day.
        LIving in pain is DEATH. It completely rewires the brain. You cannot do anything you want to do. It is not a life.
    Do I still have pain? Yes. Can I function? Yes.  But not because of anything the broken system has done to help me. I had to search for a way to survive. I have found it and have a life as close to normal as one can have working nights and doing physical labor with a bad back and neck.  Just as my life is getting back to normal after nearly a year of school and I have made a plan to just deal with things on my own and use the money for something useful instead of throwing it away on useless insurance. I cannot afford the cost of insurance and then co-pays. The specialist and pain clinics are not affordable, I tried. The broken system is USELESS.
    I plead with the powers that be to keep this useful Godsend of a plant legal and allow the research to be done on it. By all means restrict the sale of it to keep it away from minors and insure the purity of the product but dont change it. Please do not make it illegal. It is very helpful for my pain. I do not want to die from pain medication. Pain medication is never prescribed in dosages that will allow you to live. If you do not get enough of it, you cannot function and if you get enough of it then the end of it is death. Pain management needs every way it can be given to work. This plant called Kratom helps me live. Over the last 4 years I have found a much better way to help with my pain and to be able to function in society. I want to work and be productive. I want to live.


Thank you

documents.commentText:
My family is from the Pacific Northwest. My great grandfather retired from the railroad, my grandfather from a pulp mill and my father was a machinist at a paper mill. He also became the oldest man in our county to pass the deputy sheriff's physical and become a reserve deputy sheriff at the age of 40. He spent his 'spare' time as president of our county's volunteer search and rescue and learned to pilot their helicopter. 
When growing up I learned that the law was the law. There were no gray areas. If you didn't agree with a law, you wrote an initiative, gathered signatures and tried to change it, but you followed it. 
I remember my 18th birthday because it came three days after the election that year and I had to wait another full year to exercise my right to vote.  I have not missed an election in the following 40 years. 
I have been an automotive bookkeeper since 1977, working for three major automotive companies in my area. I have been a law abiding , tax paying, contributing member of society my whole life. 
16 years ago I had to stop working and apply for disability due to degenerative disc disease. From that point on my life changed dramatically. I was put on opiates to manage my chronic pain. My life soon began to rotate around my next dose of medicine  and I became the grandmother who read, played card games and board games, and sat quietly with my grandchildren because I was not able to get down and play with them. I could watch them at the park but could not participate. I had trouble attending their concerts, their soccer games and other activities. My life was centered around my pain, period. 
In February I found kratom and my life has been changing for the better ever since then. I am attending birthday parties, playing with my grandkids and even got in the pool with them for the first time this summer. We played a little frisbee. 
I am vacuuming my own house, doing my own grocery shopping and I could go on and on..
While my pain is by no means gone, and my incurable disease is not cured, my life is greatly improved. 
Kratom is legal:  in my state, in the US, in Mexico, and in Canada, as a natural herbal supplement. 
I have been watching the war on drugs since it's  inception. I am not naive enough to believe that kratom will no longer be available, if it is placed on a  schedule by the DEA. 
If that happens I will have one of two choices. To go back to the depression of a pain filled, useless life on opiates, or to become a felon. Me;  a felon, (!?!?!)
over a cup of tea that improves my life. 
This is not the America that I grew up in.
There are many terrible things out there that should be scheduled, alcohol and tobacco come to mind, but this all natural leaf is not one of them. 
Kratom is safe, it's affordable, and it's effective. 
Please step out of the ring, there is no fight here, for you. 
	?	
Sincerely,
Nancy J Sawyer

documents.commentText:
Kratom should not be banned. 
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern, 

My name is James T. and I am a married 37 year old Father of 2 

I'd like to voice my opposition to the DEA's Intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa), a schedule 1 controlled substance with no medicinal value. 

I personally have never been addicted to opiates, but about 4 years ago I tore my rotator cuff during a softball game and was in extreme pain, I could hardly work and my doctor wanted to start putting me on pain medication and eventually do surgery. I have personally seen many of my peers get very hooked on these same pain med's, and I was very scared to go down that path. One day I was watching video's online and I saw a News article about this plant from south east Asia that was related to the coffee plant and had been helping people all over the country kick their opiate habits and was also being used by other people to ease their chronic pain. After doing some Intense research, I noticed there were hundreds of testimonials from people praising this plant for being a great natural alternative to opiate pain medication without being Highly addictive and not having all these crazy side effects like other pharmaceutical opiates have, Especially respiratory depression

I decided it was worth a try since it was legal. I bought some online and was completely amazed how well it worked!! I was now able to go to work, take care of my family, and not have to worry about being led down the dark path of pain pills! i'm not going to Lie, There is a slight mood lift you get from kratom, but it is nowhere near what would be considered an actual "High". It is more like a feeling of relief that you don't have to live in pain anymore!! That alone is enough to put anyone who suffers into a good mood.

I would also like to point out that there was one accidental side effect from kratom. I use to drink alcohol every night after work to try and ease my pain, Without even trying, Kratom completely removed the Urge to Drink Everyday!! It was really amazing since I had no plans on quitting drinking, but since I have, my life and my marriage have been better than ever!!

And now the DEA wants to take that away from me and many others with similar stories??

My story is nothing compared to the stories of countless people who were able to get their lives back by using this all natural and very safe and effective tree leaf. For the Government to come in and say that this plant has NO medicinal value and belongs in a class of drugs that are extremely dangerous and Highly Addictive (excluding Cannabis which also should have never been made Schedule 1in the first place) is an absolute travesty and is completely absurd!! I have personally been using Kratom on and off for 4 years and I have never felt one ounce of withdrawal. I Never did end up having surgery and to this day my pain in my shoulder is maganged very safely and easliy with kratom

The bottom line is, kratom is a safe alternative to pharmaceutical drugs with important Dietary uses and has changed my life. Many of us in the community feel that the DEA is abusing it's power for the purposes of the pharmaceutical Industry. We know that big pharma has already Patented the two Compounds Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine for the purposes of being synthesized and we already know that they have a new pain Killing drug called PZM21 that is synthesized directly from these two compounds. I'm not saying that they shouldn't synthesize these compounds for people who want to take them through their Doctor, but to BAN those alkaloids for the purpose of the drug Industries monopolization of them is downright dangerous and Immoral. For me, I will go on with my life without kratom, But for the people out there who have diseases like Endomitriosis, Fibromyalgia, Rheumetoid Arthritis, ETC... This Ban will literally put some of those people in very bad positions! Just Imagine people who suffered for 15-20 years because of the pain regimens they were put on by their doctors, who have finally found relief in this plant, They now will ALL be left in the dark only to go back to their doctors and get addicted to these terrible pain killers once again!! I can tell you one thing, I would NOT want to be in their shoes...Would you??


At the end of the day, This ban on kratom will be more dangerous to society than this plant ever will be, In Alabama, Heroin Use skyrocketed after they banned Kratom, If you think the opiate problem is bad now, Just wait....

documents.commentText:
I am a forty-one year-old software engineer from Austin, TX. I am a loving husband and father of one son. I am writing to express my disapproval of the DEAs intent to place kratom on the Schedule I list of controlled substances. Kratom has helped me maintain a healthy, active lifestyle, and to be a better father and a more engaged, productive professional. Criminalizing kratom would result in a huge setback for people who -- like me -- have found a way to help improve their lives in a natural way. We are harmless, and only interested in being the best parents, professionals, and humans we can be.

I discovered kratom in 2011. At the time, I was heavily medicated for depression, overweight, and had no energy to spend time playing with my four year-old son. I was falling asleep at my desk at work and struggling to be productive. I was also drinking at least several days per week. After a week of trying kratom, I had energy again. Within a month, I was playing kickball in the backyard with my son, even after a long day's work. Instead of taking naps after work while he watched TV, I was a dad again. At work, I began contributing again, and it was quite a novelty not to nod off during a meeting!

Today, my career is back on track. Im working to improve my skills as a software engineer daily (and nightly). I now work out four times a week and enjoy power lifting, and am about thirty pounds lighter than I was five years ago. My interest in/desire for alcohol has also decreased, and my alcohol intake is limited to weekends. Overall, I am a healthier and happier person. While I wouldnt make the claim that kratom has been a panacea, I can say it has been a catalyst thats driven me to make better lifestyle decisions and ultimately become a healthier person.

Please consider the thousands of us who are good, decent, tax-paying citizens. We are loyal employees, spouses, and devoted parents who simply want to be healthy. Undoubtedly, the pharmaceutical industry has -- and will continue to -- provide important and life-saving drugs. That doesnt mean that we shouldnt have the choice to seek alternative natural treatments for ourselves. We are not criminals.

Thank you for your time.

While I am aware that there are segments of society that abuse or overly rely on certain medications it is necessary to keep thing's in perspective. documents.commentText:
I am very new to kratom (Mitragynine speciosa), and this plant was recommended to me by a friend. 
 I suffer from disc degeneration in my spine from C6, C7, and T1, bone spurs, nerve damage, and constant muscle spasms in BOTH shoulders (trapezius and associated muscle complexes).  My neck muscles are also involved, and this causes daily headaches, some of which are severe, as they affect my occipital nerve and cause what are called 'suicide headaches'; I now understand why that term is used, as this kind of pain pushes you into a desperate place to try and alleviate the pain!
Everything I have tried so far, under the direction of my primary doctor, nerve specialist, and physical therapists have failed: ibuprofen or aspirin, ice, heat, physical therapy, strength and endurance training, physical activity, laproscopic surgery of my right rotator cuff (not the problem!), cortisone injections, and even radio-frequency ablation of the facet joint nerves in my neck!!
Nothing has healed or even helped my neck/shoulder problem, and this year I've been experiencing nerve pain going down BOTH my arms: my left thumb goes numb and becomes weak enough that I'm afraid I will drop something I try and lift; and my right arm is now having serious problems as well. I am afraid that nerve damage is affecting my hand dexterity and strength.
I DO NOT take opioids for this severe pain, although I understand that many people do take opioids for severe muscle and nerve pain.  
I recently found kratom to be very helpful to manage my terrible physical condition. Kratom is allowing me to work productively at my job (which I'm sure is more helpful to the government than me being on disability forever!), it is relaxing my muscle spasms to the point I can actually get some relief and have some productive results from exercise, and it is helpful for my severe nerve pain and headaches.
Please do NOT make a plant that has traditionally helped people for hundreds of years to find relief a Schedule I drug!!  Mitragynine speciosa needs to be rigorously examined and tested by scientific and medical institutions to determine its value to society. It is NOT physically addictive and has very little side effects, compared to prescription narcotic opioids. From what I understand, there is a national crisis happening right now because of American dependence pain-relieving opioids...wouldn't it be helpful to offer an alternative to prescription narcotic addictive drugs and assist people to get away from that horrible dependency?
As I said, I do NOT use prescription OR illegal opioid narcotic drugs, so that is not an issue for me, but constant nerve and muscle pain is a REAL problem for me, and I have found that kratom really helps me to feel better, be more productive, and to have less pain.  Please DO NOT make mitragynine an illegal drug; but treat it as what it should be, a natural plant with amazing potential to help people with serious debilitating pain and physical problems!
Thank you, Karen Hatch

documents.commentText:
Just want to give you my experience with Kratom:

I am a registered nurse, I was injured in 2007 with a back injury that kept me off work for one year.  After many physical therapy sessions and drug (medication) counseling, I was able to return to work.  A typical day would start out by taking two #10 Norco just to be able to get moving, mid day I would need another pain pill, and by evening (bed time) I would need 2-3 more pain pills to sleep.  This cycle went on for years, until my brother told me about Kratom.   After tying it and finding the strand and dosage that worked best for me I am no longer taking the Norco (Vicodin).  I feel much better physically and mentally.  I am able to work longer shifts at the hospital, l where I am a sedation nurse.  I have never been, or felt impaired from kratom to not be able to do my job safely.  I have told a lot of my patients who struggle with the same chronic pain about kratom, and have heard back from them how much better they feel, finally getting off the narcotics.

I understand the DEA wanting to regulate the production of kratom to maintain its purity, but to classify it as a schedule 1 drug is crazy.  I hope that you do your own research, and even try kratom yourself to see that it is not harmful.  I also hope it remains legal, otherwise I will be forced to go back on narcotics for my pain relief, I've been off for over 3 years.

Thank you,
Lisa Balestreri  RN

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern. 
My name is Sarah, and I am a married, have a job, have children, and a 4-year degree. I am also a volunteer EMT.  For more than 20 years, I have had dysmenorrhea and endometriosis, for which I have at times used prescription painkillers (legally prescribed by my doctor).  About three years ago, a friend of mine recommended a supplement called M. Speciosa. I decided to do my research on the active ingredients, and it sounded promising, so I contacted a distributor with a sterling reputation and ordered some. 
    The difference it has made for me is immeasurable. I am aware that it has some opioid-like effects, but when I use it for my cramping, I don't feel "drugged," or nauseated, which I regularly experienced with my pain prescription. I am aware now that people misuse this supplement, and I am NOT opposed to regulation, but a Schedule 1 classification would close the doors on research and all the other positive and negatives that are not entirely known. This supplement has made a huge difference for me and my ability to function during menstruation. Please do not broadly classify this as something with no legitimate uses, when it has helped me so greatly. 
     Respectively and Sincerely, Sarah C.

documents.commentText: While I believe that it is good that the DEA has been given the ability to deal with dangerous drugs in an expedited fashion, I also believe that in order to exercise that power it must provide a fairly high level of proof/persuasion that said drugs should be placed into Schedule 1 (even if temporarily). I don't believe that the DEA has met this level of proof. In regard to "no accepted medical use", there have been synthetic drugs produced from these alkaloids. Please refer to https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18550129, jpet.aspetjournals.org/content/348/3/383.full, and https://www.google.com/patents/US20100209542. And in regard to "high potential for abuse", I see no evidence for this produced by the DEA. One confirmed death attributed solely to kratom use should not constitute an imminent hazard. Even the misstatement in the notice of intent that the alkaloids in kratom are opioids reveals a need for additional persuasive proof for scheduling by the DEA.

documents.commentText:
Hello, my name is Mario and I'm a carpenter from California. 

Please do not make Kratom illegal. It is a very safe plant and it poses no threat to society. In my personal experience, Kratom is a wonderful tea leaf and I have never had any concerns or problems with its use. I consume it on a daily basis and it has improved my life substantially. Kratom does not make you feel "high" or cause addiction. It is very mild, much like coffee. 

The DEA and the FDA have been very biased and unfair with their approach to Kratom. They have made some wild, absurd, and untrue claims about this plant. They say that it causes respiratory depression, addiction, and death. We Kratom consumers know this is not true. The scientific community also knows this is not true. Yet DEA/FDA refuse to accept the facts, and will not listen to common sense and reason. Why are they so determined to ban a harmless tea leaf? Are they corrupt agencies? Are they basing their decisions on a hidden political agenda? This seems to be the case, since no reasonable person would consider Kratom an "imminent threat to public health". Their negative claims against Kratom are a flat out lie.

Kratom should be freely accessible to all Americans who choose to use it. The government should not ban this safe and useful plant. They have NO legitimate reason to even be concerned about Kratom in the first place.

Please stop wasting OUR tax money on this pointless Kratom witch hunt. If you want to save Americans from an imminent threat to public safety, focus on the opioid epidemic which kills tens of thousands of people a year. Kratom has killed 0, and will most likely never result in a single death. 

Keep kratom legal!
Ban the DEA/FDA's stupidity!

documents.commentText:
I found out about kratom through a co-worker about seven (7) months ago.  I was skeptical at first because I personally do not believe in herbs.  I take over the counter meds when in pain which is rare.  However,  everything that he said about it peaked my interest but I was still apprehensive. 

My reason for finally trying/taking kratom was for temporary back pain.  I strained myself at work and typically just deal with it.  I recall having a busy work week and needed relief from my pain to be productive.  I took kratom and didn't think it was working cause I didn't feel anything.  Since I wasn't sure what to expect I continued my workday and believed kratom was just another gimmick.  Anyhow, I completed an 8 hour day with NO PAIN!   What's great is I didn't even realize it till the end of the day.  I thought to myself that my body must have healed itself.  Unfortunately,  it was back the next morning.

That morning, I wanted kratom but didn't have any.  I couldn't believe the difference in my productivity (lack of) and the pain I had...wow!   I then realized that this herb was different and did work!  I didn't feel it working because it worked so naturally. 

My back pain eventually went away over time but kratom helped me through it!   I continued taking kratom because I noticed a drop in my anxiety level.  I also noticed how alert and focused I was which is essential in my line of work. I am able to keep better relationships with customers due to being in a better mood.  To include, kratom actually made work fun for me and I am an electrician in Florida!  I work in very high temperatures.  I noticed kratom made it bearable.

To summarize,  kratom worked for my pain, anxiety,  mood lifting, made me more productive and the heat tolerable, helps me stay focused, energized, slowed down in drinking alcohol, and cigarettes are lasting longer cause the taste is not as good.  

Since kratom I am able to wake up at 4:45 am, five days a week without dreading my day.  I feel tired at first but then take kratom and it gives me the energy I need to get going.   I can actually skip that cup of coffee in the morning!   

So, with everything I've experienced and have learned about kratom I am at a total loss as to why kratom in its purest form would be banned or an emergency schedule 1?  The agendas are not matching up.

At this time,  I am in hopes and plead that the DEA keeps this herb legal so that I (a responsible adult) can continue purchasing kratom and using it accordingly.

documents.commentText:
My name is Tracy Young. I am 42 years old. I co-manage a business and I am also a freelance writer. I am a cancer survivor and I also have endometriosis with adhesions and severe tendonitis. I have lived with chronic, oftentimes debilitating pain for most of my adult life. I had a rare form of soft tissue sarcoma which required 3 major surgeries to remove. It seemed as if the surgeons could not figure out where my cancer ended and my body began. Despite the fact that my right leg looks as if it has been ripped from my body and stitched back on, I feel lucky to be alive. This was, and is my reality. I live with the fact that my cancer can recur at any time. 
I discovered kratom by accident about 6 years ago. After years of being prescribed loads of opioid painkillers, anti-depressants and anti-anxiety medications, and dealing with the plethora of ill effects that always seemed to outweigh the benefits, I was ready to throw in the towel. I began exploring more natural alternatives. One afternoon a friend of mine offered me some capsules which contained some powdered leafy material. He told me it was a plant called kratom, and claimed that it had been very effective with helping him live a relatively normal life after dealing with injuries he suffered in a construction accident. I was skeptical, but I decided to give it a go. I am very, very glad I did. 
Long story short, kratom has helped me on multiple levels. I have a job where I am on my feet all day, every day. Kratom has eliminated my reliance on fistfuls of ibuprofen and prescription drugs just to get through my day. I consume the same modest amount every day, and it is always effective. My pain, depression and anxiety are all manageable thanks to this simple healing leaf. 
After enduring the nightmare of cancer, I was offered the opportunity to apply for disability benefits. This was unacceptable to me then, and it is still unacceptable to me today. I knew I could do better, and with the help of this plant I have a very abundant life when prescription medications threatened to rob me of the ability to provide for myself, and to be of service to my family. 
It is important that we cut through all the hysteria and sensationalism and really get to the heart of the matter. Based on my own personal experience, I feel as if kratom is relatively harmless on the spectrum of addictive substances. Please reconsider the temporary scheduling of this plant. It is helped far more people than it could possibly ever harm. Thank you for your time. 

Sincerely, 

Tracy D. Young

documents.commentText:
I have used Kratom for quite some time.  It has helped me treat depression, anxiety, and pain very inexpensively.

I am surprised that at the same time marijuana is becoming legalized in several states, kratom is under consideration to be scheduled.  Furthermore, kratom has keeps me from using substances like alcohol (which is known to be addictive, and very harmful to the health of the user and others around the user) to control my severe symptoms.  

If kratom is is scheduled, I will not be surprised if heroin use, opioid medication abuse, and alcohol abuse all increase.  In addition, more deaths from the use and trafficking of these substances will likely occur.  Furthermore, it will add to an already overloaded prison population as more people are charged with possession of substances.  Finally, other medications available over the counter are more dangerous than kratom, such as Tylenol, which can be fatal at high doses, whereas kratom is not.

Scheduling this substance will only harm the people of the United States.  I am extremely disappointed that it is being considered, and that the DEA recently tried to rush it to schedule 1 status.  The DEA must complete more objective research on how useful this substance is to many people compared to other effects it may have.  Yes, it can be addictive, but so is alcohol, tobacco, gambling, pornography, etc.  Do not schedule this substance based on the potential for addiction alone.

Please, consider the possible effects of banning this material and the lives lost due to a ban before you make a final decision.  Make the decision with extreme caution.

I am writing this in hopes that the DEA will avoid making Kratom a class 1 scheduled substance. I am a 40 year old homemaker who discovered kratom through the news coverage of the possible ban in September.  I have been using it since the first part of September.  I have benefited greatly from Kratom.  I use a very small dose (1/4 of a teaspoon) a few times a day. I get no "high" feeling whatsoever but my pain levels from a chronic condition are mitigated greatly and my energy levels are better.  I have two small children that have benefited from me finding this, as well, as I can keep up with them and do more things with them than I am normally able to do. 

This herb should not require a prescription anymore than St John's Wort or 5-HTP does.    Adults, not the government, should be able to choose whether or not they want to use kratom, just as they can use any other herbal supplement. I don't think responsible use of kratom is unsafe in any way or form.  People are doing much more damage to themselves from cigarettes and alcohol that are totally legal.  Sure, it may be abused by some but they are in less danger than those that abuse prescription drugs or alcohol.  
 
I believe categorizing kratom as a schedule 1 controlled substance would be taking away the rights we have to choose our own path.  If I, as a woman, have the right to rip a baby out of my womb because it is in my body and I don't want it there, then I should have the same freedom to put what I choose into my body.  This is not a "drug" that needs to be controlled.  In 2014 18,893 people died from Pharmaceutical Opioid Analgesics according to the CDC. 15,000 people a year die from misusing over the counter NSAIDS.  Any deaths that can be linked to kratom use that I can find, anywhere, were due to using it in a large volume in combination with other drugs.  There is nothing to show that those deaths wouldn't have occurred anyway from the users abuse of other substances. 

 So, in conclusion, don't do it.  Don't make this another thing that helps over fills our jails for no reasons and vilifies a leaf.

To whom it may concern:

I would like to suggest that it is a government's responsibility to address public health crises. This country has a major issue with opiate addiction. Kratom has anecdotally been shown to mitigate the effects of opiate addiction and withdrawal. It would be wholly irresponsible and unethical in the face of such a crisis to identify Kratom as a schedule one drug and grossly limit, if not prevent entirely, any research of this substance. This substance can be a tool to combat the very same life shattering opponents that the DEA works each day to address. Be ethical, be responsible, and leave Kratom off any lists that would further inhibit research of the substance.

documents.commentText:
My experiences with kratom start about 8 months into a bad back injury. My doctor prescribed me 100 Vicodin a month for  bulging discs in my lower back. I took them as directed at first, but they ceased being effective and I started doubling up and taking them in between doses. I started running out before the months would end. I was on them so long and so regularly that I would get very bad withdrawal symptoms if I went more than 18 hours without a pill. I started getting scared that my "medication" was taking over my life. I gained weight because pills made me lethargic, and my back pain kept me from being active.

I knew I had to do something to break the cycle. I searched the Internet for ways to cope with the withdrawal and clear my system of the pharmaceuticals. I kept seeing "kratom" in forums for opiate recovery. I ordered a package from a reputable vendor (based on customer reviews) and took my last Vicodin. I didn't have another apt with my doctor to renew my prescription. 

The next afternoon, I began getting the typical withdrawal symptoms. A day later (and after a sleepless night) I called off work due to the withdrawal. Coincidently, my kratom arrived. I took a dose and 15 minutes later, I felt relief. This allowed me to spent the next 5 days in relative comfort compared to the usual pain. In addition to easing my withdrawal experience, my back pain was mitigated. Kratom gave me a chance to break the cycle of prescription pain killers.

I received a few epidural injections for my back and declined my doctors offer to renew my Vicodin prescription. I thank god kratom came along when it did or I fear my drug usage could have spiraled out of control. Nowadays, I take kratom a few times a week and at times forget about the chronic pain that took me to pills in the first place. Although it has been almost a year since I took pills, I still experience cravings. It seems kratom helps with that as well. My condition improved and I'm more active and have since completed a half marathon and 18 miles of a cross country running relay. My life has dramatically changed for the better since I discovered kratom and used it to quit painkillers.

Moving forward, I would like kratom to remain legal and accessible to addicts, pain patients, and anxiety sufferers. I can understand and appreciate government oversight and regulation, but ONLY IF KRATOM REMAINS LEGAL AND AVAILABLE. If scheduling occurs and kratom is unavailable, i fear that kratom users would return to their previous addictions. The opiate epidemic has taken friends and family from me, and I wish i had the opportunity to help them recover with kratom, just as I had.

documents.commentText:
Greetings DEA representative. This is Dennis Pelton. I am writing you today in order to voice my concern about the DEA banning the mitragyna speciosa (kratom) tree. I was first diagnosed with clinical depression at age 16. I am now 43 years of age. Since age 16 I have tried every pharmaceutical drug available to treat biochemical depression. None of them helped my condition. I only found relief for my life threatening condition after discovering & consuming kratom leaves. 
I have successfully used the leaves to treat my condition for the past 8 years with no negative side effects. If the kratom ban actually get's enforced. My greatest concern is for those that have served our Country & have come back from Iraq/Afghanistan & use kratom to treat permanent injuries that they have suffered overseas. I also feel for the elderly that use kratom to treat arthritis, fibromyalgia & many other medical disorders. The leaves of the kratom tree are saving hundreds of thousands of lives. Many will be forced to choose between staying alive & functional or obeying the arbitrary whim of the DEA and possibly dying! Or at the very least going back to a miserable life of suffering! For many this is not just a difference of opinion. It's a difference between life or death! 
     The banning of kratom will also be a burden to the health care system, insurance & government. Thousands are functional only because of kratom. Without access to this miracle plant they will go back to collecting a disability check instead of being a productive member of society. Kratom is paid for by the consumers. Not by insurance corporations or government (tax payer). However, if kratom is no longer accessible. People will have no choice but to go back to burdening the health care system & government. 
     Furthermore, has anyone actually taken the time to think about what the enforcement of this kratom ban would even look like? Picture wheelchair bound Iraq & Afghanistan veterans in handcuffs! Picture grandmothers suffering from fibromyalgia in handcuff's! This is after DEA thugs dressed in all black, wearing black ski masks kick in their front door! Videos of wheelchair bound disabled people in handcuffs being wheeled off to prison! Then after they get bailed out of jail they tell the press how they had DEA thugs point fully automatic weapons at their heads! It would be a public relations nightmare for the DEA!

documents.commentText:
First, let me introduce myself, my name is Misty Stutz, I am a wife and mother of three girls.  I have been with my husband for 20 years and our daughters are aged 16, 12 and 6. We are just your typical all American family. My daughter's enjoy many extracurricular actiavites, one does cheer and the others plays basketball and volleyball, the youngest seems to want to be a mixture of her sisters.  My husband runs a state funded company which provides home modifications for the handicapped and elderly, he loves his job.
In my mid 20's, I had my first anxiety attack while trying to go to college for nursing. It was one of the scariest things I have ever had happen to me. It was as if I suddenly lost control of what my mind was doing to my body. I tried seeing a Dr. In order to finish school, but the fear of the anxiety attacks and the fact that I kept having them, made me withdrawal instead.
Over the years since then, I have tried antidepressants and benzodiazepines to cope with my anxiety which led to depression. Yet, the side effects of these meds proved worse than the illness. The antidepressants Changed me as a person and even though they took the troublesome anxiety away, they also took the good anxiety away. We all need some anxiety to help us stay away from bad choices. After realizing this and dropping them, the withdrawal from them was an awful experience, cause jolts through my vains for weeks. Still, I tried different ones and still they all were generally the same. The benzodiazepines made me tired and slightly high, which was never something I wanted.  So, I spent many years finding any way possible to avoid leaving my house, because that usually kept the anxiety at bay, although it was depressing to feel like a prisoner to my house with my mind being the jailer.
Until I found kratom about a year ago. I was searching online for natural supplements that could aid me in fighting off these symptoms and was lucky to find kratom. I was very skeptical, but within a week, found myself feeling like myself. I never felt 'high' only a slight boost in energy and less fear of the unknown. This past year has been wonderful, I have been to all of my girls sporting events without one single incident. I have been able to volunteer more, which is a great way to combat depression. If this supplement is taken from me, I fear I'll once again be a prisoner to my mind and stuck in my home with the contant fear of the unkown and looking for every and any excuse to not do the things I love and enjoy. I also fear for our society, since recently reading how this one substance has helped so many addicts. I live in an area very negativity affected by the opiate epidemic. I would love to see the word spread about kratom, so these people could maybe get their lives back too. Although our means are different, I believe we are all victims of our minds (whether addicted or anxious) and this is something that really helps. Please reconsider your ban, as I assure you that anyone seeking this for a buzz or high will be greatly disappointed. Yet, anyone looking to take back control in their lives will find real relief in nothing more than a morning supplement. 
P.s. I apologize if my comment posted twice, as I just want to make sure it gets through once and haven't been able to verify the first one did. Thank you

documents.commentText: As a 48yo RN, I have seen many issues related to drugs. As a person who has multiple autoimmune disorders, I have done research into many prescription meds, treatment modalities and outcomes on more things than I could count. My life came to a screeching halt when my autoimmune issues took over. I have religiously followed my doctors orders, taken my meds and have no real relief. Upon learning of organ damage, I began to search out homeopathic solutions. Many of my support groups spoke about kratom. I could barely contain my excitement until I learned I lived in a state that had made it illegal. I cant break the law and risk jail time for a naturopathic assist to my health so that idea was scratched. Then, I was invited to a friends condo at the beach for a long weekend. Car trouble turned a 3 day trip into over a week. I hadn't packed enough meds and since my prescriptions had just been refilled, I was not able to get a prescription transferred to help me while on this trip. I suffer with fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue, chronic pain, hemicrania contuia, IBD, Sjogrens, Rayauds, anxiety, depression, DDD and other symptoms/issues related to the aforementioned ailments. Just a half day into my med shortage, I was desperate. My friend we stayed with offered some kratom tea made from powdered kratom. I immediately started more research and decided it was worth a try. I was amazed at how much better I felt. No high or even a slight buzz, just overall feeling better. My IBD had flared from the trip and my symptoms from that quickly subsided. I continued with the tea while out of state and I have to admit, I overall felt better than I had in a long time. Not wanting to risk trouble back home, I started my regular routine of meds.  I had no ill effects from stopping the kratom tea...NONE AT ALL. My symptoms from my varied conditions did come back along with the side effects of the medicines I regularly take. I decided then and there that homeopathic/naturopathic options need to be available to people like myself. I do also take honey, cinnamon and turmeric and after my personal experience and first hand knowledge, consider kratom tea to be along those same lines. It is (or was to me) a plant based alternative/adjunct to the harsh chemical compounds that make up the prescription medications that have caused organ damage. Is it a cure?  No.  Is it a drug? I would have to say NO. There is so much potential yet to be explored and by putting this plant and its compounds on a Schedule I list, you are taking away the possibility that this will receive research funding to see just exactly how much help it could be. It is so important that this plant be studied and used for whatever value it may have to a persons overall well being. Many of us are not wanting 'drugs' or a 'high', we simply want to be able to function at a near normal level. Please do not add kratom and its components to Schedule I. It is nothing like the substances that are there such as LSD. I personally felt no 'high' effects, no altered consciousness. This is the opportunity to leave this plant in the hands of people who seek natural ways to deal with their health and wellness. Think about how many times you have heard to eat a banana to stop a headache...does that make a banana dangerous or put the banana tree on a Schedule I seem reasonable? I think not. Adults need the ability to choose plants, natures bounty, as alternatives to their own health and well being.

documents.commentText: Due to my military service, I suffer from severe back pain (degenerative disc disease, osteoarthritis, spinal stenosis, bulging discs, sciatica, numbness in legs and feet), arthritis in my knees (one of which has progressed to bone-on bone), and periodic depression due to my physical condition. I have received on-going medical care since I retired from the military, which has included surgery, physical therapy, and multiple types of over-the-counter and prescription medications. Despite these efforts, I continue to suffer daily from severe pain. I currently take three prescription medications to control my pain. I have sought out alternative methods of pain relief. The best alternative pain relief that I have found is kratom. I am aware that the DEA has significant concerns involving kratom. However, from my personal experience, I can testify that kratom has a high medicinal value with no negative side effects. I have been using kratom for nine months. It helps my pain tremendously and has helped my depression. I have never felt high from kratom. It does not negatively affect my mental state I take kratom while I am at work and I have always remained clear headed and alert. I have never felt addicted to it and have never felt any withdrawal symptoms if I go without it for a few days. When I first started taking kratom, I accidentally took too much. I felt nauseous and vomited. However, my body experienced no other reactions from taking too much kratom and, after I vomited, I immediately felt fine. Kratom has significantly improved my quality of life and allows me to keep my prescription medicine at low doses. I am asking the DEA to not make kratom a schedule 1 drug, as kratom gives me, as well as many other people, a natural and safe way to treat their medical conditions without relying solely on prescription medication or resorting to "street" drugs.

documents.commentText:
re: 	URGENT -- DO NOT BAN THE SALE AND USE OF KRATOM

The DEA is insistent on banning the purchase and use of kratom.  Apparently they feel as if Americans are in immenent danger and that kratom is an opioid-like substance. Now, you're likely wondering "What's kratom?"  It wouldn't surprise me -- very few people are aware that kratom even exists. 

It is a gentle herbal supplement used primarily by older individuals to provide safe, non narcotic pain relief from arthritis and other aches and pains. I personally use kratom due to arthritis pain in my hand. I use kratom ONLY for flare ups and stop using it as soon as the pain subsides. I have never experienced withdrawal symptoms with discontinued use. 

There are many users who obtain relief from opiate withdrawal.  Since I've never been an addict, I can't describe its benefits for withdrawal. What I can  attest to is that kratom is NOT an addictive drug, it is not a synthetic party drug, it is not popular with millennials -- many of whom have never heard of it. The demographic of a typical kratom user  is 45-65 years old, suburban, middle class, employed. Generally all law abiding people. 

Kratom is not used merely to obtain a "high".  On the contrary, users quickly develop a tolerance to the "euphoric" side effect. Any attempt to misuse kratom to obtain a "high"  will result in nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and jitters but it will NOT result in respiratory arrest.

Another serious matter would be shutting down an entire industry. This ban would likely put tens of thousands of people out of work.  You must seriously consider the domino  effect as well.  The loss of this industry will cause irreperable harm to the economy. 

Yet another fact to consider is that President Obama worked very hard to overturn prison sentences of nearly 400 non-violent offenders. Adding a law against the sale and use of kratom will refill the prisons and overcrowd them with thousands of peaceful, law abiding people to become felons.

I've never even been arrested in my 57 years of life. I won't break the law, so now I'd have to begin the use of prescription narcotics. My doctor has offered to prescribe percocet, 10mgs, 3 times a day. I truly don't want to go there. I don't want to become an addict at this point in my life.

There is a group of senators (bipartisan) who are starting a "Dear Colleague" letter opposing the ban. I sincerely appreciate their concern in this matter and their effort to at least research kratom before banning it.

I'm sure you know that as soon as the media runs the story about the pending ban, EVERYONE will want to try it--it'll be that "wanting what they don't want you to have" category. 

Please consider the importance of keeping this mild herbal supplement legal for sale and use. I know you will do the best you can. 

Sincerely appreciated.

Kratom has helped me stop using drugs after a long battle with lower back pain, ADHD, GAD, and PSTD, and their is no reason it should be illegal. I hate the feeling I get off these medications.
