Its Natural, and its more like coffee that can either feel like a really clean coffee without jitters and anxiety and in higher doses its like an relaxing tea  it doesn't feel opiate like, but it does effect just enough areas in the brain to stop opiate withdrawal without being like these highly altered opiate chemicals like Methadone or Suboxone and I'm starting to wounder if coffee, cheese (cheese also effects opiate receptors) and alcohol (also effects an opiate receptor) are next. 

This is not a drug that you use to get high on... This is less then alcohol and the only reason I could think of this being made illegal is to keep people hooked on prescription opiates, Herion, Methadone or Suboxone. Three of these being legal and even if it is even a little bad for you there is no way its as bad for you as the four I've listed and honestly do you really think people on herio. really care about whay s good or bad for you? This is also why Thailand illegalized it in 1943(they have admited it, legalized it by prescription and are considering legalizing it because of they're growing opioid problem) Opium was legal and it helped people get off opium. This almost seems like the case now. The way the media is handling this, is like reefer madness part 2 its filled with lies and propaganda, and I wouldn't be suprised if people claiming its killing people are doing so because they need something to blame. 0 Deaths have been as a result of just Kratom use because its impossible to overdose on, the 14 of those have been debunked and shown to have had other drugs in they're system, and with the 1 death unaccounted for was probably done so with another some other drug that isn't being tested for like phenibut(you can find a lot of drugs online that can kill you and their being no way to test for them). It also has been proven to not cause respiratory depression (how opiates kill you) and you're body throws out what it doesn't want. 

Right now people are getting kicked off pain pills with addictions and horrifying at an alarming rate and without Kratom they're forced to buy pills on the street or Heroin(or they start with buying pain pills and end up on Heroin because its cheaper). This has helped friends of mine quit drugs like these, people in need of pain management, and also people in recovery that do not want to use opiates for pain or stay off opiates in general. Currently in the opiate world we have headlines like: "78 deaths in 2 days" because of a bad Heroin batch(my moms Ex was caught in that and died) "28 deaths in 4 hours" "Fentanyl Overdose Deaths In Ohio At An All-Time High As Midwest States On Alert Over Opioid ODs" and "Heroin Laced With Elephant Tranquilizer Linked to 8 Overdose". And this plant is really what we're worried about? Really? I think you guys really need to look at are drug laws, our prisoners, and the od count and really ask ourselves if this is working. The Drug war needs to end, and when you're banning plants keeping people of drugs, you really need to revaluate this epidemic. Enough is enough.

documents.commentText: First off I would like to say that I have never used Kratom but strongly oppose the schedule  classification of the drug. I don't see any positive benefits that could result from the ban. It may force people who are using it to take prescription opiates for their pain which have negative side effects for some people  There is also tons of anecdotal evidence that it is less addictive than prescription opiates. I did a quick search for scientific articles on kratom addiction potential compared to other opiates and couldn't find any (although I would hope the DEA looks at all the scientific articles with a non biased viewpoint before making any decision). A schedule 1 classification will basically prevent any further scientific research on the drug to see its effects. It's my opinion that no drug should be banned for scientific research as schedule 1 drugs are always going to be used whether they are banned or not and it's always better to have more information. The scheduling of kratom may also cause users to seek alternative illegal sources of the drug or other drugs which could be be more harmful to their health. Lastly I know a few people who use kratom for pain management as an alternative to prescription opiates who take it in a responsible manner. The 3 people I know who use it claim it improves the quality of their lives. Why take that away from them and the millions of other Americans who use it  for medicinal purposes?

documents.commentText: Under no circumstances should Kratom be placed into Schedule 1 or classified in any other way than it is now by the DEA. This is a substance that has been helpful to many people for homeopathic purposes as well as those attempting to curtail their use of more harmful substances. The fact that there was a ploy to place this substance into Schedule 1 classification under emergency provisions (thereby bypassing the public comment period) when there is clearly not adequate research and evidence for this kind of action is an absolute outrage and suggests that this action was the result of non-transparent motives at best. Additionally, the fact that there is heavy speculation from a number of public media sources that this could possibly be a move by the DEA to protect the investments and intellectual property of the pharmaceutical industry who is working on "medicines" that are based on compounds that are nearly identical to those in Kratom is absolutely unacceptable. Please immediately abandon any further moves to change the classification of Kratom anything different than it was prior to this effort.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
I am against placing these chemicals (from the plant Kratom) into schedule 1.

- Kratom is currently sold in a legal market and to place Kratom in Schedule 1 would create a black market, causing more harm than good. 

- Banning Kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

- Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports Kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

- Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to Kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on Kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

- Prohibiting Kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText: A schedule 1 drug is defined as not having any medicinal value and a high level of abuse. Kratom meets none of these criteria and as a partially selective mu opioid  agonist it has a profound medicinal value in treating the epidemic of opioid addiction in our country. There is strong anecdotal evidence that it is able to imitate the effects of opioids without the strong withdrawal symptoms of opioid misuse. This claim needs further investigation and dismissing this plant and its constituents as a schedule 1 drug would completely destroy any future investigations by qualified researchers or treatment overseen by medical professionals for opioid addiction. I ask that you not come to black and white conclusions to such complex issues especially if there's a chance of saving 100s of thousands of American lives through the outcome.

documents.commentText:
Kratom and the alkaloids it contains have been incredibly useful and healthful for me in many ways. Kratom enhanced my life in ways that only a healthy, harmless, valuable natural medicine could. I will explain the various reasons why I believe kratom should not be made a schedule 1 drug and why I believe it should be available to anyone who would benefit from its positive life changing effects.

     Prior to me discovering kratom i had many negative experiences with mental health issues, unhelpful medications, and addiction. SInce I was 7 years old I have struggled with OCD, ADD, depression, anxiety, and addiction. For 17 years I was prescribed medications that mostly  either didn't help at all or actually made my mental state worse than it already was. Some of these medications gave me a temporary feeling of euphoria that within 8 hours turned into very negative damaging thoughts and feelings. This lead to me becoming addicted to these medications. I eventually resorted to using destructive man-made drugs like methamphetamine and heroin in order to kill the pain that I felt within myself due to my mental dysfunctions. The result of this was me becoming heavily addicted to mainly methamphetamine. 

     In the depths of my methamphetamine addiction I came across a description of kratom and the benefits of using it as a tool to overcome various issues ranging from pain relief to the healing of mental issues. At first I was skeptical about it, but after using it for the first time I was sure that it had positive potential. I had become very impressed with it after a few uses. It was then that I decided to use it as a way to overcome my methamphetamine addiction and my mental health issues. I quit using methamphetamine altogether that very day. I used kratom to successfully subdue my unbearable cravings to use methamphetamine. Without kratom I would certainly still be using methamphetamine. After using kratom to overcome my meth addiction I began using kratom to deal with my excruciating anxiety and deep depression. Kratom relieves my anxiety and depression exceptionally, while exhibiting no negative side effects. By eliminating my anxiety kratom in turn subdues my OCD. Because of this I now have a safe healthy natural medicine that alleviates my mental pain. I now can work on changing my thought patterns in order to completely eliminate my mental disorders.

     Ontop of all this, kratom has helped me to quit smoking. Kratom gives me clean efficient energy and focus that is superior to most stimulants and certainly feels much safer and healthier. Even though kratom provides me with valuable energy it also helps me achieve deeper more significant sleep. Since I have began using kratom I have managed to avoid almost all of the viruses that my coworkers, friends, and family whom I was in close contact with were sick from, wich leads me to believe that kratom is a powerful immune system supporter. Kratom has completely helped me change my life for the better and should absolutely remain 100% legal.
Thank you for allowing the public to comment on this.

documents.commentText:
Please do not schedule kratom as a scheduled drug. I have been using kratom for over five years. During that time, I was able to break a cycle of addiction that I had to legally prescribed pain medication. Additionally, the depression I was suffering for many years has been lifted, and I know longer have to take antidepressant medicine that which often had terrible side effects. 

Throughout my time using kratom, I returned to college and received my Bachelor's of Science in Electrical Engineering. This is something that I never could have done before. The legal pain medicine and antidepressant medication kept me in a mental fog, and I often found it difficult to even get out of bed. 

I support a federal age limit placed on the purchase of kratom, as well as a restriction on the sale of "blended supplements" that contain ingredients other than kratom. My understanding is that many of the negative reactions a minority of the population has suffered were due to consuming products containing other substances. I also realize that there is concern for minors using any mind altering substance, and I fully support "regulation" in this regard. I believe that kratom should not be packaged in a way that appeals to minors, similar to how tobacco products are treated. However, I urge you not to "restrict" the sale of this natural botanical substance to responsible adults.

I am very thankful that the DEA has postponed any action, and I pray that the right decision regarding this wonderful plant will be reached. Many people I know would be devastated were kratom to be made a scheduled drug, and, unfortunately, I believe I would be one. 

Thank you for your time and service to the public.

documents.commentText:
My name is Michele Williams, age 34, Director of Quality Assurance for a mobile software development company.  I am opposed to the scheduling of kratom at the Schedule 1 level - where drugs with no medicinal value wind up.  I have been using kratom for over a decade.  I found kratom through research; looking for alternatives to prescription pain medication that caused noticeable personality changes, increased anxiety and a consistently growing tolerance.  

I feel kratom should remain available so that people can continue to utilize it as an alternative to prescription pain medications as well as other illegal substances.  I do feel more research should be done and that kratom, based on research papers such as pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/jacs.6b00360 show there could be medicinal value to this plant.  Scheduling it would cause a halt in many research projects, such as those being done at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and many others.  

With the opoid epidemic that has strangled our nation, one struggles to understand how the DEA could ban a substance that may have the ability to assist in reversing this epidemic.

documents.commentText:
Mr. Rosenberg and Fellow DEA Administration,

My name is Seth O'Shields; I am a 29 year old employee of the Department of the Interior, and I fully oppose the proposed DEA scheduling of Kratom (mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine). Scheduling this plant and its constituent alkaloids will only cause harm for those that rely on them to live normal, functioning lives. Many current users of this plant have been able to function while getting clean and detoxing from using harmful drugs such as heroin and pharmaceutical opioids. 

I personally did not start using Kratom for the above purpose, but rather for other reasons. In my personal experience, Kratom has helped me successfully interact with society when previously I would have had a difficult time functioning. In my job I interact with upwards of a thousand students and visitors during my work week. Debilitating anxiety has at times in the past prevented me from performing my job. I do not wish to take prescription benzodiazepines to treat this condition. I would rather seek out alternative, non-pharmaceutical options that, as an adult, I am fully within my rights to pursue. Kratom does not provide an opioid high like many news organizations and misinformed "experts" continue to claim. Unlike opioids that kill thousands every year, Kratom is not made in a laboratory (Some news outlets continue to falsely refer to it as a synthetic designer drug.), it does not cause respiratory distress at high doses, and will cause a unpleasant physical reaction if too large a dose is taken, discouraging abuse.

We all have a right to consume any number of nutritional supplements that we see fit to help improve our daily lives. Taking kratom is no different than taking Kava Kava, Chamomile or Blue Lotus tea. It has been used safely for thousands of years, and until recently it was unknown by the majority of the American public. Please defend all Americans' right to consume supplements of their choice as they see fit. Please do not pursue scheduling Kratom. The community of people benefiting from its use is too large, and too many lives will be harmed by its scheduling. The fear mongering by those who do not fully understand this plant has gone too far, and spread too many lies in its wake.  Please do the right thing and listen to those of us who's lives have been changed for the better by this plant.


Seth O'Shields

I began taking Kratom when tramadol was switched to a controlled substance. I work as a therapist  and can't be taking controlled substances, that's why I stopped taking tramadol, which was prescribed for my RLS . It was horrible getting off tramadol, but Kratom eased the transition. I have taken Kratom on and off for about two years now with no ill-effects. I took kratom for about 6 months straight. When I stopped, I had a mild headache, like what I experience when I don't drink coffee. The reason I continued taking kratom after stopping tramadol was because I have horrible restless leg syndrome, which only have been previously eased by tramadol. I have taken several drugs that are prescribed for RLS, nothing has worked. I have taken things ranging from gabapentin to pramipexole.  Not only do they not work, the side effects are horrendous. I am not productive without elimination of my symptoms and can not work in the field for which I have spent years preparing if my symptoms have to continue. 

I know the reason the DEA wants to ban this is due to mere pennies being lost by the drug companies and the fact that the pharmaceutical companies want to patent a version of this alkaloid, but there will be a greater monetary loss for the government if people cannot take this leaf that is helping so many. People will not go back to pharmaceuticals, like the drug companies so falsely think. Trust for the drug companies has been shattered. People take kratom because prescription medications don't work. If it is banned, people will either switch to illegal narcotics, like heroin, or they won't take anything and will be unproductive members of society, costing the government more money in disability payouts. Alternatively, methadone treatment will cost the government more. Similarly to what happened in Alabama when kratom was banned and people went back to heroin. This cost the government more money in disability and treatment.  This so-called war on drugs has been transparent from the beginning. It is not a war on drugs. It is a war on people wanting to get off prescription medication.

documents.commentText:
Im a 48-year-old woman. I have college degrees. I dont take recreational drugs. In fact, I rarely even drink alcohol. The first 32 years of my life were filled with abuse and trauma of various sorts from various sources. Ill spare the details, but Ive spent the last 16 years coping with the permanent PTSD all of that left me with. 
Seeking relief, Ive tried everything from therapy to meditation to prescribed drugs. The antidepressants from the doctor were the worst. Its great they help some peoplebut not me. I wanted so much to be healed. When one antidepressant left me an apathetic zombie, Id try another, and that left me irritable and mean. During the few years I tried antidepressants, I made decisions that I still dont understand. I got fired from two jobs. I reached my highest weight, more than what I weighed when I had entered the hospital to give birth. I told a family member you couldnt pay me a million dollars to take those again. I tried so hard, but they just didnt agree with me.
I discovered kratom while searching online for an alternative remedy. I found that a few grams, a few times a day substantially reduces my debilitating depression and anxiety, certainly more than anything else Ive tried. I still have good days and bad days, but the overall severity is greatly reduced. 
It doesnt make me high. Interestingly, Ive found no need to increase the amount in the three or so years Ive been using it. It seems to have a topping off point that doesnt change due to tolerance. It just balances. A few people may have used it to get high and ingested excessive amounts and got themselves sick just like they could by abusing caffeine or over the counter medications. 
Is it addicting? Well, Im also addicted to my steroidal asthma inhaler because it helps me breathe. As for kratom, when I run out, the same allergy and mental health symptoms that it relieves returns, but that is all. 
Veterans with PTSD and chronic pain sufferers deserve relief, so do former opioid addicts.  I wont break the law, so please dont take away this healing plant.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
 kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v


There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
I want to share my story of my son's addiction to Kratom in hopes that you do the responsible thing and uphold the ban and schedule 1 classification.  I also want to preface my comments by telling you I work for a non-profit that runs an early intervention substance abuse program for teens 12-17 in Colorado.  I'm in the trenches, I see what poorly regulated policies such as Amendment 64 and the failure of the federal government to protect citizens from harmful drugs has done to the youth in Colorado and to their families.

My son has ADHD as well as an addictive nature. I'll make his decent into drug abuse brief by stating only that as it so often is for teens dealing with ADHD this combination led to his drug use in high school that started with MJ.  When he no longer got the high from MJ he eventually became addicted to Oxy when he found an unscrupulous doctor willing to prescribe him very high doses of Oxy without so much as an MRI or Xray for back issues.  We later found out through genetic testing that my son has a certain gene mutation that blocked the full absorption of the Oxy.  Had he not have this particular marker, he would have died from the Oxy.  

Enter the next hell, Kratom.  A friend suggested Kratom as a way to detox from the Oxy, it still gives you the high like Oxy and it's legal and safe.  Nothing could be further from the truth.  My son was taking the Kratom by the spoonfuls and washing it down with a glass of water numerous times throughout the day using an entire bag a day.  He became just as lethargic, just as dangerously thin, just as unmotivated, just as depressed and anxious, just as explosive as when he was taking Oxy.  He lost several jobs, a relationship, teeth and I'm convinced if it went on much longer he would have lost his life.  Instead of enjoying the most wonderful time of a twenty something's life, he was very much dependent on us because he had no money to move out spending $30 a day on Kratom and could not keep a job.

Detoxing from the Kratom took several long and agonizing weeks.  Any drug or "safe" herb that does this kind of damage to anyone should never be legal.  Although he is completely drug and Kratom free, I can still see the physical effects the Kratom had on him and I'm afraid to even think about the health issues he might experience when he is older from the lethal doses he was consuming.

His "crutch" excuse was always that he needed it for back pain, however, now that he is off the Kratom he rarely complains about his back.

The DEA has ignored what's going on in Colorado with MJ legalization.  It has had a devastating effect on our teens as I see it everyday working with them.  This failed experiment has proven that regulation does not work and has given our youth up as collateral damage.  I implore you to do the right thing and uphold the ban on Kratom.  We were lucky to be able to intervene and help our son but many families are still struggling with heart wrenching situations as their love one self destructs before them.  The biggest problem we see in our youth is the removal of the perception of the harm of MJ and other drugs.  We do pre and post tests with our teens and over the last few years their perception of the harm of all drugs has gone down considerably.  Don't do the same thing with Kratom.

Lifting the ban has been very unfortunate as so many addicted people had probably gone through the detox phase already.  Kratom is NOT a safe alternative to Oxy or Heroine, it's just one more in the mix.

It's time the voice of reason starts being heard over those who want to continue to support their habits despite what it does to families and our society.

Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Dear Sir or Madam,
First, thank you for the temporary retraction of the DEA ban on Kratom and permitting the public comment period. My and is Shannon Riley and I am a 36 year old woman with an extensive education and aspirations. I am in the process of starting my own business and have otherwise spent the past 6 years as a professional in the media. I would like to share my experience with Kratom.

When I was 14 or 15 years old I had gone to the hospital with rapid heartbeat, chest pains and dizziness. I literally thought I was dying. The diagnosis was a panic attack and anxiety. I had this occur a couple more times throughout high school and college. While I had received professional help from psychologist during my high school years I chose not to take any medications. I had learned to have this as a part of my life. After my undergraduate years, I started to not only deal with anxiety, but also depression (my family has a significant history of depression and anxiety). Finally, I had to again seek help for these symptoms as they were interfering with my day to day functioning, at which time I was prescribed anti-anxiety (Xanax) medication and a multitude of attempts for different antidepressants. I did feel like things were better than they had been, however I was starting to have other symptoms, which were mostly a feeling of not feeling at all. I was told these were side effects of the medication and tried yet another attempt at different depression medication. This lasted for the better part (or more) of a decade. I graduated with my Masters degree in 2010, at which time my brother came to celebrate. I had not seen him in about 2 years and he pulled me aside to ask what was going on with me. I did not understand what he was asking until he told me that I seemed vacant and not the same person that he had known for 30 years. That is when I realized what detrimental effects these antidepressant and anti-anxiety drugs were having on me. While dealing with the anxiety and depression was horrible, I wanted to be able to be the person I once was and feel again. 

This is when I had started talking to good friends and going online to seek alternative options for my depression/anxiety. I went through a period where I tried some herbal options on the mainstream health supplement market and unfortunately, they did not seem to have an impact. I was talking to a good friend who also suffered somewhat from anxiety, but had chronic pain from a knee injury. He had been prescribed pain medication, but instead found Kratom and found it to have helped him enough where he did not use the prescription, as he had described the similar side effects that I had experienced with anti-anxiety/depression medication. In this conversation, he mentioned seeing that Kratom was also used for anxiety and depression. I looked online into Kratom and its uses and the research that I could find regarding side effects and potential issues with Kratom use and decided to see if it would help me. I made a tea with it 6 years ago, and have not looked back to the alternatives. I use it daily and situationally if I feel anxiety coming on. I have not experienced a panic attack the way I used to, my depression has lessened extensively, but what has helped me more than anything is that I can feel this way without compromising happiness for indifference. While, I know there are contentions about the effectiveness and usage of Kratom, I can only speak for myself in that it has helped me to regain enjoyment in my life. I truly hope the restriction on Kratom by the DEA is whole heartedly reconsidered, as I could not imagine the alternatives for myself. 

Thank you for the consideration,
Shannon Riley

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA,

I urge you not to place kratom (mitragynine) on Schedule I of the CSA.

Kratom does not meet the criteria of Schedule I. There is virtually no evidence as to this drug's potential for abuse, though it appears to be much less addictive than opioids or alcohol. There have been no documented deaths attributable to kratom alone, and autopsies finding
mitragynine have no scientific basis to conclude that it contributed to or caused the death. Anecdotal evidence seems to indicate that it is a safer alternative to opioids: it has fewer side effects, doesn't repress breathing, and can help a user overcome opioid addiction. Where is the public risk from this drug? Opioid addiction has become an epidemic in this country. Stifling research into mitragynine's potential medical uses benefits only sellers of opioids.

There is now a small but dedicated community of kratom users. Their recountings of its use as a pain reliever, sleep aid, and effective substitute for opioids are strikingly similar to the personal histories of medical marijuana users. 

At 66 I am now one of those medical marijuana users. With access to marijuana I have avoided using large amounts of NSAIDs, but may in the future need a much stronger pain medication to treat the symptoms of degenerative spinal disc disease. A drug derived from kratom may, if research is allowed, provide an alternative to opioids for me.

Please, show that you can consider all aspects, good and bad, of this traditional herbal medicine. On balance it appears that it may REDUCE risk to the public by offering a safer alternative to opioids. 

Thank you,

Catherine Ries

documents.commentText:
I am a student at Ferris State University working towards a degree in engineering. Over the last few years, I have personally began experimenting with legal drugs including kratom. In the near future kratom will be reviewed with the potential of being placed on the DEA's list of schedule 1 drugs.

The reason I am writing this letter is to share my experiences with the drug and my concerns with it being placed on this list. Firstly, the drug is often used for the purpose of pain relief. Thought the drug can give the user sedative-like side effects, this can be avoided by consuming the drug at low dosages. If kratom were to be placed on this list not only would the product be unavailable for public use, but also potential research purposes in the future.

Secondly, kratom is not a synthetic drug, created specifically for recreational purposes. Kratom is a crop that can be grown in any individuals backyard, given the right care and environment.

Finally, because of the nature of the drug, kratom isn't a plant that would cause problems for non-users. While particular drugs such as PCP are known to create erratic behavior in the consumer, potentially creating danger for a third party, the consequences of improper kratom use are directed towards the consumer. My question to you is: do you believe that an individual should be punished for the products they personally consume in their own private residence? This is the likely scenario for the majority of kratom users.

Any person able to access the internet today has the ability to find for themselves the proper way to handle products like kratom, and how to use them responsibly. When I first began consuming kratom I used the internet to discover the correct dosage for me to receive the plants anti-anxiety properties. The plant has helped me to combat my struggles with social anxiety disorder and is used rarely and in small amounts. If the DEA decided to classify kratom as a schedule 1 drug, the have essentially decided that people like me cannot be trusted with their individual autonomy and are not generally able to decide for themselves whether or not kratom can be used to benefit their lives. I hope that in the coming months kratom will not be classified as a drug and that the potential for research into the plants pain relief properties will remain open.

First, my personal history with Kratom. I am a 33 year old software architect/engineer with a BA in psychology and strong interests in biology, chemistry, and neuroscience.

One of the side effects of working on the computer all day is that -- regardless of how much care one puts in to ergonomics, stretching, proper exercise, and good working habits -- it eventually takes a toll on the body. I have been to a few physiotherapists, orthopedists, and related specialists, but have not come away with anything that alleviates the issues I've had with my neck. 

Aside from the neck issues, I am in good physical and mental condition; this makes things all the more frustrating. My experience with standard medical care was less than satisfactory. Exercises and stretching help, but cant be used as spot fixes on days when things get really bad. Pharmaceuticals can work as spot fixes, but leave me feeling worse in the long run; they reduce my motivation, make me tired, and have unacceptably negative influences on my ability to think and remember things. That leaves me with a choice between being in pain but functional, or achieving temporary relief at the cost of job performance. This is not an acceptable trade-off. 

Enter Kratom. After doing a lot of reading, looking for some natural supplement that might help, I came across Kratom. The research on it is limited, but its been around long enough to guess at safety for personal use, and didnt appear to have any major negative effects. In short, it sounded like a lot of herbal or alternative medicine. Not a lot of evidence for effectiveness, but nothing too adverse, and plenty of positive  reports. 

That was about 2 years ago. I've been taking Kratom for about 2 years now; about 8 months continuously the first time, followed by a break for about a year, and approaching 10 months this time.

I find that Kratom has a positive effect on my well being. Kratom allows me to function better. Kratom results in less pain and more energy, without forcing me to sacrifice mental clarity or physical ability. While I hesitate to say that its exactly like coffee, I would suggest that its effectiveness, tolerance, usage, and experience quitting is pretty similar. Its kind of a calmer version of the first cup of coffee for the day. I just feel better generally; the pain in my neck fades out of the picture and I can proceed through my day normally. 

If I forget to take it, or skip it that day, I feel about the same as if I skipped my coffee. If I stop taking it, it feels exactly the opposite of quitting coffee; instead of being groggy for a few days, I have trouble sleeping for a few days. 

While I do believe that regulating Kratom in a very general way -- namely with an age limit -- would be wise, any measures beyond that are liable to have a significant negative impact on the well-being of millions of people who use it as an alternative to heavy-duty pharmaceuticals in dealing with mild-to-moderate pain and general malaise.


To state things clearly, though less personally:

I believe that Kratom should be regulated as a supplement, available to those 21 and up, and with no additional restrictions. 


Kratom has been around for quite some time with limited negative consequences. Millions of Kratom users represent only a small fraction of emergency room visits or poison control calls, and there is an  apparent lack of mortality in sum total when considering incidents involving Kratom alone (non poly-drug). A large body of anecdotal data suggesting that Kratom can, and has, been used to successfully transition off of opiates (harm reduction). There are many current Kratom users, some like myself, who take it in place of pharmaceuticals with severe adverse effect profiles, to generally improve their quality of life. And, there is significant research interest in Kratom (two papers published in the last 6-8 months, along with a patent) that would likely suffer a chilling effect as a result of more stringent regulation.

While Kratom may not be entirely without downsides, it appears it has much more in common with herbal supplements than with pharmaceutical drugs. Things like Coffee, Cats Claw, Ashwaghanda, Bacopa, St. Johns Wort, Kava, various forms of Tea& all have both positive effects, and potential negative effects on the same order of those exhibited by Kratom, and all are expected to be remain legal for the foreseeable future. Please make the correct decision, and group Kratom in with its herbal supplement kin.

Please consider my comments, and the thousands of others made on the topic of Kratom during the review period in making your decisions about the fate of this plant, and, more importantly, about the potential fates of the millions of people who use it in pursuit of improved well-being.

documents.commentText:
Hello,
I am a 30-year-old stay-at-home parent. I have suffered from mild to moderate depression and OCD for 10 years. I tried multiple prescription antidepressants and anti-anxiety medications over the years, and I stopped each time due to lack of efficacy and unacceptable side effects. Those medications made me feel apathetic, and my quality of life was no better while taking them. When stopping SSRI drugs, I had a very strong reaction in several cases; I ended up in he hospital due to suicidal idealations that I had never experienced prior to starting the medication. I decided that living with mild to moderate depression and OCD was preferable to what I experienced on those medications.

I started taking Kratom two years ago in a last-ditch effort to alleviate some of my symptoms and have some semblance of happiness. Not only did it help with my depression, it also didn't cause the same apathy and other negative side effects commonly associated with SSRIs. I finally felt normal for the first time in 10 years. Moreover, when I have taken periodic breaks, I did not experience the same severe discontinuation syndrome that I did with the prescription medications. 

I take two grams twice a day. I have been doing so for two years and have never felt compelled to increase the dose.  Kratom has increased my quality of life tenfold. Please don't take it away.

documents.commentText:
Dear Sir or Madam:

I am writing you regarding an issue very close to my heart.  This is in regards to the DEAs Notice of Intent to Schedules of Controlled Substances: Temporary Placement of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine Into Schedule I, essentially banning a harmless herb, which has helped many individuals to alleviate their own personal physical pain, including our men and women in service and that have served who cannot find relief for their daily physical pain (or choose not to) through conventional narcotic pain medication, would only increase the prison population greater or lead to these people to choose a path they dont want: that of using prescription painkillers. 

It can also help with withdrawal symptoms from prescription opioid drugs and street narcotics, which we are seeing an epidemic of in our country. It is my opinion that the DEA is exceeding its authority to place a plant used by hundreds of thousands of law abiding citizens on the list of Schedule I drugs, which would turn them into immediate criminals - risking extensive jail time due to mandatory minimums, removing their right to vote, and severely impairing the ability to get a job once they are freed, amongst all the other negative consequences.  As Im sure you are well aware, the US has the highest prison population in the world, with over 50% of the inmates in federal prison being non-violent drug offenders.  It is absolutely absurd for the DEA to add a plant, which has been used as a tea for thousands of years by East Asia to their scheduling list.  According to medical literature, not a single death has been caused by kratom (without the individual being a polydrug cocktail that included kratom). [1]  

The DEA says that kratom has resulted in a total of 30 deaths in the US, and although that is a tragedy, prescription opioid medications alone have resulted in a whopping 28,000 deaths from heroin and prescription painkillers in 2014.  Right now, there is a huge crisis of deaths from opioid abuse in this country that could be helped greatly by leaving kratom available and in the hands of consumers.  Kratom, being a natural plant, should be regulated by the FDA under the DSHEA as a dietary supplement, as it meets that exact criteria.  If there is concern about its misuse, it should be restricted to adults age 18 or 21 to purchase.  Unfortunately, because of all the yellow journalism and smears in the mainstream media, kratom has been lumped together with drugs that should have and have been properly banned.

Recently, the state of Florida had proposed to ban kratom earlier this year, but after testimony and an examination of common sense medical information, Florida came to the conclusion:

a review of information currently available through identified law enforcement and laboratory sources in Florida indicates that Kratom does not constitute a significant risk to the safety or welfare of Florida residents. The Florida Department of Health (DOH) reports no pervasive health issues attributed to the ingestion of Kratom products in Florida. [2]

I myself am a daily kratom user, drinking it in the form of a tea to help alleviate the excruciating pain brought upon by my irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD).  Banning this substance would negatively affect my quality of life to intolerable degree, of which I have found no prescription medication or treatment to be as effective as kratom.

I believe God gave us this miracle pain relieving plant, to use for the benefit of all mankind, as he said in Genesis 1:29-30

Then God said, "Behold, I have given you every plant yielding seed that is on the surface of all the earth, and every tree which has fruit yielding seed; it shall be food for you; and to every beast of the earth and to every bird of the sky and to everything that moves on the earth which has life, I have given every green plant for food"; and it was so.

I view the fact that this plant was just recently brought to the west from across the great oceans as a sign from God that it is intended to help the people of this nation, to help our opioid epidemic, which is taking the lives of so many of our young people today.

I am not the only one who will be impacted by this insane ban.  Just search the hashtag #IamKratom on Youtube, Twitter or Facebook and listen to the stories of people who have been helped tremendously -- many have had their lives saved -- by this simple plant, a tea, that the DEA wants to take away from us for no just cause.

I appreciate the DEA listening to us, the kratom users, and giving us the opportunity to have a public comment period for kratom. These are my thoughts, facts and opinion on the matter.  I hope you will make the right decision and leave kratom as a dietary supplement.

Sincerely,
Jonathan Grose

Foodnote source [1]: bit.ly/2gzGuYE
Footnote source [2]: bit.ly/2gmzPTQ

He was told that the cure was neck and back surgery, told he had arthritis.  He thought those types of surgeries didn't work and that it would exacerbate the pain. So he took his prescription of 120 Norco's every month and of course had to buy more off the streets to keep his pain levels manageable. It was to say the least the lowest 5 years he'd ever experienced. Then four years ago we heard about Kratom. He did some research and decided to give it a try.  Three years of using a regime of Green Vein Malaysian and he has NOT taken a pain pill since.  No side effects, no mind alterations, no mood swings, no withdrawals like when he was on pain meds.  A complete change in his motivation for the positive. I've always believed in God and the power of prayer, but I would never have guessed that Kratom would be so unbelievably effective in managing his pain without the side effects.  I am asking so hopefully that you will consider doing research on Kratoms properties, instead of banning it all together. Please do not put this as a Schedule 1 drug, it's helping so many more people than it could ever hurt.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern,

I am a 49 year old full time reading specialist in a Title I school and an actively involved mom, two roles that I cherish. I mention this up front to assure you that I am productive contributor in society and share many of your goals. 

I have an incurable medical condition called Chiari Malformation, a condition in which the cerebellum crowds into the cervical spine. I have spent years homebound and in severe pain, unable to work and be an active mom. I sought to free myself from addictive pain killers and the stupor they cause, and instead I decided to take a natural approach to management of my condition. 

Kratom allows me to feel comfortable, yet mentally sharp. I am able to commit to my demanding work with the confidence that I can handle flare ups of pain and symptoms and show up and do my job daily. It has been the biggest blessing on my healing journey. 

Please imagine if you or your loved one was in chronic pain, untreatable by current medicine, yet made manageable by a natural herbal supplement. A supplement that has contributed to my ability to lead a full life and work for eight years now, as well as be there for my son.  I choose a natural approach to health and appreciate kratom which has a gentle effect of easing symptoms without a high or stupor that medications can cause.  I love my job teaching children to read which requires me to be alert and physically active. I want to continue consuming kratom as I have done effectively for years without any harmful side effects.  

I am in support of research and study, and understand that regulations such as proper labeling and age restrictions could be explored if the science suggests that it is advisable. However, I am opposed to criminalizing thousands of responsible citizens like myself who consume kratom tea to aid quality of life.

I hope that you will listen to the veterans, teachers, lawyers, police officers, corporate CEOs, professors, scientists who have spoken on behalf of kratom. They are chronic pain patients, elderly, single moms, and accident victims. They are people who are finding relief and renewed life with a simple plant. Please hear us.

The evidence clearly shows that there is no cause for a ban, and the effects of such a ban would be unfortunate and potentially tragic.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,

Kathryn Quintana

documents.commentText:
My concerns over kratom remaining legal (which i desire it to remain) boil down to a few simple concerns that i feel should be addressed.

1) It should be noted that the plant, which is a cousin of the coffee plant has action on several receptors (adenosine/adrenaline in addition to subtypes of opiate receptors)  and it is the net effect which yields any perceived effect. adenosine receptors are effected by coffee; adrenaline by yohimbine, and the opiate stimulation is only a small part of the perceived effect. 

2) The legality of kratom stops a lot of people from using heroin. kratoms binding to the opiate receptor does not recruit a protein known as beta arrestin this protein is what makes normal opiates deadly through stopping of breathing/heart. kratom  NOT doing this means it does not present an immediate health risk or burden on medical services as heroin does. I live in Tampa; heroin is prevalent here, i hear ambulances on a daily basis due to overdoses. I have personally witnessed people shoot up and overdose while on my way to the store for christ sake. kratoms specific aspect of being not deadly is very important and should be asknocledged.

3) I personally struggled with drug addiction after an injury and prescription drugs/heroin. Kratom allowed me to quit prescription drugs (with only slight withdraw) and my sobriety from those drugs have allowed me to not only not experience cravings; but has allowed me to stop taking my depression meds (due to mitragynines effect on serotonin) and has helped me go from failing college to being a A student.

It is my personal opinion that if there is a creator (god;ywh;allah) kratom was put here by that god to help people.  Kratom alone has never killed anyone as the american kratom associations review of the deaths that have been supposedly blamed on kratom.

To Whom it May Concern,  

I would like to briefly share my story about Kratom and how it has changed my life.   When I was 21 years old, I had my wisdom teeth removed.  Upon completion of the procedure, the doctor prescribed me oxycodone.  Before long I found myself addicted.   It wasn't long before I was seeking narcotic medication on the streets.  Shortly after, my life started to deteriorate.  I ended up getting a DUI and a criminal record.  Years went by and my life worsened in many ways.  Narcotic medication was the first thing I thought about in the morning and last thing I thought about at night.  I would go to doctors and try to convince them to give me more meds whether I had insurance are not.  Several times I attempted to quit taking narcotic meds but found myself craving whenever I passed the pharmacy on the street or was in situations that reminded me of the euphoria I felt when I was high.  I went to a methadone clinic and after several months I started weaning myself off.  During this time, I was experiencing horribly uncomfortable days and almost no sleep at night.  It was on one of the sleepless nights that I read about Kratom online.  I decided to try it and almost immediately the withdrawal symptoms subsided.  Since I've found kratom my life has drastically improved.  I sleep at night better than I have in years.  My wife and I started and maintain a successful business.  I'm a contributing member to society and a faithful Christian.   With my addictive personality I can't imagine what life will be like without kratom.  I know several other people personally that have similar stories.  My personality does not enable me to have the self-control to manage pharmaceutical medication.  I recently underwent a dental procedure and at which point the dentist prescribed me Vicodin.  I can gladly say for the first time that I did not feel the need to fill the prescription.  I pray that you will take this story into consideration before making your ruling on kratom.

documents.commentText: PLEASE-PLEASE-PLEASE!!!! Do not place kratom on a schedule 1 drug list. I am a 61 year old female. I have suffered with chronic lower back pain most of my adult life, and for the last 10 years developed what at times can be excruciating pain in one hip.  I haven't had health insurance for years since I was laid off of the last decent paying job I've had in about 10 years.  Bad economy and lack of jobs forced me into working in retail which doesn't pay enough to meet the high payments of even Obama care.  Unfortunately, I only discovered kratom about 8 months ago, but it was a life saver and a game changer.  I currently work at a gas station/convenience store where I stand for 6 to 8 hours a day, without a break or lunch.  I have to empty what can sometimes be quite heavy bags of trash, plus lift and stack heavy flats of beverages in order to keep coolers stocked. Prior to kratom, there were days where I just wanted to sit down and cry due to being in so much pain.  After working my 4 day week, my first day off was almost always wasted because I could barely move while my body tried to recover from the stress of the week. I have never been one to take pain pills.  I don't like the way they make me feel and some of them make me so sick that I'm useless anyway.  Even when I've had surgeries, I would only take the pain pills for the first 1-2 days and then maybe take ibuprofen or nothing at all. Kratom has helped me immensely. No it does not always take away ALL the pain, but it can take the pain from a 9 or 10 down to a 1 or 2 and that is an enormous rescue considering it does not make me sick, it does not cause me to feel like I'm drugged out, I'm still able to function, and I only need a small amount. I actually have a slight increase in energy due to the lack of pain. I could never figure out why I was always so tired, then I realized, I was always exhausted because I was always in pain!  Without the pain, I felt almost normal again.  It was as if I had new life!.  If I have to go back to not having kratom avail again, it will be a dissension into an abyss of chronic pain again with no relief.  I will not be able to continue working as I am at this time with the help of kratom.  I will probably end up on disability and another burden for the government to bear.  This is not what I desire.  I hope to be able to continue to be mobile and look forward to continuing to work (though not at my current job) for another 5 years minimum, until I'm 70 at best.  Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
I am strongly opposed to scheduling or banning kratom (mitragyna speciosa) and its active alkaloids namely, mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine. Kratom is a very safe herbal supplement that millions of Americans use for a variety of reasons to enrich and better their lives. From personal experience and from reading and hearing hundreds of anecdotes from users, it is no more habit forming than coffee and it is much less dangerous than traditional opiates due to the fact that it does not cause respiratory depression. The science thus far shows that the compounds in kratom appear to be biased agonists that only trigger one opioid pathway, called the G protein pathway, and not another pathway associated with respiratory depression. Though it does have the potential to become habitual, much like caffeine, it is self-limiting in that consuming progressively higher amounts does not produce euphoric or narcotic effects.

     I am 30 years old and have been taking kratom regularly as an herbal supplement for over 3 years and have only experienced positive benefits. I drink low doses of kratom tea because I have found it to help relieve my chronic back pain and pain from carpal tunnel syndrome after a long days work as an IT contractor for the federal government. I have noticed too, that kratoms mood boosting effects have reduced my anxiety and helped alleviate depression. Its beautiful to have found a natural herb that can both reduce the pain caused by software programming and aid me in my social interactions and mental well-being. Much in the way coffee helps me to work hard, stay focused, and feel energized, kratom has a similar positive role in my life. By banning this substance, the government would be making me a criminal for responsibly utilizing an herbal supplement that helps me work and function better. I fear banning kratom will rob folks who suffer from debilitating and chronic illnesses of an alternative way to reduce their symptoms and make their lives better. 

     We must allow American adults the liberty to make their own decisions about what they put in their body. Frankly, prohibition of a reasonably safe substance goes against the very foundations of this great nation. The DEA and FDA would really need to prove that kratom is responsible for widespread negative effects on health and well-being and we simply dont have any evidence of this. Furthermore, these laws that allow emergency scheduling of substances were put in place in order to stop dangerous and novel synthetic substances from causing harm to society. Kratom is a plant that has been safely used for thousands of years and we certainly arent seeing an epidemic of abuse or widespread deleterious health effects like we have with new synthetic designer drugs. In fact, we are now seeing many reports that kratom is helping people to quit toxic substances like heroine, oxycodone and other synthetic opiates, and even alcohol. 

     The CDC estimates that over 14,000 people per year die from opiate painkillers while several hundred die from NSAIDs like acetaminophen. According to the DEA, kratom has been implicated in 15 deaths between 2014 and 2016, though experts familiar with the cases are arguing that nearly all of them involved other substances. Even if we were to overlook the probable polypharmacy cause of death in most of these cases, 8 deaths per year is far safer than what we are experiencing with NSAIDs and prescription painkillers. Unfortunately, we dont have enough data to directly compare the mortality rate, but we can accurately say that kratom is not causing an epidemic of overdoses, acute health problems or substance abuse. Opiate pills and heroine on the other hand have become increasingly damaging to individuals and society. If there is a chance that kratom could be part of the solution to the opiate epidemic in this country, we should certainly put the time and effort into conducting scientific studies before hastily illegalizing it.

     In conclusion, the unprecedented and reckless move to emergency schedule the kratom plant before properly considering it scientifically, while also ignoring the millions of responsible Americans users that find benefits in supplementing the plant, would be wrong both logically and morally. We know for a fact that kratom is providing a large number of people with a variety of benefits with negligible reports of negative effects on health. The plant and its alkaloids should be studied extensively before we make any rash decisions that would prevent regular Americans citizens, veterans, folks that suffer from chronic medical ailments, and heroine/opiate addicts from accessing an herbal remedy that can and does greatly improve their lives. I think it is clear that the benefits of kratom as a supplement vastly outweigh any argument against scheduling it at this point in time. I strongly support keeping kratom legal, unscheduled, and available as a supplement for American adults.

documents.commentText:
I am a 60-year old professional whose life was catapulted into the throes of illnesses in 2001. After a severe toxic exposure, I developed interstitial cystitis, colitis, fibromyalgia and CFIDS within several years. In fewer than five years, I'd also developed two stage III cancers: bladder and colon. As one might imagine, I was left disabled and in considerable, worsening pain due to pelvic radiation disease, and the pain brought about by the other illnesses.

The only thing that addressed the level of pain that I experienced was a battery of pharmaceuticals: Morphine, Gabapentin, Hydrocodone (Vicodin), and then the attending medicines so typically prescribed for the various side effects of these drugs -- sleep medications and anti-depressants. Although I always took only what prescribed and often under-medicated, after years of taking these drugs, I had become inefficient, distracted, and unable to successfully carry out my active everyday routine. On three occasions, I was unconscious and vomiting -- had I been alone, I would be yet another of the millions of people dead from accidental Rx overdose. Never having taken more than prescribed, I learned that it only takes one pill atop a weary body to KILL, and that death from narcotics and other pharmaceuticals is shockingly so very simple to achieve.

Wanting to free myself from the life-choking clutches of pharmaceuticals, I had extensively looked into and tried natural remedies, none of which worked for me. I felt dejected that I was stuck, stuck being dull, spacey, and in general, a shell of what I normally am, as a result of narcotics and the other medications typically associated with them.

Two years ago, I discovered Kratom. Thinking it a last effort and not expecting anything positive, I was shocked and delighted to find that KRATOM WORKED! I began to substitute it for my narcotics and other medicines and within two months, I was ecstatic to have achieved getting off ALL prescription pain, sleep, and anti-depressant medicines. I have not had to take them since 12.31.14, and my life has once again been returned to me. This IS life. This IS normal, daily existence. I can speak without losing my train of thought, I can write again, I can think sharply again, I can carry out my work again, and I am once again "myself," thanks solely to Kratom. 

This is not a "high-making" substance. It is simply a leaf from a tree related to the coffee plant. In two years that I have been taking it, I have never had to increase my dosage, and at times, my pain is so well controlled that I take less than my average dose. It is an amazing gift to be able to return to LIFE, which had been suffocated beneath the necessary pharmaceuticals I took for so many years. The sheer joy of not having to be rendered a dulled, distracted, unengaged shell of the person I am is indescribable, and I have said so much, ad nauseam, as I have emerged from the cloud of prescription drugs, which, stop their life-sucking horror, also cost me a great deal of money. 

In having become familiar with many groups addressing the use of Kratom, it also became clear to me that *many* people who found themselves in the throes of addiction to street drugs were able to get off them by using Kratom. This is a huge boon to society! 

The thought that this magnificent, life-saving plant might be taken from me is quite literally terrifying. I compare it to a death sentence. Indeed, while on the drugs necessary to quell my pain, I do not have much of a life, and if I have another episode of passing out and vomiting without being accompanied, I stand to *lose* my life. Certainly, many people who have found Kratom help in dealing with chronic pain will suffer and some will die when forced to go back to the dangerous combinations of prescription drugs required for relief. Please, please do not take this amazing, life-saving plant from us  it  unlike anything else out there   has given us our lives.

Joana Dougherty deBelkadi

documents.commentText:
As a psychiatric nurse practitioner involved in treating patients with substance abuse problems, I am always looking for ways to help patient reduce the harm caused by substance use. One way of reducing harm is to substitute a harmful drug (such as opiates) with a less harmful drug (such as mitragynine or 7-hydroxymitragynine). The logic to this is axiomatic - a drug that can clearly cause great harm, including death, such as opiates, is more harmful than a less-dangerous drug such as kratom. While abstinence may be ideal, it is not possible, nor desirable to many substance users. That is why we need more, not fewer options for helping substance users reduce their substance use (and it's attendant harm) while en route to abstinence, whenever possible.  This is why I strongly urge you NOT to place mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine on schedule I of the CSA.

Respectfully,

Andrew Penn, RN, MS, NP, APRN-BC
Psychiatric Nurse Practitioner, Lisc CA 15914

documents.commentText:
To whom it concerns:

I suffer from chronic anxiety and frequent bouts of depression and anhedonia.  I'd like to state why I use kratom instead of prescription drugs to manage these issues.

  I have found prescription medication to be problematic to such an extent that they cannot work as a treatment solution for me.  SSRIs blunt all emotions leaving one neither high nor low, and they are severely disruptive to one's sex life.  This is not a desirable state for me and many other people.  In my estimation SSRIs are only useful if the patient poses dangerous harm to himself or is otherwise on a destructive path. In this case SSRIs can keep the problem at bay until therapy or other drug treatments are found.  

The other popular option is benzodiazepine medications.  While these work acutely, and produce feelings of peace and pleasure, they are very often abused and over-prescribed.  Most importantly, the withdrawal danger is severe with this class of drugs and can cause death.  The same simply cannot be said for kratom, yet only one has been considered for scheduling.  The faulty logic of this situation is self-evident.  Given the choice between (a) synthetic drug whose withdrawals may kill you, or (b) a plant whose withdrawals involve restless leg and diarrhea, the sensible choice is obvious. Kratom is the more useful treatment.  

A side benefit of opioid usage is it completely removes the urge to consume alcohol, which, again, is another far more lethal substance that destroys lives of its users and non-users every day, which is not being considered for scheduling.  We cannot continue this topsy-turvy outlook on drug usage in the United States.  I find kratom to dramatically improve my quality of life, with the only downside being cost.  Kratom allows me to function at a higher level, put in more hours at work, drink less, work out more, and face situations with a sense of calm instead of anxiety and dread.

documents.commentText:
To whoever this concerns, 

As we all know the fine upstanding folks at the dea have located the next public health crisis. Has it killed anyone by itself? We can't say since the handful of deaths haven't had autopsies made public to my knowledge. Do people become addicted to it? I don't see how we can say that if we don't let the proper associations do reasearch on it (I won't rule out that possibility, but we cannot state "yes or no" until research has been conducted). Is it poisoning the youth? I have never met a youth who even knows of this plant, I also have never seen it sold to a minor in the gas stations which do provide it. It could happen in the current model, but if our government took proper action and regulated it, requiring state ID and licenses for purchase(like they should be doing) then it would be no more of a problem then alcohol and tobacco. Is it as bad as those comparisons? Until there is some unbiased research I don't see how we can say otherwise.

I'm not saying what we have now is perfect but i will say it's better then your proposal. If we moved it from storefronts to online websites only, it would be a whole lot harder for a minor to get their hands on, and a fraction of people would use it. 

Schedule one is not an option as i see it. It is an embarrassment and no different then sweeping things under the rug. It is saying "NO" to science, the medical community and making people's mind up for them, without their say in thw matter. How that is allowed in the land of the free I've been asking ever since I realized how absurd a war on drugs really is.

Please don't tarnish the phrase "land of the free". Please go pick up a dictionary and learn the definition of the phrase " Protect and serve". If you expect your agency to be taken seriously in this nation, then learn what we mean when we say " Don't tread on me".

Man up, do the right thing and quit screwing the citizens of my nation over.

documents.commentText:
My name is Beth. I'm a 41-year-old woman from Texas. I have a genetic bone disease called osteogenesis imperfecta which led to multiple broken bones over the course of my life, as well as scoliosis that required 2 surgeries with spinal fusions and metal rods, first in my thoracic spine and later in my lumbar spine. The surgery for my lumbar fixation didn't go well and left me in severe chronic pain. That surgery was in 1997. I have been in ever-escalating pain for almost 20 years.

About 6 years ago, the rods in my thoracic spine, which had previously been without pain, started causing me pain, which has steadily gotten worse over the years. I was told they couldn't remove the rods because of the bone disease, as it could leave me quite a bit worse than I am now, including possible paralysis. Unless it is an emergent situation, the rods stay where they are and continue to cause me horrible pain.

Over the years, I've tried many things for my pain, prescription pain meds, injections, physical therapy, stretching, meditation, heat, cold, etc. I was still in pain. The prescription opiates made me a zombie, unable to have any kind of life because I was always drugged up.

Then I found out about kratom on a chronic-pain forum. I tried it. It works! After almost 20 years of this pain, I finally found something that works for my pain that doesn't make me drugged up and unable to function. It doesn't completely get rid of my pain, but it decreases it enough that it is worth it.

My severe chronic pain has taken so much of my life from me. Now that I have kratom, I feel like I can finally be somewhat of a normal person. Please don't make kratom illegal.

documents.commentText: First and foremost I should note that I am a convicted felon. For some reason people will always want to know that. However, now that I have that out of the way, I should also mention I am a husband to the most beautiful and amazing women I have ever met, a middle-class homeowner, a college graduate with a bachelors degree in banking and finance, a member of my local church community, a resourcefully effective employee at PrimeNet where I work in the accounting department, a proud American, but most of all, a loving father of four amazing children I would do anything for. Everything I am today was accomplished after I committed the crime of obtaining a controlled substance (OxyContin). I was a drug addict that went to treatment for 18 months, and served jail time and probation. I did my time and paid for my mistakes and have earned everything positive in my life through good deeds, love, and hard work. When I hurt myself in 2013, all of this was threatened when I was put back on pain killers for a quite serious back injury that occurred on the job I am currently at. This was prior to graduating and moving into the accounting department. I could have stayed on those pills and suffered just like I had when I was younger, because pain killers are so addictive and I know it first hand how horrible they can be. Kratom is nothing like the drugs the pharmaceutical companies produce. It is literally taken off of the plant, dried out, crushed and drunk within a tea or drink. You can take capsule, but there is no secret additive, as it is the natural plant that produces the results. It resolves pain, helps individuals fight the most horrible addiction and withdraws, and allows people to pay taxes while consuming a totally natural product that helps them gain their lives back. Kratom is not the be all end all of a person suffering when they are fighting an addiction, but that's why it's so effective: It forces them to face the reality of their situation, but at a much less extreme level. In addition, it is a wonderful pain killer without any of the ridiculous side effects of powerful opiates found in pharmacies and on the streets. And lets be realistic, if you drink and entire 5 ozs of Kratom you wont even be close to sick, or anything in terms of a negative outcome. Yet, drink down a 5 oz handful of Tylenol or Ibuprofen, which would be potential 30-40 pills or more, and you're dead or close to it. This is what is so strange about the situation. Over the counter pills will kill you 1000 times before Kratom could even harm you once. I agree there are symptoms if you suddenly stop taking it, but coffee will give a consistent drinker nightmarish headaches/migraines if they suddenly stop taking it. In addition to powerful stomach aches and a total loss of energy for days to weeks. Alcohol I'm not even going to get into, because we know that it destroys lives, families, livers, hearts, relationships, and it doesn't take but a single bad night for 1 or all of those to happen. I just want you to know it means a lot for the people of this nation to be able to access this one thing, this substance that has promoted so much good compared to bad. I really believe you made the right decision to reverse your ban, and I hope you give the ban a permanent stay. It is so welcomed, just as Kratom is so welcomed in this society for all the good it has allowed to come about. All the lives it is saving, the money it is saving, and the money it is making. America can benefit greatly from this, as it is a whole new market for us, and if the ban is lifted and the product can be grown right here at home, then there would be no need to purchase it from outside the USA. This would save and make so much money for us. Thanks for your consideration.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern,

Kratom has saved my mind, and in turn my life. I am a 28 year old biomedical engineer, with a Masters from the top program in this field, Johns Hopkins University. I have worked 2 years in the pharmaceutical industry with corporations including Johnson & Johnson, and Baxter International. The previous achievements would not be possible without Kratom. What Ill share here draws upon both my technical knowledge on the subject matter as a professional, my regulatory knowledge from product development in industry, and my personal experience from using Kratom.

The childhood of an engineer is oft filled with ridicule, anxiety, and depression. These attributes even today are not well understood, but can be exaggerated in the mind of one who is full of thought, and introspection. The effects of such a relationship with ones peers during childhood can be permanent, and scarring, for ones adulthood. This experience was my life at school; my life at home was worse.

My parents came to the United States to find a better life for us. Their upbringing was in a third world country full of war, famine, and strife. This experience provided them none of the emotional and spiritual tools to raise a child in a different world. My parents way of teaching was with fists and spittle, while I could see my friends parents teach with words and nurturing. I cultivated a lack of understanding, a truly negative sense of self-worth. Am I different? Am I less? Why do I get the palm when everyone gets the pat? This dichotomy truly devastates, whereas a homogeny makes one feel normal or as one should. This feeling is vital to a child. 

My life outside of home, and my life at home, cultivated a churning cauldron of anxiety and depression I carried with me to my 18th birthday. I went to college, and quickly leveraged my independence to seek release. This release? Alcohol. I was quick to observe how easily the veil lifts, and how readily I detached from my past. It was exhilarating, and gave me what I never thought possible. That is, until it didnt. Without too many details, I will share that my grades plummeted, my personality deteriorated, and I was even less of a shell than when I started. The SSRIs I eventually turned to did nothing to stop this descent, and I clawed desperately for a way out. Whether through luck or fate, I heard about Kratom. 

The introduction to Kratom was easy and full of disbelief; I reminded myself daily of how my relationship with alcohol started. The thing is, Kratom didnt ever do what alcohol did: throw me into excess. The moderation that comes from Kratom is intrinsic to its ability to mentally heal. With this discovery at the start of my Junior year, I quickly pulled 180 degrees in both academics, and two years later, professionally. I have achieved success through being able to harness my energies towards the productive. Kratom was the catalyst that focused the strengths, and perished the weaknesses, in my highly capable mind. I am today a top contributing member to society, far happier, more successful, and most of all, understanding towards my parents and childhood peers. This all would not be possible without Kratom. 

There are many comments and resources out here already submitted on the merits of Kratom, its safety, efficacy, and scientific/medical potential, so I chose to share my story. I hope it has imparted a better perspective on your readership. The agencies of this great country are meant to do one thing: make the world a better place for its inhabitants. Kratom is something that binds, mends, and bonds. The world has enough division today, please help make it better, keep Kratom legal.

Best,
Anonymous.
