My name is Willa Phillips and I am a 36 year old wife and mother from Clarksburg, West Virginia.  I am a former teacher.  I now home school my five year old son.

  I would like to share my experience with kratom.  Kratom is helping me to live a happy and productive life despite living with depression, anxiety, chronic migraines and chronic pain due to scoliosis.  It has also help me stop using opioid pain medication and benzodiazepines.   
 
    In 2007, I was teaching at a local high school, when my occasional headaches, which I had suffered from for years, became so frequent and debilitating that I had to quit teaching.  I started to search for a cause for the headaches, began having panic attacks almost daily, and was eventually diagnosed with chronic migraines, scoliosis, depression, panic disorder, asthma, and generalized anxiety disorder.  For eight years I sought conventional medical treatment.  I saw many specialists and I was prescribed many medications including hydrocodone, benzodiazepines (Xanax, Klonopin), SSRIs and Fiorocet just to name a few.  Life became a blur and my quality of life plummeted.  Nothing fully eased the pain or relieved the misery I was in.  
      Then ten months ago, I found kratom on the internet and I was able to easily quit both the narcotic pain medications and the benzodiazepines.  I have no need for either.  Kratom has truly given me my life back.  I am terrified of what would become of my family and me if I did not have kratom, 
     Kratom is safe and it helps me every day.  It changed my life.  I implore you - I beg you.  Without kratom my quality of life will quickly deteriorate.  If you have questions about kratom, please visit www.americankratom.org.
                                                                                            Thank you for your time.
                                                                                             Sincerely,

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText: I am a 65 year old man and now retired. A year and a half ago I was in an extremely serious car crash, when a van driving in the opposite lanes of the highway I was on, was hit by someone trying to pass it. The driver lost control, and came crashing through the highway divider and hit me head on at high speed. I needed three operations on my left arm and right leg, and had a metal plate installed in the arm. Worst of all, I suffered damage to my lower spinal vertebrae, which ever since the accident has left me with pain and with what I can only describe as a sensation of radiation in both my lower legs, which stays with me 24 hours a day, getting progressively worse as the day goes on. It prevents me from sleeping more than two hours without being awakened by the pain, whereupon I need to get up from a horizontal position for another hour or two until it subsides enough for me to be able to fall back asleep again, exhausted, only to be awakened again two hours later to repeat the cycle over and over. My spine and pain doctor prescribed percocet to manage the condition. Percocet works. As you know, drugged sleep is not good, refreshing sleep, and the drug has some unpleasant side effects, but nevertheless it has given me back a semblance of normal life. Six months ago, through endless research into my condition, I came across articles on kratom. I bought some and began to experiment with it. I have been amazed by the results. It's not morphine, and would not relieve the extreme pain of broken bones and severe wounds, all of which I have unfortunately experienced. But it has a very real, and very pronounced analgesic effect on the neuropathic pain that I suffer in my legs as a result of the spinal damage. I have gotten to the point where I can now alternate percocet and kratom, taking each every other day, and have recently been able to go three days on kratom, followed by only one on percocet. I hope, and am trying hard, to make a full transition to kratom alone. My doctors tell me that it could take three years or more for my neuropathic pain to subside, but to be prepared for it to never fully go away. It may be something I just have to manage for the rest of my life. Nerve damage is difficult, very slow to heal, and manifests a wide spectrum of different effects in different people. Kratom has absolutely no side effects on me. The intoxication that it causes is so extremely mild as to be negligible. Sometimes I notice a very mild, subtle feeling of relaxation; other times I feel nothing. In either case its analgesic effect is very real. I only take it at night, and after an hour or so it allows me to fall asleep and stay asleep. That is an absolute blessing for me. I feel no grogginess whatsoever the next day. I have absolutely no feeling of dependence whatsoever on the drug. To be clear, I've also never felt the slightest dependence, or "craving", for percocet, an opioid that I'm aware people get into trouble with. My view, based entirely upon my own experience, is that if these drugs are taken the right way, in the right dosages and for the right reason - namely, as medicine, and not for intoxication - that they are benign. I've never been a recreational drug user, and only occasionally drink alcohol socially. All that said, my experience is that kratom is less intoxicating than a half glass of wine with dinner, has remarkable analgesic properties, has no unpleasant side effects, and is less habit forming than a morning cup of coffee. This plant has had a profoundly positive effect on my life, which I can assure you has been quite difficult after my accident. Therefore I ask you to please keep it legal, both for people like me, and for the scientists who will be able to study its properties and possibly be able to use it to synthesize a new type of pain killer without the addictive and often debilitating side effects of all the opiates. Speaking as a father, if I found out that my children were smoking marijuana or drinking alcohol on a daily basis, I would be quite concerned. If they were using kratom on a daily basis to treat some condition, I would be relieved and happy that there was something available to help them. Thank you for reading this rather long comment. I try to be rational and sober in my views, and I'm certainly officially old now. I try to think things out myself, and base my views on my own experience, not those of others. Kratom is real, effective, harmless, and a blessing.

I discovered Mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, commonly referred to as Kratom, due to a chronic illness which creates pain, exhaustion and brain fog.  I was bed-ridden for months living on Advil and Tramadol, which left me spacey and nauseous.  I was unable to run my businesses, which adversely effected my business and my employes. Kratom made it possible for me to function in blocks of time, without danger of an overdose or addiction.  Given my success and those of my fellow tax-payers who have also turned to Kratom, I strongly believe Kratom should NOT be classified as a Class 1 drug for a multitude of reasons:

-Opiate addiction kills approximately 40 people a day in the US, alone.  Kratom is one of the ways to mitigate this issue!  It uses the opiate uptake receptor, in effect blocking the addict from getting 'high.'  The current studies in this area would be discontinued. Simultaneously, the DEA is going to restrict opiate production. What are those in pain going to do?

-The DEA references a number of deaths, however, not one single death was due to Kratom, rather they were due to cocktails of other medications, including Kratom. A number of them were due to Fentanyl. 

-In my case, I have not needed an opiate pain medication for almost a year, and have instead, been able to increase my work-load while chronically ill, due to the benefits of Kratom.  And to be clear, if I don't need the medication on  any given day, I don't suffer from withdrawals, or other deleterious symptoms if I do not use Kratom. 

-I am better able to be a parent and a wife. Pain can make a person unpleasant to be around, (it certainly does with me), and not suffering has certainly helped me continue to be a loving wife and parent. 

-And because Big Pharma has now patented the active ingredients, that is somehow better than the existing product?  Ridiculous assumption and one that makes many Americans suspicious of the FDA and DEA, and the belief in a corrupt system. 

I hope that my voice and the millions of others who utilize this plant as a relief from pain while alleviating our need for opiate drugs are able to keep our chosen, safe way to deal with pain. It is good, natural medicine.

documents.commentText:
I am a 53 year old female professional in the medical field, that has bulging discs in my neck, scoliosis in my spine, and have been diagnosed with fibromyalgia and Seasonal Affective Disorder.  I also suffer from insomnia and often wake up in the morning feeling un-refreshed.  I would often spends several days in a row in bed, unable to function due to my pain and resultant depression, and I felt there was no longer any hope.  

Kratom was suggested to me after asking what others do to treat their symptoms of chronic pain naturally.  I started investigating and learning more about this plant, Kratom, that is related to the coffee plant.  In just a matter of a few months, I tried Kratom and it didn't take me long to realize the benefits of this amazing plant.  My life changed that very same day I tried my very first cup of tea I made with the pure ground Kratom leaves.  I have only spent one day in bed (I was suffering from a biliary stone that day) and my depression has eased up, I feel more alive than I have in years, and have more energy to tackle everyday projects, like preparing and cooking a meal for my family.  After using Kratom a few days, I told my husband that it benefitted me in such a positive way, that I felt it would be outlawed - just because it helped me so well.  Then came the devastating news that the DEA was in fact, going to try to schedule it.  I feel that anyone that tries to "claim" that "Kratom is as dangerous as heroin", has never actually tried it.  If you have tried a cup of Kratom tea, you know very well, it is not the "dangerous" substance that the DEA is trying to make everyone believe it is.

The Kratom plant is related to the coffee plant and they share many of the same benefits, except that Kratom is milder and has a more natural feeling when it comes to the energy boost and uplifting my mood.  It does NOT give me a "high" or a "buzz", but rather is uplifting, helps me focus, helps ease my body aches, gives me a natural energy, improves my mood, and is very similar to drinking a cup of coffee and is no more dangerous than that cup of Joe.

I am happy to report that Kratom, a natural plant leaf, has given me my life back and I am able to enjoy living again.  I now have a grandson that I am caring for and must attest that it really has changed my life.  To make this plant illegal, would be devastating to me, personally.  I would like to see Kratom remain legal and accessible for everyone to use as a natural supplement.  Please do NOT make the Kratom plant a scheduled substance or out law it.  It really is a harmless plant with some amazing health benefits.


Sincerely,



Tamara M. Calise RT(R)

documents.commentText:
Please do not ban kratom for the following reasons:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.
Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Kratom should not be banned because: 
 
1). Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
2). If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
3). Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
4). Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
5). Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
6). Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText: I started using Mitragyna Speciosa,  AKA Kratom four years ago. I've suffered with severe bipolar disorder. All my life. I began having issues as an early teenager. I have been prescribed Paxil, Zoloft, anatriptaline, Valium, Depakote, and a few others. Nothing helped me. I had a motorcycle accident that severed my foot from my leg. I was prescribed perscription opiates. They helped for a very short time. A few months into using the prescribed opiates I went into one of the worst bipolar episodes I had ever experienced thus far.  I can only attribute that to the opiates I was taking at the time. I went from the sever depression bipolar into the bipolar/manic type. I tried stopping the opiates. The pain I was going through and the mental agony I experienced was tremendous. So now on top of my bipolar, I was suffering from chronic pain. So I kept taking opiates. I would feel good one month and another month or so I would go into a deep dark depression. I was either way up or way down. Which to me at the time was better than being severely depressed all the time. Either way, I was unable to take care of myself or my family with any kind of consistency. This pattern went on into my 30s. At the age of 32 I was introduced through differing support groups to plants and herbs that others claimed had helped them with similar issues. I tried quite a few and did quite a bit of research. Many did help. Such as holy basil for anxiety/ depression, turmeric for anti inflammatory, Akumma seeds that help with pain, shilijat, for mood, cats claw for pain, and many others. Then I began using Kratom. It didn't work all that well at first. But I was told to keep trying, that different strains worked differently with individuals. I found a combination of green vein, and red vein leaves that began to help me considerably. Once I found the strain and proper amount to take, I noticed and family members noticed an enormous improvement in my wellbeing in general. I've been taking Kratom Four years now. I feel stable and balanced and just plain capable. Im well into a career now as a CNC department supervisor. I've been working the same place for two years. Prior to this job I haven't been stable enough to maintain employment for any longer than 6 to 9 months. My family wife and children all attest to the difference this plant has made in my life. They feel as though they can depend on me, and they can and do now. I feel as though I'm clear minded, goal oriented, motivated, happy more times than not. My level of chronic pain and fatigue has all but disappeared. Many other aspects of my life have improved as well I could go on.   That plant changed my whole families welfare not just mine. I beg you to to keep this plant available to the public. Age restriction I agree with. Schedule of any kind I strongly disagree with. Hundreds of thousands of people benefit from this plant. I've seen testimonies from mothers that can manage their families, fathers that have put down heroin or prescription pain killers and lead productive lives, Teachers that suffer from fibromyalgia return to work, elderly whom suffer from severe arthritis become active and lead healthy lifestyles because of the benefits this plant has provided for them. Research must be allowed to continue. This plant must not be taken from the people. Our country is experiencing an opiate and pharmaceutical epidemic. This plant has brought many out of the grasp of that epidemic.  The pharmaceutical companies already have the alkaloids in the kratom plant researched and patented. They want to synthesis it, make it into something they can sell to the public. Everything they touch turns bad. Let the people choose to take this plant in its natural form. The pharmaceutical industry will make something bad out of it, and raise the price on it so much that it will cause hardships. This plant helps people in its natural form. I know my family and I's lives will be turned upside down and many others will also if this plant becomes inaccessible. Addicts will return to street drugs or pain pills, people will have to quit their jobs, vendors will lose their businesses, vital research that's going on right now concerning this plant will be halted, overdoses from heroin, and prescription drugs will spike tragically at very high rates, children will lose their mothers and fathers. There are dire consequences to taking this plant away. Please do not take away a plant that has the potential to thwart the opioid epidemic.

documents.commentText:
Let me start by saying that I respect our agencies and appreciate all that they do for us. The facts and hard statistics do not support the scheduling of kratom's two alkaloid compounds. Kratom is helping so many people cope with debilitating personal issues such as anxiety, depression and ptsd as well as pain management. I have severe arthritis. Bone deteriorating arthritis. I will be dealing with this on my own if kratom were to become a schedule 1 "drug". I have seen far too many people throw their lives away to opiate prescription medication. I can not bring those chemicals into my home. I will not expose my family to those drugs and in that, I will be in terrible pain every moment.

The fact of the matter is, this plant has been around far longer than this country and without incident. There are no documented cases of overdose to support a scheduled classification. Yes, uneducated people have taken too much and become sick for a couple hours. Those that have died with kratom in their system were all under the influence of something else as well. None of this warrants a drug scheduling. 

I understand the fear of losing business in the pharmaceutical industry but lets face it, that's solely greed speaking and that is what this is truly about. Go ahead and regulate and tax if you NEED to control it like EVERYTHING else but don't make us normal people out to be criminals just so the g.o.v can incarcerate more innocent people, further congesting our detention centers. We are 5% of the world's population and we hold over 25% of those incarcerated. Let's stop this momentum now for the better of our country. If this continues we will see a lot more citizens choosing to leave, as our country continues to prove it actually is far from being the best country in the world.

Scheduling kratom will only make this country a worse place to live. Let people have access to this wonderful plant. It truly is a godsend. Thank you for your time. I wish you nothing but the best.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary, kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how kratom works: 
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6 

About kratom, a leading researcher notes: 
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v 

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet, the FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom? 
As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
Hello,
I'm writing to you as someone who has benefited greatly from kratom.  I have Chronic Fatigue Syndrome, which is a notoriously difficult condition to manage and treat.  From the age of 12 to around 25, I had a really difficult time functioning and succeeding in life, whether it be at school, work, or with social obligations.  I'm now 31, and for the past few years have not really considered myself to be suffering from the the effects of CFS.  My improvement is due to a variety of factors, and I'm certainly not claiming that  kratom has even been the major player, but it has been extremely useful to me in regulating my energy and mood, without any negative side effects that I have been aware of.  As someone who has gone through years of trying different types of medications and treatments, some of which had terrible side effects, kratom has been one of the most effective things I've tried in terms of it's benefits to my energy level and productivity and lack of negative effects.  I am now not only capable of working full time, but also working in the evenings to start a small business, and in no small part thanks to kratom.  I've heard stories from people with diverse medical problems who claim that kratom has helped them on levels far beyond what I'm describing, and while personal anecdotes are not scientific facts, I hope that they at least speak to the need for further research and access.  Please don't shut the door for good on what could be an incredible opportunity to help and heal!  Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,

Victoria Eskenazi

She found Kratom 7 years ago which I can honestly say saved not only our marriage but her life.  Kratom helped with cravings as well as pain and overall emotional well being. I know she needs occasional relief from Percocet as Kratom doesn't manage severe pain, but kratom allows for more manageable transition off opioids so the threat of addiction and the related dangers surrounding addiction are gone. Making this plant illegal will cause disaster and destruction of so many lives and families I pray they do not make this horrible mistake.

documents.commentText:
Hi, 

In 2010 I was ejected from my car and broke my spine in 5 places, 2 of which were burst fractures. I've been through every single pain management option there is to offer including 2 spinal fusions, injections, physical therapy, tens, chiropractor, acupuncture, etc. I've also been prescribed nearly every pain killer there is: morphine, dilaudid, butrans, oxycontin, oxycodone, hydrocodone, tramadol, lyrica, meloxicam, etc. Nothing has stopped my pain. I have been in pain for 2420 days. I have lost jobs, had to drop classes, and lost friends & family. I've been treated like a drug addict by nurses, pharmacists, and doctors. 

That was all until I found Kratom. I can now have days where I spend the majority of it with no pain. I don't have to pay a copay to see a doctor who no longer wants to see me for fear she will lose her licence (her words, not mine).  I don't have to miss work to go to monthly appointments, I don't have to schedule my life around refill appointments, and I don't have to be treated like a criminal at my doctor's office, or at a pharmacy. I'm happy to be alive again.

I implore you, please let us have control over our pain and keep this plant legal and unregulated. I can't go back to living in a world where I am in pain everyday. 2420 days was enough for one person for one lifetime.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,
    My name is Jonah Ricke. I am a 29 year old business owner from Colorado, and I completely oppose any attempt to make the herbal supplement known as Kratom illegal. Putting this plant on the list of schedule 1 substances is a ridiculous abuse of the DEA's power. This attempt shows that the government can enact laws without any major scientific revelations to back it up. This plant has been legal in the United States for centuries and never seemed to have caused a problem before. Now that more people are discovering the amazing benefits of this plant, the DEA is trying to say that there are absolutely no benefits of this plant. Furthermore, the DEA seems to have justified creating an emergency law by creating a self-fulfilling logical loop in describing all use of kratom as abuse, and then claiming that the plant has a high likelihood for abuse. This is just silly and is a logical fallacy
   I personally have used kratom for about five years, and I have not found the plant to be addictive or "a drug". I like to take kratom some days when I am skiing or hiking as an alternative to coffee. I do not go skiing or hiking as much as I'd like to, so my use of this plant only ends up being about 10-15 a year. Kratom is an amazing alternative to coffee or caffeine containing drinks because in my experience it acts as a more mild simulate, does not give the "jitters" as caffeine, and it also has mild pain relieving properties. It is also much more portable than a cup of coffee. These factors make kratom a great supplement to add to any strenuous outdoor (or indoor) physical activity. When I use kratom, I will take one 500 milligram capsules twice over the course of the day. If you do the math on that, over the past five years i have only consumed between 50 and 75 grams of dried kratom leaves in capsule form. That hardly seems like the habits of someone who is consuming "a dangerous and addictive drug" as the DEA wants to label it.
    In conclusion, I consider myself a great example of how kratom is not addictive or a drug. I personally have not experienced any sign of addiction or abuse in myself or others that I know to have consumed kratom. Furthermore, I am a fully functioning adult and a taxpaying United States citizen, and do not appreciate any attempt to curtail my freedom to put whatever plants in or on my body. Stop making nature and life illegal. Let people decide for themselves what is good or bad for them and stay out of their personally business.

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
    If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
    Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
    Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
    Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
    Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.
there's no profit incentive for pharmaceutical companies to do years of clinical research to gain FDA approval for a plant that they can't patent for prescription use...

documents.commentText: Two things control my days: my career in early phase drug development and my L4/L5 & L5/S1 spinal injury. I first injured my spine in 2009. Since then, I've had to give up several things in my life like powerlifting and being able to work in the yard without a back brace. At first, I was prescribed hydrocodone, which helped with the pain and allowed me to sleep, but the side effects ruined my life. I was severely constipated with every dose, and it upset my stomach greatly. Combined with cyclobenzaprine for spasms, it made me feel like I was in a fog. Then, I discovered kratom one day. Everything changed. Instead of painkillers, I use red vein kratom. I am able to sleep without pain and I'm not constipated. As a drug development professional, I know MEDRA Adverse Events and their scoring. I have had no adverse events associated with kratom since I started using it for pain a year ago. The risk/benefit ratio I see is a substance that does not require scheduling. I have never been so sure of anything before in my life. Kratom assists me to live a painkiller free life, which is something that most spinal injury patients never receive. In my professional opinion, it does not meet the threshold necessary for emergency scheduling.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

In regards to the proposed scheduling of Mitragyna Speciosa, also known as kratom, I am using this method of a public comment in order to voice my disapproval of the proposed scheduling of Mitagyna Speciosa to a schedule 1 substance.

The problem I have with this proposed scheduling is when it comes to the CSA stating, "the DEA Administrator may temporarily place a substance in Schedule I where he finds that doing so is necessary to avoid an imminent hazard to the public safety."  Particularly, "imminent hazard".  According to the Cornell University Law school, "...imminent hazard means the existence of a condition that presents a substantial likelihood that death, serious illness, severe personal injury, or a substantial endangerment to health, property, or the environment may occurr..." I am very confused as to why the DEA assumes Mitragyna Speciosa to be an imminent hazard.

The DEA states that over the course of two years, ranging from 2014 to 2016, the substance know as Kratom was at fault for 15 deaths. However, the DEA fails to mention that in all 15 deaths, other substances were also found in the bodies of the deceased that are known to be fatal in overdoses on their own.  And according to a 2016 review of the deaths by Warner, M.L., Kaufman, N.C. & Grundmann, O. Int J Legal Med; "there is no solid evidence that kratom was the sole contributor to an individual's death."  

And with the DEA also stating there is enough kratom currently in the US to account for 12 million doses, and only 15 non-directly related deaths being attributed to kratom, the threat hardly seems to be an imminent hazard. There is a much higher percentage of alcohol deaths and prescription drugs per dosage than kratom, yet there is no attempt to act because of an "imminent hazard" on the public for those substances.

Also the DEA is ignoring the current medical use that so many kratom users are reporting. Reported uses range from lower blood pressure, relief of pain, increased metabolism, increased sexual energy, immune system booster, anxiety easer, stress reliever, sleep aider, and providing help with addiction to other substances. And while these reported benefits may or may not be true, the DEA is preemptively outlawing a plant that helps many more people than it has supposedly harmed. The DEA would be wise to at least let more clinical studies be preformed before drawing judgement on a plant it knows little about.

documents.commentText:
Please consider the following when viewing policy action that would ban the use and investigation of the benefits of kratom in the United States:   

 Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

    If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

    Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

    Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

    Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

    Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

While the basic reason for the existence of the DEA is to control and discourage the use of chemical agents by the population this is in itself, not a reason in itself to ban the use and study of the medicinal value of Kratom. Canabis, subject to the same draconian law for many years is just now being discovered as a medicinally useful plant.  The DEA should not determine whether or not to ban any drug or plant.  That should be the realm of medical professionals and the scientific community.

documents.commentText:
Any attempt to schedule or otherwise ban Kratom would be ill-advised.  It has documented medicinal beneficial effects, as witnessed by millions of users in USA and around the world.  Adverse effects are virtually unheard of, and not reliably documented.  Prescription drugs have a monumentally more significant track record of adverse effects, up to and including death.  The beneficial properties of Kratom are widely known.  The downside risks are rare and minimal.  The potential for abuse is vastly overstated.  Quite the contrary, Kratom has proven to be a great help for withdrawal from opioids.  The opioid epidemic in this country has been widely publicized, so we should be promoting alternatives such as Kratom, not banning them.  Furthermore, any attempt to schedule or ban Kratom would prohibit any further research into the benefits and the mechanisms of Kratom effects.  I am urging you in the strongest possible terms to abandon all attempts to restrict the possession and use of Kratom.

Thank you for your consideration.

documents.commentText:
The Drug Enforcement Agency is already viewed as a laughing stock of non-science.  Unfortunately their latest quest, again not based on facts, further erodes their respect.  Please verify facts before making decisions.  Among items to consider for kratom are:

	Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
	If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
	Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
	Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
	Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
	Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

To say this is a very dangerous substance with no potential medical use is an outright lie.

documents.commentText:
I am a 47 year old Accounting Manager with Multiple Sclerosis, Advanced Degenerative Disc Disease, Spondilosis, and Scoliosis....

In an effort to keep this short, sweet, and to the point I am going to leave a large chunk of my testimony out and try to stick to the facts of how Kratom has helped transform my life!

I was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis when I was 19 years old ..it would be another 10 years before I was diagnosed with the other diseases. At 19 years old I was told that I would be in a wheelchair by the time I was 30 and that my life would be managed with pharmaceutical drugs and physical therapy. Determined to change that outcome I set my life course to become as healthy as I could by eating right, exercising right, and using herbs and vitamins to control my symptoms and for the most part this worked well for me. For about 15 years I managed to hold off what doctors told me I couldn't avoid. But by the time I was 35 the disease had set in and was taking over my body. I began to suffer from debilitating muscle spasms in my neck and back and this would be the first time I ever took prescription pain pill to control the pain associated with MS, degenerative disc disease and spondylosis. Needless to say it didn't take long for the prescription opioid medication to take over my life. Within five years of taking my first pill I was addicted and just like everybody else began a course of abuse and dependence on the opioid pain medication. By the time I was 40, whatever left of my life that wasn't robbed by the disease was now under siege by the pain medicine and my life resembled no kind of living. I was merely existing to wake up, take pain medicine and go back to sleep. It would be another two years before Kratom was introduced to me and I would gain control of my life again. Kratom not only helps to manage the pain associated with MS, degenerative disc disease, and spondylosis but it also helped me break my addiction to the pain medicine that I thought I would be slaved to forever. I would later learn through my experience with kratom how bad my addiction to the opiate pain pills actually was and how the opiate pain pills contributed to the problem and the pain. Now I'm able to manage my symptoms, which range from pain, to issues with balance and, restless leg syndrome and anxiety with two simple teaspoons of Kratom each morning. In discovering Kratom's fantastic benefits it has not only given me my life back but I can afford to live as well. Where I was once unable to work and function in society I now hold a managerial position and work up to 60 hours a week at times because I'm functioning in life. My days are no longer consumed by countless doctors appointments and pharmacy errands. Kratom has returned the quality of my life to me and I shudder to think what will happen to me if Kratom is taken away or made unavailable or becomes ridiculously so expensive I can't buy it. This just can't happen. I also feel it's important to mention that while I was on the opiate pain meds my blood pressure had to be control with blood pressure meds because I could it get it under 165/99. Now my blood pressure is a steady 110/88 without meds to control it and all I take is Kratom. Before Kratom I was on 3 different pain meds, BP meds, anxiety meds, depression meds, nerve meds, and steroids! I've replaced all that with two teaspoons of Kratom each day and I am not only living but I am ALIVE! 

Kratom is safe based on my 5 years of experience. I have never had any adverse reactions to Kratom and I can't say enough how my life has steadily improved since the day I discovered Kratom. 

Please don't take it away from me!

documents.commentText:
I am a 38 year old mother of 3 with chronic pain, depression & anxiety. I have facet joint arthritis, herniated discs, torn discs, scoliosis and hip issues. I have PTSD from childhood sexual abuse as well as being in an abusive marriage I finally got out of.   Years ago I was prescribed pain medication for my physical ailments.  The longer I took it, the less it would work.  I felt tired, worn out, unable to think clearly, and it was expensive.  I no longer felt like myself - but rather a shell of who I used to be.  But without it, I could barely get out of bed, let alone be a contributing member of society.  I was depressed, I didn't see an end in sight to the awful cycle of 'needing' the meds just to attempt to have any quality of life.

I researched many things: medications, herbs, vitamins and the like.  I tried chiropractic, acupuncture, massage therapy, bee sting therapy.  None of these worked for any long period of time. I had spinal injections, hip surgery, did rounds of steriods.  Still the pain would always come back.  During my research I found kratom and decided to try it.  What did I have to lose, I figured.

My life changed drastically, for the better, after that day.  Kratom has given me my life back.  This is no exaggeration,  I honestly feel the most "normal" i have in YEARS.  After 5+ years of being on heavy prescription narcotics, I have been free of any narcotic pain medicine now for 4-1/2 years.  There are just no words to describe what a relief it is not to be dependent on something that could have killed me.  There is no way to explain how wonderful it is to feel like myself, not someone just going through the motions of life.  There is no way to explain how for me, kratom is hope.  Kratom helps my pain, anxiety, depression.  Kratom helps me to be a better wife, a better mother, a  better person - because i can participate in life now, I don't have to sit and cry out of sheer pain every day.

I am absolutely terrified for there to be a ban on kratom.  I do not want to go back on prescription narcotics, I do not want to be in horrid pain every day.  I do not want to have to take higher and higher doses of medication that could kill me.  There is currently an awful epidemic of heroin/opioid use and overdoses gripping our country.  I cannot understand why in the midst of such a crisis, anyone would want to take away something that could help.  People are dying, and if i was forced to go back on prescription narcotics, I could be one of those people.  

I fully support regulation of kratom while still keeping it legal, but an outright ban on it would be life shattering for me, and so many people like me.  Since getting off prescription drugs, I have made so, so many positive changes in my life.  I started my own company which enables me to work from home, so I can be here for my children everyday.  I am able to engage with my children, care for them, and do everyday tasks that before I just couldn't do.  I am not mentally "out of it" like i was on prescription drugs.  I am full of hope, laughter and love for them.

Please do not take the life I am able to have due to kratom's effect on my physical and mental pain away from me, from my kids or my husband.

Sincerely,

Ellen Kozak

documents.commentText:
I am a 26 year old female from Tacoma, Washington. I have a Bachelor of Arts in Sociology and my passions lay in helping disadvantaged people, particularly children. I have a strong empathetic connection to individuals struggling with mental disorders, as I suffer from Panic Disorder (PTSD related), Generalized Anxiety Disorder, and Depression. I am opposed to the DEA's intent to put Kratom as a Schedule 1 drug. Kratom is not a drug. Kratom is not addictive! Kratom truly saves lives.

Here's my story:

While at the University of Washington, Seattle, I spent a lot of time experimenting with different therapies in alleviating my PTSD symptoms; biofeedback, breathing exercises, visualization, meditation, exercise, talk therapy, etc. I also was prescribed several medications and more medication to relieve the side effects caused from the first medications. I had been prescribed every medication under the sun since I was 16.

While in college, the stress of classes and assignments increased my stress to the point that my panic attacks were out of control. Unfortunately, my desperation increased and I choose to self-medicate with alcohol. My alcohol use during panic attacks slowly turned into a full blown dependence. I chose to use it because I wanted to do anything that would avoid the absolute terror I felt during my panic episodes. I often felt like I was suffering as if I was imminent danger, as if a gun was to my head....in reality, I was alone in my dorm room writing a paper. This sheer terror often came with an excruciating pain in my stomach that felt like there where hot coals melting throughout my body. 

Unfortunately, I drank to the point where I damaged my pancreas, leading to several bouts of Pancreatitis. I now suffer from chronic pancreatic pain; this pain is amplified when the panic attacks occur.

After doing some research online, I ran into a message board for people who suffer from anxiety. Kratom was mentioned several times and I decided to order it online. I remember the first time I used this supplement; the best way to describe what it did is simply to say that it took the edge off. I felt more in control and my breathing exercises and biofeedback practices actually began to work whenever a panic attack came on. Most importantly, Kratom removed the horrible pains I would feel in my core...neither Ibuprofen, Tylenol, or Naproxen did the trick. NEVER did I feel intoxication. I felt like I drank a great cup of coffee that didn't make me jittery!

I was using Kratom in a time where it was not sold and marketed in head shops next to synthetic drugs like Spice or Bath Salts in gaudy packaging. Unfortunately, these companies created a negative image of what Kratom actually is. Concerned members of society began investigating, and rightfully so. No one in the Kratom community would be supportive of Kratom being sold as if it was a synthetic drug or as if it a cure for anything. It is also concerning to the community that Kratom is often adulterated with other unknown synthetic components. I do believe this is rare, but it is something that needs to be dealt with.

Kratom supplements my treatment of my Panic Disorder and my chronic pancreatic pain (Endocratic Pancreatic Deficiency). Without Kratom, I am able to survive, but my struggle will be intense and I am not sure how I will be able to continue working and being a productive member of society.

I have seen heroin addicts use Kratom to get off of heroin, or at least supplement with a less dangerous option. This itself has probably saved many lives; from what I have read, Kratom does not create the kind of respiratory depression as heroin does. KRATOM NEEDS TO BE STUDIED FOR THIS REASON ALONE! Kratom, as a schedule 1 drug, will be limited in its ability to be studied. We need everyone taking a look at the alkaloids in this plant and studying it. If I, or anyone else in the Kratom community, used Kratom illicitly we would not be begging for research! I have had 3 friends who have died from an opiate related overdose. Kratom being available in the US as it has been has probably saved many people...either from chronic pain, PTSD, heroin addiction, panic disorder, etc.

Kratom saves lives.

Sincerely,

Leah Staub

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern,

I am a recent college grad working in the non-profit sector.  I just finished my AmeriCorps year of service in which I spent Aug '15- July '16 teaching service learning to youth ages 11-18.  I spent much of that time volunteering with those same youth at various non-profits in the major metropolitan area I live in.  

I am diagnosed with Major Depressive Disorder and anxiety.  I am on prescribed anti-depressants that I've been taking for several years, but when I forget to take a dose (or can't motivate myself to out of the apathy that comes with my depression), the medicine doesn't stay in my system long enough to work well enough.  I spend a lot of time feeling anxious and hopeless and worried about nothing in particular.  

When I first heard about Kratom on social media after the DEA's proposed ban, I had never heard of it.  I did further research and found out that it has been anecdotally proven to help with anxiety and depression.  Since it is still legal in the state I live in, I went to my local head shop and talked to the owner about it.  He was very knowledgeable and agreed that it had helped him with his own anxiety.  I bought a container of about 20 capsules and the next time I missed a dose of my medicine and was feeling anxious, I took about 2 grams worth.  

Kratom makes me feel like a normal person!  I feel much more motivated to do things that would normally have felt too daunting.  It doesn't make me dangerously delirious or high. It helps me feel like everyday tasks are do-able and I don't needlessly worry anymore.

The most amazing thing that has happened to me post-Kratom use is my slowed usage of alcohol.  I have a family history of alcoholism, and though I wouldn't have said I was an alcoholic pre-Kratom, my drinking was definitely starting to get worrisome.  I would only drink at night after work and before bed, but I would always drink to excess.  There was a stretch of about a year where I  never went longer than a week without drinking.  Now, I hardly ever "feel" like drinking.  I drink maybe two or three times a month, and never to the point I used to.

I am a much happier and better-functioning human being on Kratom and I hope you consider stories like mine before scheduling it.

Thank you.

Kratom is certainly no hallucinogenic.  However an individual can sniff any number of household products (like laundry detergent), they can make you hallucinate.

Kratom is a very effective OTC analgesic.  It is also extremely effective in ameliorating opiate withdrawal and aiding rehabilitation from continuing opioid abuse.

It needs to be seriously researched and implemented for both these uses.  It would be ignorant to ban it when other safe treatment for opioid abuse rehabilitation are scarce or nonexistent.

And remember, the most dangerous OTC drug is Tylenol--which can easily cause liver failure fatalities.

I eat well, exercise regularly and get lots of sleep - I do my best to take care of myself in general. I have never had chronic physical pain or an opiate problem, but I've pretty much always been prone to depression and social anxiety -as long as I can remember, even as a kid. I've been prescribed many different mood stabilizes and anti-depressants and each time I couldn't wait to get whatever zombie pill they gave me out of my system. The FDA & DEA-sanctioned drugs that a doctor prescribed to me made me feel non-human and emotionless.

I discovered kratom almost a year ago, and it has eased my anxiety and helped me see over the fog of depression to the extent of putting into action a new life for my family. With kratom I no longer look to alcohol to be able to bear social situations, and I feel clear-headed and the most "myself" I've ever felt. It's not a "high" that kratom gives me, it's a subtle, yet effective relief.

I don't know what I'm going to do if kratom is banned. I can't imagine going back to the crippling anxiety, general malaise and cravings for harmful substances, such as alcohol, that affect both my work and home life.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern regarding putting kratom in the Schedule 1 class. That is simply ridiculous!  You cannot get high on kratom. I know! This tree leaf is helping so many people in many different ways all without the possibility of death. You take too much you get blurry vision and really really nauseated. Kratom should be left alone! We were doing just fine with it before you got involved. The biggest argument is that it acts like an opiate. Yes it does! We get all the benefits without risking death! But "acting like an opiate"  is as far as it goes. The alkaloids in kratom connect with SOME of the receptors in the brain that opiates do, BUT NOT ALL THAT THEY DO. Kratom helps with pain of all sorts and some people even get the added benefit of their nervousness and shyness being lessened. 
Let me tell you my brief experience with kratom. I have chronic back and neck pain. I get pain pills but it takes more and more to do the same work as one pill used to do in the beginning. So I run out and have to go through opiate withdrawals. That really sucks BAD!  I was working out of town in North Carolina a few years ago and ran out of my prescription pain meds. I was freaking out. I had meetings to attend and work to do. I couldn't afford to deal with the pain and withdrawals. I searched Google for help with my situation and I kept seeing the same herbal item KRATOM. I did my research on kratom for the next hour. It sounded too good to be true!  I did a search in my area for kratom retailers and found one. I went there on my lunch  and bought some capsules of it. I took a few and just waited. Not expecting anything I was COMPLETELY AMAZED!  Not only did kratom ease my pain and suffering, it even got rid of the opiate withdrawal symptoms!!  I went back to the store and bought some more to get me through my week and trip back home. After I got home I started dear ching my locality for kratom sellers. And what I found out literally brought tears to my eyes. Kratom was banned in my state of Indiana a few years earlier! I couldn't believe it!  So in between my trips out of town I had to settle for buying pills from neighbors and friends when I ran out! I really looked forward to my trips to Charlotte, NC for work because I could buy and use kratom! I was no longer a slave to that damn pain pill. The freedom was a glorious feeling although short lived. After a week out of town I had to come back to the state that would not let me choose a herbal solution for my pain!! The lawmakers of Indiana bought into the hype and misinformation about kratom when they banned bath salts and that fake marijuana incense stuff. They just clumped kratom in with those killers!! 
Please don't ban kratom across the US. I wouldn't wish what I have to deal with and go through not having access to kratom and doing whatever I have to do to get pain pills just to avoid withdrawal. PLEASE LET ME CHOOSE THE HEALTHIER ALL NATURAL SOLUTION FOR MY CHRONIC PAIN. PLEASE MAKE IT LEGAL IN INDIANA AGAIN. PLEASE DON'T MAKE ME KEEP USING THESE PRESCRIPTION PAIN KILLERS. I'M SO AFRAID I'M GOING TO ACCIDENTALLY OD WHILE TRYING TO TREAT MY PAIN. PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE HAVE MERCY ON US. Kratom is a better option than Norco & Percocets, etc. I want my life back please. This "hydrocodone haze"  is changing me. Withdrawn, unmotivated, depressed, apathy. Kratom did not have those side effects. Please don't make us suffer. I'm begging you.....

documents.commentText:
My name is Caroline Palmieri and I'm a 39 year old female living in Las Vegas and working as a cocktail server since I was 21. I carry a heavy tray and wear high heels 40 hours per week. I developed excruciating back pain over the years and have been living with chronic pain since 2009. I was taking massive amounts of prescribed narcotic pain meds for several years.  What my doctor didn't prescribe me I bought on the street.  Not only did I intermittently stop working several times because the pain meds made me crazy and my life fell apart, but every relationship in my life suffered or ended as a result. I lost my house because I spent my mortgage money on pills. My behavior was erratic and my temper was through the roof. I drank regularly and mixed that with my prescribed meds to dull the pain. Driving under those circumstances was normal when I had to work. 

I discovered Kratom in 2011 and have been taking it ever since. I completely stopped needing/ taking all narcotic pain medication in 2014 because I learned that I really don't need it if I gauge the proper amounts of Kratom to take and time it properly.  My worst time of day is in the morning, waking up with severe back pain after not having it in my system for 6-8 hours.  I keep It on my nightstand and take it immediately upon waking. After it kicks in, I fall back asleep and wake later feeling really great. 

This stuff is a miracle. No joke. I contemplated suicide every day for several years while on prescribed medication. Sure, pain meds are great until they aren't. When the pain breaks through each time it's like your life is over all over again each time  until you feed yourself another pain pill and make it stop. But it wears off so quickly that you plan your entire life around the pain. I even made an emergency suicide cocktail comprised of a lethal dosage of enough morphine to kill a horse. I held on to this thinking that surely the day would come when I would finally give up and end my tortuous life of pain.  Then one day by accident I stumbled on Kratom at a friends house. He said it would give me energy but didn't mention anything about helping ease my back pain. I waited months and even forgot about it. Then I found it in a drawer and took it to go run some errands and later that night realized I hadn't needed to take any pain pills. It was amazing. That was the first time in several years I was free. It was like my pain disappeared all day and night. So I researched it and started purchasing online. 

Now, 6 years later I buy Kratom by the kilogram and buy many, many different strains (15).  I have several capsule filling machines (25-400 capsules). I carry a pill case in my purse and have my Kratom in my kitchen and bedside. I take Kratom regularly and my life is wonderful. I haven't missed a day of work from my back pain in years. I have remodeled my house doing a lot of the work myself. I absolutely believe Kratom saved my life. I no longer contemplate suicide because I have learned that I can thrive with Kratom. I don't have to end my life.  BUT.....Taking Kratom from me would be sending me back to that dark place. I believe my life would be over. I know I couldn't go through that again or put my family through all of it.

documents.commentText:
To Those Whom Make The Rules,

I have been a regular user of Kratom for over 3 years now. A married adult with a more than full time job... you know, the model citizen that America seems to want. I have spent the last 10+ years of my life with a condition which causes sometimes extreme pain, but persistent pain at the least. My doctor had me on Hydrocodone but after years of that I wanted something that wasn't going to control me, or mess me up. So I did some research and found out about Kratom. Since using Kratom my quality of life has improved 10 fold. 

But now, the government is taking a position to extinguish my liberties. My liberties to take what I'd like, my liberties to not be in pain, you want to turn me into a felon tomorrow for doing what is legal today. There is currently no evidence that I know of to even suggest Kratom is a danger to the public. How many cases of death do you even have for people that solely use Kratom? I doubt any, but even if there is any, I'm sure it's less than aspirin, or people who choke to death on hot dogs annually. 

So you are either taking the approach of using heavy handed authoritative rule to strip us of our rights, or you are being paid off by lobbyists for drug companies currently researching some of the active chemicals in Kratom. There is absolutely no good reason, or even the least bit ethical reason for you to schedule Kratom. 

I am sincerely asking you to stop this attack on Kratom. It is an attack on me, and my quality of life. Maybe one day I won't have to use Kratom for pain management, but I would hope that anyone else in the United States of America would have the option. The option to make a decision for themselves. The option to not become addicted to deadly FDA approved drugs. Please think about what you're doing and who you're doing it for. This is not crack or meth. This is a naturally occurring leaf that offers people comfort.  

Zachary Collins

documents.commentText: These natural plant compounds that have been consumed for 1000's of years in Asia as a tea should not be placed into Schedule I. The NIH is currently funding studies to investigate the potential medicinal use of kratom-related compounds and therefore its constituents should not be placed into a category of "no currently accepted medical use."  Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine are derived from plants of the Rubiaceae family (other members include coffee and gardenias) and have much more complex pharmacology (and lower abuse potential) than classic opiates with its effects on 2, 5-HT2A, , , and  receptors, along with providing anti-inflammatory effects via inhibition of prostaglandin E2 production (Prozialek et al, 2012).  The activity at , and  receptors is particularly interesting since these may be alternate pathways to prevent the addiction potential of pure  agonists. As a psychiatric pharmacist, I routinely see patients struggling with addiction to FDA-approved prescription opioids like Vicodin and Oxycontin, so eliminating one potential harm reduction strategy with a much lower abuse potential seems like a very poor decision during our current opiate epidemic.  I am also concerned that scheduling these compounds will hinder ongoing scientific inquiry into the potential pharmacologic benefits of these compounds and other chemical analogs for the treatment of pain and opioid replacement therapy.

I am a Registered Nurse, and studying for my Family NP.

DEA does not regulate alcohol, does not regulate cigarettes - both of which actually harm and kill people, whereas Kratom has a safety record spanning hundreds of years. No one has ever died solely from using pure Kratom, no one.

Kratom is the only thing I can give my elderly parents that seems to help their pain, without any dangerous side effects. My 77 year old mother is a retired RN, has afib, and thus is on an oral anticoagulant medication. She has Rheumatoid Arthritis and such severe osteoporosis she gets fractures from daily life. She is not supposed to take aspirin or ibuprofen or naproxen, or any other NSAID for pain, due to the high risk of bleeding. Narcotic medication makes her so loopy, she loses days, and she cannot function. She also gets constipated.

My father is 88 years old, a Korean War combat veteran, an electrical lineman for 40 years. He has a bad back, and osteoarthritis in both of his feet from wearing steel toed shoes for decades. His doctor doesn't want him taking NSAIDs over the same bleeding concern.

Kratom helps both of them with their pain, and in my mother's case, also seems to help reduce her anxiety.

If I do not have Kratom to give them, the only choice they will have is to use narcotic painkillers, and endure all of the life changing side effects that goes with narcotics, which neither of them wants to do.

Please, leave Kratom alone. If you want FDA to regulate it purely to the extent of making sure the Kratom we buy is actual Kratom, that would be wonderful. But please, focus on real problems, like rampant narcotic abuse, like the massive spike in heroin use, and leave Kratom alone.

documents.commentText:
I have been a patient of more than 10 physicians, since being diagnosed with a rare neurological disorder called IIH along with chronic severe migraine.   The disabling nature of my illness is profound, the pain is chronic and hits peaks of severity several times per week.  The visual distortions and audio whooshing of the neurological disorder and the pain of varying severity are not controlled with any available painkillers and make it very very difficult for me to complete activities of daily life like housework.  Work is currently out-of-the-question.   I was a licensed career medical professional before my injuries became severe.  I hope to return to work some day if effective treatment can be devised.  

Kratom is not a miracle cure for me, but when I have a spike of severe pain it usually takes the edge off enough that can I partially function and/or return to a tolerable condition.  I usually take a teaspoon and a half dissolved into a cup of hot cocoa, and usually I get partial relief within 45 minutes or so.  When a pain spike becomes intolerable, any relief at all is very helpful.  At this dosage, I am somewhat calmed.  At lower dosage, I feel mildly agitated without much pain benefit.  At higher dosage the kratom acts more as a sedative and sometimes makes me too sleepy to function and I just need to nap.   It is not intoxicating in the way that alcohol is intoxicating.  It is more of a sedative that allows me to relax and re-center my mind to cope with the pain signals.  I have taken it one time per day so far, usually two or three days per week, and the dosage does not seem to need adjustment.  Kratom does not seem a logical risk for a 'recreational drug' in any way because larger dosages seem to put me to sleep.  It may be prudent to control the availability or sale of concentrated preparations, but to eliminate the kratom option from chronic pain patients who have so few options is unnecessarily cruel and counterproductive. 

  I have been treated by neurologists, pain specialists, osteopaths, rheumatologists, physical therapists, counselors, chiropractors, and practice mindfullness, group therapy, individual therapy, and have tried all the forms of relief offered by all these professionals.  All the therapies are somewhat helpful, several can help to make the situation tolerable;  Kratom is an indispensable tool for attempting to live a normal life.

 I urge the research of possible new therapies as may be warranted in standard double blind medical research, but the profit potential seems limited for simple natural remedies and therefore big pharma seems uninterested.

documents.commentText:
I use kratom to control my ulcerative colitis and have for several years. I have had ulcerative colitis for 18 years and have tried a variety of prescription drugs including immunosuppressants and steroids to treat my disease. A few years ago a friend told me about kratom and the next time my disease flared I tried it. I was astonished at how well it worked. My disease went into remission in about 3 days of moderate kratom use - approximately 10 grams per day, divided into 2 or 3 doses. 

I then found that I could gradually taper down from that dose to a far smaller one and use it as a daily maintenance dose. Since doing so I find my disease kept very much at bay. When I do start experiencing a flare I take a higher dose of kratom which then reduces my intestinal motility and in a few days I recover. Then I taper down the dose again to a low maintenance level. 

There are no side effects of this medicinal use of kratom; it is remarkably inexpensive; and it seems far safer than the expensive and somewhat unpredictable cocktail of pharmaceutical medicines I was taking before. I think kratom has enormous medical utility for treating inflammatory bowel disease, and I understand that this was an indigenous use of this plant in Southeast Asia.

It is thus very important to me personally that kratom be kept legal and unregulated. It simply works better than anything else I have used for treating my disease. With kratom I am able to function normally; don't miss work; and am a more productive citizen. I suspect this is because of its strong anti-inflammatory properties and its ability to reduce motility without causing constipation or toxic megacolon.

Sincerely,
Jonathan Taylor, PhD

documents.commentText:
Public Submission concerning the proposed ban and classification of the natural plant Kratom. I would like to submit a statement based on how kratom changed my life perminantly and for the better.
 When I first tried kratom I had been a 12 pack a day drinker for 20+ years. I did not intend to quit drinking when two unrelated friends suggested that I try kratom. In fact, drinking wasn't even mentioned by either friend but I was hoping it could help me with my daily hangovers. They had both stated that it had been helping them with their moods for a long time and thought that I should give it a try. Because there was very little information out there 3 years ago I had a rough start. There is no overdosing with kratom because when it is over-consumed the human system ejects what is in the stomach. Once I was able to get the dosing down properly I was finding that I was becoming less and less interested in drinking. I had my routine down for the last 15 years where I would stop in to the liquor store that was right at the corner of my second bus transfer point and I would conveniently bring my daily 12 pack home from there. On the weekends or if I wasn't buzzed enough and wanted more alcohol on weekdays I would call and have it delivered. Where I was once left wanting more after drinking my 12 pack for the night, I was now finding that I still had beer left over from the night before. This was practically unheard of in the drinking pattern I had created over half of my life. Eventually, the same few beers just sat in my fridge until I was able to give then away to guests. Before it had gotten to that point however, I started fighting to keep my drinking lifestyle going. I began buying bottles of hard alcohol because it was quicker to get down with a much more condensed impact. Hard alcohol had never been something that I had a taste for up until then but I had lost my desire to sip beer all night. I could knock back almost an entire bottle myself and wake up still drunk the next day. I had enough common sense to know that wasn't going to work so I went back to the remaining beers that were still in my fridge. When those started getting warm and flat after I'd opened them I gave up on alcohol entirely. I gave it a good go, though. I really enjoyed drinking and listening to music while chatting online with friends. I tried my best to keep my drinking habit by my side.
It is now almost 3 years later and I am still going strong. I can drink whenever I want but I have completely lost the desire. The best part for me is that it was completely unintentional. I was a functioning alcoholic who had kept the same job for 15 years (18 years this year) with promotions and financial loyalty rewards etc. I am a server and my job is to take care of any and all customer needs. I was hungover every single day and made a game of it to get through each shift without having anxiety attacks. I called it "Muppet Time". Because of this continued success I had no intention of quitting. Kratom removed that desire slowly but surely. This was a lifestyle habit but with the wonderful mental state that kratom gave me I was able to effortlessly fill my time with projects and hobbies that I was unable to perform while intoxicated. The transition was painless. The big difference between using kratom to wean and NA or AA programs is that not only can I drink when I want then leave it behind without relapsing into binge drinking, I simply just do not desire alcohol in any way whatsoever. In my extensive experiences with friends and family members who have gone through NA and AA, they think about drugs and alcohol constantly. It is a life consuming struggle to stay clean and sober. As I have stated several times in this plea, drinking was a lifestyle for me my entire adult life and I was still able to thrive so when I looked back and found that I had completely quit binge drinking-and pretty much any kind of drinking, I was still surprised that I had really lost the desire to drink for good. Many people fail sober programs because abstinence and withdrawal are too much to battle every single minute of every single day with no reprieve. Not only does kratom gently ease the addict out with minimal impact or side effects, it also alleviates depression as well. Because of kratom I am successful in so many ways that would have been impossible if I were still an addict living under the oppressive thumb of alcoholism.
 If the public's best interest is the main concern here kratom will remain available to everyone who uses it for addiction alleviation, chronic pain, and mental health issues-to name just a very few of its incredibly effective uses. Please. Do not force dangerous synthetics on the American people by banning this very effective natural alternative to pharmaceuticals. Kratom Has The Potential To Save Lives.

 Thank you for taking the time to read my public submission to keep kratom legal in Minnesota.

Lynette Foxen

documents.commentText: I suffer from chronic back pain from scoliosis (a curvature of the spine) and kratom has helped relieve my pain without the use of more addictive and harmful forms of painkillers. It's side effects are virtually non-existent compared to opioids. I don't feel impaired when I take it and the only negative side effect I've personally experienced is constipation, which is laughable compared to the side effects of many pharmaceutical drugs. Adding kratom to any of the five drug schedules would do nothing but make criminals out of normal human beings looking for a healthy way to relieve pain or anxiety. Studies have already shown kratom's analgesic and anti-anxiety benefits to be true, but more research is still needed and making kratom illegal would make that research hard if not impossible to do. I would not at all be against keeping kratom legal and regulating it like tobacco and alcohol to ensure quality control. But criminalizing normal people looking for alternatives to opioids would do nothing but expand this country's failed war on drugs, which has cost us untold billions and is opposed by the vast majority of American citizens.

know someone off opiates and taking Kratom for pain management, and if they ran out, yes a bit irritable but not losing their
mind like heroin, etc. I live in Long Island,NY and when the prescription opiates access got totally tightened up heroin use
skyrocketed, even among teens and many overdoses. You really must think about this.....the heroin thing could get noticeably
worse. Kratom has some drawbacks, and I don't know how to possibly control the alkaloid thing. But also a lot of times a bunch of teenagers swallow half a bottle of whatever (ephedra then,Kratom now) and the substance is demonized. You

center etc. for this plant.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,  I am a recoving addict who has struggled with opioid addiction in the past, with very few available options for helping my recovery. I heard about kratom from a friend and decided to try it in an effort to keep from sliding back into full blown drug use. I tried the kratom, and it offered some small comfort from opioid withdrawal. The kratom didnt feel anything like an opiate, except that it did keep me from feeling the pain i normally would while in withdrawal. I only used opioids a couple of times since trying to get clean all together and mostly was able to just use  kratom when i was feeling sick or would relapse. I used kratom for about 6 weeks daily until i began to just feel normal again without using anything. It can be hard to find help for an addiction, and can be just as hard finding a way to pay for a program without insurance, or to follow arbitrary rules put in place by local human services. Kratom definetly afforded me with just enough of an effect to curb the worst parts of opiate withdrawal and for that i am grateful. I have currently been clean off of all drugs and no longer need to even use the kratom.  I would recommend the use of kratom to any addict, and think that everyone deserves to have a chance at beng clean.  This plant should be studied before making a drastic decision to ban it. There have been enough mistakes made in the past regarding banning medicines. let this be studied before jumping to an emotional decision to prohibit. 
Respectfully--Justin
