documents.commentText:
I am a mother, a wife, a public figure who works diligently with children. I have a Bachelors and a Masters Degree. I know what hard work and integrity is. I am clean and take kratom to manage pain, anxiety, and exhaustion. I am healthier than I have ever been in my life. Other than my yearly well-woman visits, I have not seen a doctor in over 3 years nor have been sick.  I take kratom like a vitamin regime for energy, mood boost, and pain. I work long hours bettering and brightening the future for children. And I am one of the best in my field.  I dont get high from kratom. I use it responsibly. I dont drink alcohol. I dont smoke cigarettes.  I am the Best Me I have ever been.  Kratom has saved my life. 

While the DEA statistics say that Kratom has killed 15 people in 2 years (although the people who have died had other substances in their system), cigarettes are responsible for 480,000 deaths a year (CDC, www.cdc.gov/tobacco/data_statistics/fact_sheets/fast_facts/)  . Alcohol is responsible for 88,000 a year and 2.5 million years of potential life lost (CDC, www.cdc.gov/alcohol/fact-sheets/alcohol-use.htm).  Approximately 185 accidently die each year from Tylenol yet it remains on the shelves for public consumption because the FDA stated the agency saw the benefits of keeping acetaminophen widely available as outweighing the relatively rare risk of liver damage or death (U.S. Center for Disease Control and Prevention Multiple Cause of Death Database).  Many, possibly hundreds, of prescriptions and over-the-counter medications that the FDA and DEA allow for use as relatively safe, have been the cause of more deaths and more overdoses in one year than decades of Kratom use.  Substances that the DEA and FDA know are dangerous such as alcohol and cigarettes continue to be a part of our mainstream repertoire of consumption, yet those remain legal and a staple in our culture. 

Kratom has saved the lives of thousands of people. My conservative family members are thankful for kratom and what it has done for me.  Thousands of people use kratom to abstain from the very things that are legal and harmful. That being said, kratom users are not all addicts getting clean from drugs that are illegal and legal. Many people use kratom as a healthy alternative to combating the effects of diseases, chronic pain, depression, and the list goes on and on. Their eyes are open to the harmful side effects of any prescription drugs that may be prescribed and they are choosing safer alternative methods such as kratom.  I strongly and diligently urge you to reconsider your position on kratom.

documents.commentText:
I have been a recovering alcoholic/addict of 16 years. Unfortunately, I have had 5 back surgeries also, which means I have had to go on and come off opiates several times in the last 20 years. 8 years ago, the Drs wanted to do ANOTHER back surgery and I refused. They said, "Let's get you on OxyContin.". My response was simple...I am an addict. "Don't worry, we will watch you.". Within 3 months, I went from 5 mg of Oxy to over 800 mg of Oxy and THE DR. prescribed this because of my "tolerance". Within another month or so, I was ready to take a drink and fade back into where I came from, but decided to go into in patient treatment.

For 3 days, I WAS IN HELL! Coming off opiates is literally hell on earth (body spasms, vomiting, diarrhea, psychosis, etc, etc). The "treatment" plan was to put me on Suboxone, which is an opiate that you can't get high on, but works on pain. On day 3, I was curled up in a ball in the commons area and a Dr walked in and said, "Get that man on Suboxone!". Within 5 minutes, I had a tab of Suboxone under my tongue and within minutes, I was normal!

Fast forward 7 YEARS LATER and still on the drug. Last month, we switched insurances and it was an ACT OF GOD to try and get the Suboxone covered. I had 30 pills left and decided to ween myself off by reducing by 25% every 4 days. Well, I did that, and for 9 DAYS after my last crumble of Suboxone and the inevitable happened, SAME EXACT WITHDRAWALS...hell on earth.

4 days ago, I went to Sprouts to find something to help me with energy as I was literally exhausted. I own 3 businesses and need to be able to work. The man behind the counter, after telling him what was going on, said, "Have you ever heard of Kratom?". He explained that people use it for pain and for opiate withdrawal. Luckily, he had some with him and gave me a teaspoon of it. MY LIFE SEEPED BACK INTO ME!

For the last 4 days, I have been using small doses to treat pain and the withdrawals and it literally works like a charm.

I am a successful business man and have a wonderful family. Point being, I am NOT some whacked out addict trying to get high. I am trying to treat medicinal situations with a natural herb and not this GOD DAMN crap they dole out to us like candy.

Enough is enough, quit letting BIG PHARMA control our freedom to choose!

Call me if you have any questions!

Benjamin A Mueller

documents.commentText:
My wife has suffered with chronic pain for almost 25 years.  Her ailments were from Fibromyalsia, and spinal issues both at her neck, and lower back.  Through the years, she has spent most of her non work hours in bed.  Her doctors have tried many different drug therapies to give her a quality of life.  The side effects where not pleasant.  Her personality changed, she became highly volatile and angry at times.  Other times she was like she was dopped up and slurred her speech when she was awake.  Much of the time she slept.  Approximately 12 years ago, she could not work any longer, and became housebound.  I did all the shopping, yard and house work, prepared simple meals, and made excuses for her not being able to socialize with our friends.  She treated me poorly and disrespectfully.  Talked over me when visitors stopped by.  Became rude to me and was very difficult to live with.  Our children moved out when they became adults, and kept away from her to avoid her highly volatile mood swings.

2 years ago, she discovered Kratom, and began taking it regularly.  She has eliminated all her prescription drugs, has her personality back, interfaces well with friends and society.  Her thinking is clear, pain is virtually gone, and a quality of life has returned to her and our family.  She suffers no side affects to the herb, and is frightened at the prospect that Kratom would be outlawed by scheduling it as a hard narcotic.  I fear that if she loses access to it and must go back on prescription drug therapy, I will not be able to tolerate living with her, and our family unit will be destroyed.

I respectfully submit that banning Kratom would be a serious mistake and would negatively impact our quality of life.

documents.commentText:
Dear Drug Enforcement Agency

Im a twenty-five year old man from Colorado and Im writing to let you know how Kratom has improved my life and allowed me to become a functional member of society. 

Recently your agency has announced their intent to schedule Kratom (Mitrygina Speciosa) as a schedule 1 controlled substance. This herbal supplement taken by tens of thousands of people with arthritis, back and knee pain, Major Depression, Restless Leg Syndrome, and a multitude of other ailments has helped improve the lives of individuals all across our nation. This supplement has helped thousands overcome their opiate addiction and its about to be placed in the same category as heroin effectively turning people with physical and mental ailments into felons. The banning of Kratom will prevent further research as to the medicinal benefits, which, to date, have shown that Kratom is, in fact, very helpful to the afore- mentioned physical and psychological conditions. 

I first heard of Kratom when I was looking for a natural way to help with Major Depression and Restless Leg Syndrome. I have been to the hospital multiple times in my life and I do not want to turn to even more prescriptions.  I was doing research online and came across a website that contained the testimonials of people that were taking this supplement. To this day I take two medications for my depression and work closely with counselors and doctors every week to manage my conditions. Kratom has allowed me to function on a level that is closer to what people would call normal. I have used it to help treat my condition along with prescriptions. Because of Kratom I dont feel lethargic and chronically fatigued every day. Because of Kratom I can sleep at night because my Restless Leg Syndrome is completely abolished by drinking this tea. Because of Kratom I can work and soon I will be returning to my Jiu-jitsu classes. Because of Kratom I can laugh with my father again. That is if I dont become a felon for taking it. 

Kratom is a safe alternative to pharmaceutical drugs that contain deadly side effects. Sometimes prescriptions are unavoidable, but if I can drink some tea and avoid some of the serious side effects of prescriptions I would much rather do that. I already manage the side effects of prescriptions and Kratom has helped to treat those side effects. It contains more than one medicinal use and has greatly improved my livelihood. I fear that this action from your agency will lead to an increase in deaths from prescription opiates and heroin. I fear that this will be another failed attempt at the war on drugs and people will become criminals for trying to cure their health issues without taking a pharmaceutical drug. I know that I will not be able to function the same and be a productive member of society without it. It truly has improved my medical conditions.

If you have any questions about Kratom, please visit, www.americankratom.org I also strongly encourage you to watch what this veteran has to say about the matter. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7VwKcTH2nik
Thank you for your time. Thank you for reading.

Sincerely, 

David Perrone

Most of the prescription drugs I have been prescribed do not work as intended or cause too many unpleasant side effects. When I feel a migraine coming on, I take 3-4 grams of Kratom and it usually prevents the headache from being too painful. Instead, I am able to stay productive at work or enjoy whatever plans I have for the day.

Before trying Kratom, I did hours worth of research and decided I was willing to undertake the risks associated with a somewhat unknown substance. To this day, I have noticed no ill effects from taking this "drug." Although I cannot alone confirm its safety for all people, I has had a positive impact on my life without causing any noticeable problems for me. Thus, I believe it would be wise to allow this substance to be distributed legally until there is a strong reason to doubt its safety. After all, we live in a supposedly free country.

Thank you for taking the time to read my comment.

documents.commentText:
Firstly, I'd like to state that I am strongly opposed to the DEA's intent to place Kratom on the list of Schedule 1 substances. Actually, because of my own personal experience with Kratom, and the overwhelming benefits I received from it, I am completely against any scheduling of Kratom, as this would undoubtedly restrict its access to people that could potentially benefit from it just as I did.

I discovered Kratom about 6-7 months ago during a desperate attempt to regain control of my life, after researching its potential ability at assisting people struggling with opiate addiction. Opiate addiction, something I have been battling since the age of 19, which developed very rapidly after a 14-day stay in the hospital, in which the strong pain killer Dilaudid was administered IV every 3 hours for the entire duration (that being my very first experience with Opiates), while also taking home a 30-day supply of Percocet (Oxycodone), and was ultimately diagnosed with Crohn's disease. The speed in which the Opiates took hold and an addiction began was incredible. It began controlling every aspect of my life, and without any Opiates, I had no life, except that of suffering beyond measure, the notorious Opiate withdrawal. After about two years of that, I decided I needed to make a real effort to get clean, because my life was beginning to become completely unmanageable due my addiction. I heard about the drug Suboxone, a relatively new drug at the time, which apparently was having reasonably good success in treating Opiate addiction, so I jumped at the chance to begin Suboxone therapy when the opportunity presented itself. At first, it was amazing, with Suboxone I finally felt like I did before my addiction, but of course, there was an enormous catch.

Suboxone, the brand name of the drug used to treat Opiate addiction and withdrawal is made up of 75-80% Buprenorphine, which itself is a partial Opiate receptor agonist giving it its ability to ease withdrawal symptom and cravings. Of course, this means that I would become physically dependent on it, just as I was with Oxycodone and heroin, but now instead of calling my dealer, I called my doctor. I would literally walk into his house, hand him $250 cash in exchange for my script. No counseling at all, and most of the time he didn't even ask how things have been going addiction wise. So I'm sure you can guess, my life was still completely dictated by drugs, except the only difference this time was I was receiving it legally. After being on Suboxone for 2+ years, I decided being a slave to the drug needed to end. The withdrawal from Suboxone was beyond intense, and not just that, the withdrawal period was much longer lasting than heroin or Oxycodone. This was due to the half-life of Buprenorphine, which is anywhere from 24-42 hours. I ended up in the psych-ward due to not sleeping for over 17 days during my withdrawal from Suboxone, an experience I will never forget. I did however, finally get off Suboxone, but my addiction was far from over. 

Unfortunately, the battle to get through the acute withdrawal is the easy part, the hard part is staying clean. Admittedly, I have been failing at this for the past 5-6 years. I would have brief periods of time in which I was clean which never lasted, I always ended up using again, which of course, negatively affected the quality of my life substantially. I first heard of Kratom a couple years ago, after researching legal remedies for Opiate addiction, but I never took it seriously (I wish I would have) which ended up being a mistake on my part. 

As stated in the beginning, it was my desperation that compelled me to give it a try, as I had nothing to lose after nearly losing 10 years of my life to the relentless addiction. When I received my Kratom, I followed an easy recipe online to prepare it as a tea, and the day I drank the most disgusting flavored tea I've ever tasted, was the day I finally recaptured my life. Since then, which as I stated earlier was about 6 or 7 months ago, I have been able to stay off Opiates, which is now the longest stretch of time that I've been clean in the past 10 years. The most amazing part is; I have actually gotten to the point that I don't even use/need Kratom every day. The changes in my life, as I'm sure you can imagine, have been significant and drastic in amazing ways, and I am never looking back. 

So I'm asking you to please fully appreciate, and consider, the real life implications that any Scheduling of Kratom would have on a countless number of people throughout this country.

Thank you for your time,
Chris

documents.commentText:
Hi, I am a 21 year old c-level executive of a small national nonprofit. Before I get started, I'd like to thank the DEA for opening up the scheduling process to public comment.

I oppose the DEA putting Kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances, or any other illicit drug lists. I have severe chronic lower back pain, and Kratom has helped me manage it for years. My chronic pain causes me moderate anxiety, and Kratom improves my mood. Kratom significantly increases my quality of life as a chronic pain sufferer, and if it is banned, my quality of life would significantly decrease.

I started using Kratom 2 years ago after my doctor told me that I had no remaining options for my chronic back pain. I ordered some online, and ingest it by mixing Kratom powder with water - a Kratom drink. This is the only way in which I consume Kratom.

Within minutes of ingesting Kratom, I experience mild pain relief as well as mild anxiety relief, and I also experience increased energy about the same strength as a cup of coffee.

I use Kratom to go about my day as a productive member of society. I do not use it recreationally. Kratom has limited recreational potential - it simply lacks the intensity to be so. Like I said, it is about as strong as a cup of coffee, there isn't enough there to get 'high' off of. Contrast this with heroin. Kratom is not an opiate, it is a natural herb with 'opiate-like effects', and the body does not respond to Kratom and traditional morphine-based opiates in the same fashion. If Kratom was anything like heroin, it would have seen instant popularity and received national recognition and prohibition a decade ago. Instead, Kratom has been sold in mostly obscurity for decades, and the majority of people (51%) who use it, use it for managing pain. https://www.painnewsnetwork.org/stories/2016/9/18/kratom-users-say-ban-will-lead-to-more-drug-abuse

Banning Kratom is going to make the opiate epidemic in our country explode too. This problem is out of control. 78 people die of opiate overdoses every single day (46 from prescription painkillers). 3 die an hour. Over 6 in 10 drug overdose deaths involve opiates. 50% of them are from prescription opiate drugs (far more than heroin). 2016 statistics: www.asam.org/docs/default-source/advocacy/opioid-addiction-disease-facts-figures.pdf

Kratom has no confirmed deaths as a standalone. However, it can be a helpful opiate alternative that can save lives. Current and former addicts rely on Kratom to prevent relapse and will be forced to seek out more dangerous drugs if Kratom is banned.

Take Alabama for example. In May 2016, Alabama banned Kratom without public comment. In June 2016, heroin overdoses statewide DOUBLED over the average of previous months. April 2016: 47 deaths. May 2016: 56 deaths. June 2016: 101 deaths. 

For an examination of Alabama: www.gll-getalife.com/Are%20Rising%20Overdoses%20in%20Birmingham%20a%20Result%20of%20Kratom%20Ban

Kratom education and use should be treated as a safe alternative to opioids, NOT prohibited.

As a chronic pain sufferer, banning Kratom will have a significantly negative impact on my ability to go about my day normally. As a concerned citizen over the opioid epidemic in America, I know that banning Kratom will increase overdoses and only make the opioid epidemic worse. Kratom should be readily available - it is safe and effective.

documents.commentText:
I am 51 year old single mother in Cleveland, Ohio. I have herniated discs in my neck and back from a car accident in 1992.  I also have scoliosis in which the curve pushes on the herniated discs in my back causing almost continuous pain.  In 1998 I was diagnosed with Lupus and Rheumatoid Arthritis.  I also have a bad knee from a sports injury as a teenager needing yet more surgery.  I have arthritis in my neck and in my large toe so bad it no longer bends.  I will always be on Plaquenil to keep my lupus under control as much as possible as sadly there is no cure for lupus.  For pain I have been on Corticosteroids (steroids like prednisone), anti-inflammatory drugs (Naprosyn or ibuprofen), pain meds (Vicodin, Vicoprofen or Percocet), muscle relaxers (Flexeril) and sleep meds (Lunesta or Ambien and/or trazodone) for many years. While the pain meds helped at first it never completely handled all the issue plus it came with side effects. I refused to take any RA biologics (like Enbrel or Humira) or cancer drugs (methotrexate) which are the only options for arthritic pain. In September of 2010 I was laid off from my job of 10.5 years.  My insurance would be ending at the end of the month and Cobra was not a viable option being on unemployment I could no longer afford to go to the pain doctor. I struggled daily and continued to use only ibuprofen for pain. I was miserable and spent the majority of my time either in bed or on the couch. Most people know people with lupus are in pain but another thing you battle is extreme exhaustion; 24/7/365 non-stop exhaustion.

In June of 2012 a friend of mine brought over some all natural pain medicine she got from a chiropractor.  This friend was in a horrific car accident and deals with lots of pain daily.  Nothing had really helped her but this did and therefore she wanted me to try it.  She had gelatin capsules filled with Mitragyna Speciosa better known as kratom.  I tried the (capsules) to humor her. I was expecting nothing but I was amazed! My back did not hurt. My neck did not hurt. My toe did not hurt. I also noticed I had more energy. With kratom I was able to do basic chores for more than 10 minutes at a time.  I ordered myself some of the capsules and that was the beginning of my kratom 

I started to do more and more research on kratom.  I read lots of great things about people who took it for various reasons; chronic pain, energy, MS, RLS, depression, diarrhea, insomnia, diabetes and opiate withdrawal.  I joined groups and forums to talk to others using this wonderful plant. I learned about the different strains that offer different results.  Some are more stimulating, others more relaxing.  I read anything I could find on kratom be it good or bad.  Throughout reading the information a pattern became obvious.  People who were taking kratom said wonderful things about it. Things like how much it has helped them and changed their quality of life. However, the FDA and mainstream media say something completely different.  I would like to say that they are some inaccuracies but that would be an understatement.  Fallacies would be the correct term. Here are some examples.

Kratom gives you heroin like high.
FALSE. You do not get high from kratom.

Kratom is dangerous and you can overdose.
FALSE. You cannot overdose on kratom. If you take too much kratom you will get nauseous. If you really take too much you will throw it up.

Kratom is highly addictive and you will go into withdrawal without it.
FALSE. Ive used it on and off for over four years and I have never had any withdrawal symptoms. 

What you WILL notice when you stop taking it is how much it was helping you.  As for side effects, the only one I have ever had is some constipation. To alleviate that you need to drink lots of water and eat fruits and veggies. All things we should be doing anyway.

Most days I have my pain level is low.  I have energy again.  I am able to do chores, go grocery shopping and even some light yard work.  At night I am able to relax and sleep without pain and without drugs. My blood work is the best it's ever been. My rheumatologist (at the Cleveland Clinic) is aware I use kratom & turmeric and is amazed at how well Im doing.  Someone recently asked me to describe my life with kratom.  I said with kratom I feel normal again.  I am able to participate in my life instead of watching it go by.  What an amazing feeling that is.  I was even able to go back to work which I never thought possible.  If I lose kratom my life will again consist of me either in bed or on the couch. THAT is not a life.  I can't believe the DEA wants to force me back onto opiates (and other meds) when this plant works better.  Where is the logic?

I have had chronic pain ever since I can remember. Having kratom tea has been a godsend.

I have used the same amount of kratom daily for about 5 years. I do not increase the amount, nor do I have any desire to. This is not a recreational substance to me, I don't even consider it a drug, and I have never been a recreational drug user. Just like coffee, it is something that helps me get through the day. Unlike traditional prescription pain drugs (opiates), kratom is self-regulating in its dosage. I have never felt I needed more than my typical daily kratom tea (about a gram a day or less).  Some days I even forget and don't even think about it!  In the past, on harder days with prescriptions, I have had to take more pain meds to ease pain. I have not had any work related decline in productivity--in fact it has helped me be more productive and focused throughout the day, where before I either was too drowsy or too much in pain to focus on my work. 

Moving Kratom from a supplement to a Sched. 1 substance will force some people to start using opiates. Opiates like vicodin/percocet can be lethal.  Pain pills are addictive and dangerous. The danger is known and well documented. My grandma recently passed away partly because of morphine and the respiratory depression that it causes. I wish she had found kratom instead, I feel like she would still be alive if so. Pain pills cause respiratory failure and that truly scares me. Kratom does not have that side effect. 


Please do not change the legal status & scheduling of this substance on the federal level. Its legality should not be changed. States should be able to decide this, and it should be a decision put to voters to decide if there is enough opposition to it in their state. I applauded the DEA's push to make "research chemicals" illegal so quickly, there were some truly dangerous substances on the streets.  But this is not the same thing.  Please listen to us. Kratom has been used for centuries all over the world, and no documented deaths have occurred due to Kratom alone. This alone should warrant more careful consideration. 


Thank you for your time, and listening to us.

documents.commentText:
In 2001 my now 40 year old daughter was critically injured when she was run down on a Boston sidewalk by an out of control SUV. Although she survived - bearly- she spent the next  7 years in and out of Massachusetts General Hospital. Multiple surgeries and installation and removal of hardware left her with permanent, unresolvable physical issues and was told that she would be in pain for the rest of her life. She has been under the care of a pain clinic and has faithfully followed the advice and direction of her very qualified, very compassionate doctor, but there is very little he has been able to do to make her pain and her life bearable. This constant agony prevents her from having any quality of life. She cannot sleep, stay in any position for any length of time. She is exhausted and do to lack of sleep is depressed. She can't participate in life. Can't sit in the car for very long, so she rarely goes out and when she does, the effort to deal with the pain of moving is not worth leaving her home. This leads to isolation which contributes to the depression. It is a vicious cycle with no relief ever. I don't know how she does it and am frequently afraid that she will end it all, due to the fact that there is no hope. She hates the side effects of pain meds which provide her with minimal relief but are her only option.
Then along comes her discovery of Kratom, which has changed her life. It helps her pain so she can sleep. She can move, she can leave her home and participate in life. Her mood is elevated and she is upbeat and hopeful for the first time in 15 years. She can play with her 4 year old, whereas before it was too painful for her to sit him in her lap! She is smiling and laughing again. Kratom has also changed my life as well. I have my daughter back! I don't worry all the time and spend countless sleepless nights trying to figure out a way to help her. I have prayed for a miracle for many years. I had no idea it would come in this form, but we will take it. I hope and pray she continues to have access to this life changing miracle. I am afraid to think of what would happen to her if she no longer was able to get it. I also hope that it does not become unaffordable. She is so young and has her whole life ahead of her, but without the Kratom has no quality of life and no hope.No human being should have to live with what feels like and unbearable sentence when there is relief available. I thank God for this discovery and hope and pray that she continues to have access to Kratom. Now that she knows and remembers what it feels like to live again, I know she will not go back to the life - or lack thereof-  before Kratom. Please keep Kratom available and affordable to the countless people like my daughter, whose lives it has saved. Thank you

documents.commentText: I suffer from diabetic peripheral neuropathy.  At times the pain can be unbearably intense.  Imagine having someone dump a gallon of gasoline on you and then toss on a match. This is the best description of how this feels that I can come up with.  My symptoms are mostly managed with a combination of pregabalin and nortriptyline.  This works about six days out of the week but about once a week I get a pain flare up where these drugs fail.  These drugs provide satisfactory control of pain for only 10% of the people with this disease.  I suffered horribly for several months until I opted to give kratom a try.  It has been a godsend.  It totally relieves my pain without causing drowsiness, anxiety, or any sense of being high.  I can manage my business and get my work done.  Kratom is inherently safe because long before you could approach the point where you are going to feel significant respiratory depression, it causes nausea and vomiting and is self-limiting in that respect.  This may not be true of extracts and I would agree with a ban on concentrated extracts specifically because this self-limiting mechanism would not be present with extracts.  If you ban kratom it will result in many more deaths as people turn to strong opiates for relief or give up and commit suicide.  Before finding kratom I was considering both of these options.  As for it's addictive qualities, I have never felt either a craving for it nor have I experienced any withdrawal symptoms between periods when I use it (typically 7-14 days).  The deaths on record involving this substance have always involved co-administration with other more powerful drugs, usually opiates.  Often this is because an opioid addict is trying to use kratom to reduce their withdrawal symptoms and then gives up and reverts to using opiates.  Kratom is not to blame for these deaths, on the contrary, many opiate addicts have successfully gotten off their habit by using kratom to dull their withdrawal symptoms.  Banning this substance will both leave people with chronic nerve pain like myself with no legitimate and safe option and it also will take one tool away from opiate addicts trying to kick their habits.

documents.commentText:
I write today in opposition to the proposed rule intended to schedule the components of Kratom and propose that Kratom remain unscheduled.

I urge the DEA to consider that by scheduling this drug, it will create a public health crisis.  As best as my research can uncover, there are hundreds of thousands of Kratom users in this country, and I see three primary use cases:

1) To treat chronic pain,
2) To treat anxiety, and
3) To assist in the discontinuance of opiate use for those with an addiction or dependency.

If Kratom is no longer available, the DEA should not expect that these users will no longer treat their issues, but instead will find alternative means.  Unfortunately, these alternatives are far more dangerous.  Users in groups 1 and 3 will return to opioids, while users in group 2 will return to benzodizepines.  As the DEA is keenly aware, opioids are the #1 cause of death among drug users in this country, and benzodiazepines are regarded by many as one of the most addictive substances in the world.  Quite bluntly, if the DEA reduces the availablity of Kratom, it will increase the demand for heroin, oxycodone, and Xanax.

Respectfully, I understand why the DEA may have concerns regarding the potential for abuse of Kratom.  However, despite Kratom being popular, legal, and incredibly inexpensive in this country for many years, reports of Kratom abuse are minimal.  While a world in which no one is in pain or has anxiety that they need to treat would be wonderful, we are not in that world at the moment, and we should allow people to use natural remedies that have proved to be vastly safer than virtually any of the prescription pills -- or illegal narcotics -- that treat the same.  

As *any* scheduling of Kratom will result in a de facto ban, since the plant is not patentable and therefore no drug manufacturer will invest in the research required to market Kratom as a drug, the prudent course of action is to leave this plant as-is unless and until the DEA has solid evidence that the public heath faces greater risk because of Kratom's legality than it would if Kratom were banned and its users returned to opioids and benzodiazepines.

Thank you,

Jonathan Corbett

"Jon Corbett is a civil rights advocate known for filing the first lawsuit against the deployment of TSA nude body scanners, as well as defeating the body scanners live in 'How to Get ANYTHING Through TSA Nude Body Scanners.'  Presently a law student, he continues to advocate for travel and privacy rights, as well as Second Amendment rights.  Twitter: @_JonCorbett, Web: http://professional-troublemaker.com/"

documents.commentText:
I work as a registered nurse (RN) in a high-volume hospital emergency department in the western United States. As a front line healthcare worker in this setting I experience, on a nightly basis, the public and personal harm caused by our country's precarious relationship with opioid pain medications. We need help. I am writing this comment to express my grave concern with the recent DEA decision to place kratom and its opioid alkaloids on the schedule I substance list.

I first became aware of kratom through the experience of a friend, who consumes the plant to help treat intractable pain caused by advanced neuropathy. I consider it both a personal and professional duty to help my loved ones understand the benefits and risks of any substance they put into their body, the same as I do for the patients I treat. Kratom is a plant with obvious benefits and risks to the public, and a thorough investigation of its pharmacological qualities is quite warranted.

After even a cursory review of existing research and anecdotal evidence, it is clear to me that placing kratom into the schedule I category is premature, highly misguided, and a blatant abuse of DEA authority.

Kratom does demonstrate obvious benefits and risks. Clearly, it is effective in pain management in many people. It also demonstrates immense potential as an alternative to pharmaceutical opioids in those patients who suffer from physical dependency to these medications. Based on anecdotal data, kratom also appears to exhibit the potential for anxiolytic and antidepressant treatment as well.

As with any opioid, the risks of kratom appear to include potential for abuse, mild constipation, and impaired judgment or coordination. There is absolutely zero evidence to support the DEA assertion that kratom contributes to the severe and dangerous side effects of respiratory depression or sudden death. I find it highly irresponsible of the DEA to make such claims.

The pharmacological qualities of kratom warrant further research. Scheduling this plant would effectively halt these efforts, and stands in antithesis to the DEA's aims at harm-reduction and evidence-based policy.

Our country is losing its battle against the chronic use and abuse of oxycodone, hydrocodone, fentanyl, and other opioid pain medications. My heart is broken on a nightly basis observing the direct and collateral damage of this war on patients, families, and communities. Kratom is an immensely promising plant that can assist in this struggleplease do not destroy this tool before we have even began to explore its use.

I implore the DEA to allow further examination of this plant in the medical and scientific communities where its management belongs. Any further abuses of the DEA's scheduling authority will only inflict further direct harm on our country. Prohibition is a failed model and a waste of public resources.

Thank you for considering this comment.

I am 57 years old.  I owned a business for 29 years; I just started a new business to serve the elderly and disabled.   I am a husband, father of four children, and am an ordained minister.   I can still work because Kratom is helping me live a normal life!  Despite having suffered from severe back pain due to bulging disks (and surgery) as the result of a car accident, spinal stenosis, Fibromyalgia and Sjogrens Syndrome, Kratom has helped with each of those ailments so that I can function normally. Before using Kratom, the only relief medicine could supply for me was Oxycodone, and surgery, neither of which solved my problems.  A pain management doctor suggested that we try a spinal cord stimulator to see if it will help.  We had come to the point of just guessing at what might work.

I do not need to guess at what might work; I know what works, Kratom.  The most relief I have had is from Kratom. I do not wish to lose that ability over misconceptions and incorrect information.

Since using kratom, I no longer need Oxycodone for pain.  Sjogren's and fibromyalgia are much more manageable. While I do still take Plaquenil and Lyrica for Sjogren's and fibromyalgia respectively, I can function with no other prescription medication except Lisinopril (for high blood pressure).

Kratom does not get me high and never has.  I am not looking for a high.  People I have come to know who use kratom do not want to get high either.  I have never heard anyone say he or she have gotten high from Kratom.  There are no reports that I have found where Kratom alone has led to death.  Can any prescription medication for pain make that claim?
Lets not demonize a safe alternative to narcotics that helps countless people every day.  Kratom is a legitimate product that is doing a tremendous amount of good for many people.  Please do not ban Kratom.

If Kratom is banned, I will have no option but to go back to pain management doctors, prescription medications including narcotics, and trying to guess at what is going to work for me.  I have long felt that without Kratom I would be unemployed.  I would not be able to put the work into my business that I do now unless I started taking more and more pain medication.  That was the trend that I saw when I was on pain medication.  I constantly had to increase the dosage to manage pain.  I have not experienced that with Kratom.  I am still taking the same dosage at the same intervals that I found worked for me three years ago.

This comment in reference to Docket No. DEA-442W in your comment and submit.  Thank you.

documents.commentText: I am writing in support of the movement to maintain the legal status of Kratom. From a personal viewpoint, it has given my son his life back. documents.commentText:
To whomever it may concern at the DEA:

I have tremendous respect for the DEA and the important work that you do, and I understand the need for caution and scrutiny of any new substance, herbal or otherwise.  However, banning kratom in the United States is not necessary and would end up being counterproductive for public safety.

I am a third year medical student, father of one, and ex college-football player with chronic neck and shoulder pain.  Before switching to kratom, I relied on prescriptions for tramadol, hydrocodone and ibuprofen to manage my pain, and the side-effects eventually became worse than the pain.  These were constipation, mental confusion, drowsiness and driving impairment.  Further, I experienced horrible withdrawal whenever I stopped taking these drugs.  

After switching to kratom, I never had any of these problems again.  The pain relief is more mild than the pharmaceuticals, but the drastic reduction in side-effects made it well worth the trade-off.  

During the thousands of years of kratom use in Asia, nobody has ever died from or gotten sick from its use.  It is illegal in Thailand only because the government there did not want it to interfere with the country's opium trade.  Similar legislation here would protect the vastly-more-dangerous narcotic prescription sales, but it would also cost the public money and lives if current kratom users were forced to switch back to narcotics.  Kratom causes no illness and cannot cause fatal overdose, nor does it have much potential for abuse and addiction due to its mildness.  It is a safe and effective herb, so please do not make it illegal in the USA.

I sincerely thank you for your time and consideration.

Bernard Lischer
St. Joseph, MI

documents.commentText:
I am a Board Certified pain specialist with 30 years experience. 

By far the majority of pain sufferers in the US who use pain medications in order to allow adequate daily function, do so responsibly. Sooner or later, most will exhaust all reasonable other treatments (surgery, therapy, exercise, OTC meds and other pain substitutes.) Without a real pain medicine to take the incessant edge off pain, most think twice about getting up from a chair to do their daily routine. Leading to obesity, deconditioning and worsening of discomfort. 

The elderly (>50 yrs), which are becoming a majority of the population,  do not have the problem of "tolerance" to opiates (unless they have a pre-existing drug issue) and can stay on a modest dose to remain functional virtually forever. Able to live more productive, better lives and won't tend to seek more aggressive and expensive treatments.

Yet, DEA and other regulatory agencies has created such onerous conditions on medical practitioner's ability to prescribe pain medications, with no reimbursement for the extra work required, that their response is to make this effective treatment unavailable. 

Kratom regulation is another example of withdrawing a potentially useful treatment for pain. In countries where it has been widely and easily available for centuries does not seem to have an issue with its prevalent use. Wide-spread public testing of Kratom's efficacy and safety has already been been done in these countries. To criminalize this and legalize marijuana is nonsense. If and until it proves to be a problem, leave Kratom uncontrolled.

Jan P Maddox, MD
Blue Jay, CA

documents.commentText: I oppose the DEA's intention to make kratom and it's alkoloids a schedule 1 illegal drug. This would be a step backwards in progress. First off I'm a graphic designer and I sit at a desk all day which can lead to back pain quite often. I heard about kratom from a friend who said it was a good substitute for prescription pain killers. I gave it a try and had great results! The pain reduction was amazing and I didn't have to go to a doctor to get a prescription. It didn't give me nausea like hydrocodone did. It gave me a mild sense of euphoria, an elevated mood, and a reduction in pain. I have seen people become slightly dependent on it but I've personally witnessed waaaaaay worse addiction/dependency from drugs like hydrocodone and oxicontin. The thing about kratom it has similar effects of these LEGAL  prescription drugs but milder and without the liver damage and less addictive. People who quit prescription pain killers have very bad side effects. When I took kratom for a month straight and quit cold turkey the only side effect I perceived was restless leg syndrome for about 6 hours. That was it! I think it is irresponsible for the government to simply outlaw a medicinal plant that is more effective than LEGAL prescription drugs we have. Kratom in my opinion has very benign side effects when compared to hydrocodone and a much smaller dependency/addiction rate. It simply does not make sense. The government should protect its citizens and it seems this legal action would do the oppsosite. Alchol is the worlds most addictive drug and has taken more lives than any other. It also happens to be legal because the government recognizes that he majority of the population can use it responsibly. On the spectrum kratom is much less damaging than alcohol.

documents.commentText:
As a 36 year old certified pharmacy technician who has done extensive work in the pharmacy field, I have seen firsthand the devastation and destruction that drug addiction can wreak on lives.

I have also personally witnessed the profound relief that kratom can offer to ease PAWS in those suffering from addiction, and how beneficial kratom can be to help sustain the path to recovery.

Do I consider kratom to necessarily be a treatment or cure for any disease? No. 

However by restricting this herb to schedule 1 classification, I believe you are causing much more harm than good.

Do not banish this herb to schedule 1 restriction, DEA. Let us be able to freely continue our research, and let the people continue to exercise their right to ingest a simple tea leaf if they so desire! Please.

Thank you for this opportunity to let our voices be heard.

Jessica R. Moran 
CphT

Hello,  and thank you for the opportunity to voice my oppion today about kratom. I believe strongly that kratom is an incredibly helpful plant and supplements and the loss of it would be a devastation to 1000s ( at least). I am a 29 year old women working in the health care field and living with chronic pain. Pain that dramatically hinders my quality of life. I choose to live my life without the use of narcotic pain medications, as they can be addictive and damaging as I have seen first hand in my personal and professional life.  I choose instead to take care of my body the best I can by exercising regularly and trying my best to make healthy and beneficial choices whenever I can. I have tried many herbal, vitamin,  and natural tools in my pursuit of wellness , including kratom. To say kratom was helpful doesn't seem like enough.  To say this supplement improved my quality of life, would still be selling it short. But both are abundantly true.  Thank you for not making a decision lightly that has such high ramifications for the wellness of so many.  Your willingness to hear those who wish to speak out on this matter is a wonderful step  towards a brighter future, and I believe has strengthened the bond and the trust you share with the people.  Thank you sincerely for taking the time out of your day to read my and countless others comments. 

Sincerely,  Allison Burwell

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA,

I am a recovering addict.  After breaking my back in three places 12 years ago, I first entered the world of prescription narcotics.  My doctors prescribed me Vicodin and Percocet, and for a few years, I was able to somewhat mitigate my back pain by taking a pill or two 3-6 times a day.  All the while, my body kept on needing more and more medication in order for me to receive the same level of pain relief; this is a standard case of opioid tolerance.  After a few years, my tolerance soon skyrocketed out of control.  I began running out of my legal prescriptions early, ended up becoming noncompliant with my pain management contracts, and was left out in the cold by my doctors.  I turned to heroin to relieve my pain, and I lost everything.  My family, my career, my money-- all gone in an instant. 

I figured that there had to be a better way.  I went to an intensive rehab program, where I was put on Suboxone to mitigate my withdrawal symptoms.  After I stabilized on my dose of Suboxone and completed my rehab program, I began to get my life back together.  I ultimately got myself back on track, on the suboxone, while still in an immense amount of back pain.  A couple years went by, and I found myself unable to get off of the Suboxone.  I was as dependent on it as I was the heroin and prescription opioids.  

Kratom was a true lifesaver for me when I found it three years ago.  Not only did it allow me to get off of Suboxone without the horrible withdrawal symptoms, it ACTUALLY ALLEVIATED MY PAIN and allowed me to resume a somewhat normal level of activity!  It is an amazing plant, with a HUGE potential for medicinal uses.  Please don't ban this plant-- please dedicate federal funds to researching the potential medical/medicinal uses for this plant.  The terrible opioid epidemic in this country could be greatly mitigated by the proper use of this plant, and federal research is needed for this to happen.

documents.commentText:
Greetings,

I am a Board Certified Psychiatrist and Child Psychiatrist.  I have met hundreds of patients over the years who have benefitted from Kratom, and without any identifiable adverse effects.  For many of them, it saved them from taking prescription opioids and/or KEPT THEM WORKING AND OFF OF DISABILITY.  The usual user in my experience is a person with chronic debilitating illness, for whom there are limited options.  I have completed a systematic review of the scientific evidence in PubMed, the primary medical database, and there are no harmful effects identified through any scientific process.  On the contrary, there is a significant body of evidence supporting the clinical utility of Kratom in regards to chronic pain.  If the DEA feels some regulation is required, I would recommend considering age limits or only banning the extracts.  Theoretically, concentrated extracts could pose more risk than raw herb.  There are multiple researchers actively investigating the efficacy and safety of Kratom; banning its use would effectively halt that research.  Please please reconsider this ban.  It will adversely effect tens of thousands of individual patients with chronic illness.

Sincerely,

Jeffrey S Bradley MD MA

documents.commentText: I am a daily kratom user and have also introduced kratom to dozens of veterans with PTSD, Chronic pain sufferers, now ex-Opiate addicts and others from all walks of life and disease states. Kratom has been safely used in the Southeast Asia and Thailand regions for thousands of years, and it has been safely used by every human i've ever witnessed interact with it. Kratom has the potential of treating anxiety disorders, GI disorders, IBS, Crohn's, PTSD, Depression, CFS, and many other plaguing disorders or the central nervous system and digestive tract. There are NO substantial dangers to Mitragynines or their associated alkaloids, short of minor constipation or nausea if consuming far too much in an irresponsible fashion. Kratom has zero overdose potential, and lacks the affinity for respiratory depression exhibited by other pharmaceutical class opiates, thus eliminating the risk of death by respiratory depression. I believe the illegalization of Kratom and it's coinciding alkaloids would put this country into a position of a far worse opiate addiction epidemic. As most recovered pill addicts refuse to ever touch pills again, this would also cause a sharp uptick in heroin or alternative illicit drug use, addiction and correlating violent crime, an expensive and troublesome issue for both state and federal officials. There is simply no gain to be had federally or for the American public to illigalize such a medically beneficial and physiologically harmless plant material.

documents.commentText:
My wife has been suffering for five years from Fibromyalgia and Rheumatoid Arthritis.  We have been using Kratom as a supplement to treat her pain and depression for the past year.  Her improvement and ability to get through her day has been almost miraculous!  She had been taking prescription medicines, but has been able to significantly reduce her dependence on them to get through the typical daily pain that is associated with RA and Fibro. 

The thought of my wife being an addict is laughable.  She is a mother of 7 grown children, she is a practicing Mormon and has never taken an illegal drug in her life.  She also runs her own business.  I do not believe she would be capable of running her growing business without the benefits of Kratom. She makes and markets goat milk soaps and lotions from our two dairy goats.  Her business is NOT selling Kratom.  She only uses it. 

I have also used Kratom myself for treating depression and it has also helped me to lose 60 pounds, which has affected my health dramatically in a positive way.  I do not take Kratom regularly like my wife does, but just as needed, as opposed to going on antidepressants.  I have never had any issues with withdrawls when I stop taking it, even after a couple of weeks.

I am a tax paying, law abiding citizen and I have no intention of becoming a drug user, so if the ban goes into place, my wife and I will stop using Kratom.  But it is absurd to consider this supplement in any way dangerous.  The worst effect we have experienced with it is some mild constipation.  Banning Kratom will affect our lives significantly, Please do not remove this "gift from the Gods", from the free market.  I am deeply concerned that the ban will force my wife to turn to legal pharmaceuticals, which will reduce her ability to function dramatically and may lead to addiction.  Do not fix, what is not broken.

Kratom does NOT cause addiction.  I have started and stopped using this supplement  after a week or two of use and have suffered absolutely NO side effects from stopping using Kratom.

Please, understand that I am a law abiding citizen, and not a drug user. I do not even use alcohol! I simply wish to have open and free access to this supplement, a supplement that has changed my families lives for the better.  

I suspect that Kratom may just work too well, and perhaps that is the issue.  I am all for Pharmaceutical companies to research and provide a better form of this, as it does not cause addiction, and its effectiveness is remarkable.   A concentrated pill form of this would be far more convenient.  Yet it seems to be almost perfect just in its natural form, but if it can be improved, I am all for it.  

In my opinion, you simply cannot overdose on Kratom.  You just get sick and throw it up if you take too much (which I did once by accident).  we take about half of the recommended dosage, (1 level teaspoon) and it is perfect.  You cannot abuse Kratom. It does not cause a "high". It produces a calm.  It has never caused either of us any impairment whatsoever.  Its like taking melatonin. Please dont plan on banning that naturally occurring supplement either.    

   James T Johnston

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W,


To whom it may concern,

I strongly and respectfully oppose classifying kratom as a schedule 1 controlled substance. Kratom has helped thousands of people with medical conditions who choose to use a natural alternative to pharmaceutical drugs. This plant has been safely used for thousands of years with little to no negative side effects. I urge you not to turn honest, responsible users into criminals from an inaccurate claim of kratom being an imminent threat to public health and safety. We as Americans should have the right to use kratom if we so choose. More people are poisoned per year from laundry detergents than kratom, yet laundry detergents still remain legal because the majority of the population uses it responsibly for its intended purpose; this is also true for kratom; it has positive and helpful attributes to aid with treating anxiety, depression, pain, and many other ailments, both minor and serious. Kratom also is extremely effective in helping people end their opioid addictions in a safe and controlled manner. I again respectfully urge you to not criminalize the use of kratom.

http://jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2094342

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3670991/

documents.commentText:
Please do not ban kratom.

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, which the public overwhelmingly supports ending.  It is a waste of resources to ban a substance which has been safely used by millions of people in the U.S., and for which evidence supports its use as a pain reliever and opiod replacement.

Doing so will just make criminals out of people who use it -  with no benefit to society - but doing so will harm those who use it to treat opiod addiction, and we as a society will end up spending lots of money pursuing and housing these new criminals without any benefit.  And this will effectively stop all research into it's potential benefits.

The end result will be more criminals, more people in jail or prison, more opiod drug use, and no research into it's possible benefits.

That's pretty much a lose-lose proposition all the way around.

documents.commentText:
In a free society it is an individual's right to ingest substances that can be shown to provide health benefits. The evidence I've heard, from those taking this naturally-occurring substance, is that it relieves pain without the negative effects of intoxication and without the damaging effects of opiates. Prescription pill addiction is rampant in our heavily medicated culture and a plant that can be substituted without harmful side effects should not be pushed towards Schedule I banning; it should be made readily available for testing and additional research. While I understand the DEA's objectives include protecting the public from harmful substances, it should also include ensuring the population's access to naturally-occurring plants that may have beneficial medicinal purposes. 

I do not take Kratom but have heard from individuals who do, and comprehensively undermining their health without any supporting empirical evidence would be the opposite of everything we value in terms of living in a free society. Please reconsider this scheduling so the appropriate research can take place. We hope you will side with the public's true interest over Big Pharma, fear-mongering, and those seeking to profit off the alternatives. Thank you for your consideration on this topic.

documents.commentText:
Ladies and Gentlemen of the DEA,

I am writing you regarding the DEAs consideration of scheduling Kratom as a controlled substance, specifically as a schedule 1 substance. As a highly successful real estate investor, which hokds  both undegraduate and graduate degrees from the University of Colorado I'm  happy to report that me and many of my friends and coleagues responsibly use Kratom on a weekly basis. Not a single one of use has ever experienced any of the negative effects that are sometimes attributed to Kratom.  I honestly believe this attempt is a completely misguided attemp to ban Kratom is based on misinformation and fear of misunderstanding, probably due to the lack of understanding about the effects and perceived dangers of this safe natural plant. 

First I would like to address the question of whether kratom is safe or if it is the highly dangerous plant that deserves schedule 1 designation in the same category of methanohetamine, cocaine, and other obviously danger drugs. In order to make this determination and hold a conversation on this issue let's consider the facts about Kratom safety. 

1) The US government has noted a group of 15 or so Kratom related deaths in our country in the last 5 or 10 years. Well, with closer examination not a single one of those incidents was attributed to Kratom and Only Kratom. These people virtually all had a coctail of legal and illegal substances in thier system which more likely to be the cause of over dose. Just because Kratom was in existence in those cases does not in any way determine it was the Kratom that caused thier overdose. In fact, people from Southeast Asia have safely been using Kratom for thousands of years without a single report of Kratom death or overdose. 

2) The health benefits of Kratom are vast. Kratom is a light mood amenhancercthat create a feeling of energy, well being, reduction of anxity and decrease in depression and chronic pain. These affects are mind and last no longer than 4 or 5 hours. It encourages productivity and energy as well.  Compared to other mind altering chemicals the intoxication effects are millions of times less intense than alcohol and marijuana.

3) in conclusion Kratom is a very safe "coffe like" substance that is extremely safe and should be made available to responsible adults, 

On behalf of the medical patients in the country who are no longer willing to endure the crippling side effects of prescription drugs such as benzodiazepines and prescription pain killers, please bo not take this safe alternative from our access. Try it yourself if you don't believe me. 

Sincerely,

Observatory Properties LLC
2810 Clermont Street
Denver, CO, 80201
Jake Silcott, B.S., M.B.A
720-431-0164
Jakesilcott@hotmail.com

As a 23 year old severe alcoholic, I've finally found a way out with kratom. 

I've been drinking heavily; very heavily since about 16. Since a young age I've drank almost everyday and most of the time by myself just to cope with what I thought life had to give me. Depression and anxiety have ravaged my life and for years since my TEENAGE years, I thought life was pretty much drinking myself to oblivion so I could sleep at night.

Fast forward to a few months ago when I discovered kratom, and initially didn't think anything of it. 

Something that could not get me high but just make me
feel normal. And what do you know? It exists.

The month after I stated drinking the tea, I could sleep, I felt rested and that deathly
feeling of being sober was gone. 

It was insane. Not a high insane. But an insane of the thought
that I could actually function on a day to day basis.

My own mother has struggled with doctor prescribed opiates and drugs for opiate withdrawls. I hadn't heard a positive thing from her in years. I told her to try out kratom and this was the response:

"I am scared, it's been about an hour, powder will probably be better,  feels like last capsule is stuck some how.  I am nervous to get excited about how I feel because I am afraid it's not true. That horrible feeling I had in my body is gone,  I feel less anxiety I actually feel like talking,  which I haven't in a long time.  I am going to open 1-2 more capsules and put them in liquid and drink it, I feel it will probably work better.  I only took 4 so 2 grams. Thank you so much"

"The death feeling inside is gone!!!!! I took two more to see, but I am actually in the living room talking with my twins, feeling so much better, is it really happening?  Or is it a dream?"

Relief. Absolute relief. Not a high. But relief.  

If kratom is banned, it will become vividly clear that the people that are in control
of us do not give a damn if we're healthy and/or happy.

At the end of the day, if we're out of
luck with this plant, go get yourself an 18 pack
of bud light and kill your anxieties that way.

It's even promoted.

documents.commentText:
To the esteemed deciding members of the DEA,

    As a parent who has helplessly observed my son wrestle with depression and anxiety over the last two years, I feel compelled to join the chorus of Americans requesting the DEA to not place Kratom on Schedule 1.  My son tried multiple prescription medications that only made him feel worse.  The ONE substance that has helped him has been Kratom.  Some of you must know the vicarious pain associated with watching a loved one suffer from depression.  Imagine, then, the threat of restricting access to this one helpful remedy.  Kratom does not induce a high, retard cognition, intoxicate or seem to have any addictive response in him.  All it does do, in fact, is give some relief, where no other relief is possible.  

    I feel strongly that such a ban, if imposed, will have the effect of negative contagion for the DEA, and ultimately will not prevent people from using Kratom, but will only tax your limited enforcement resources and criminalize innocent civilians who are only seeking relief from situations our society has otherwise failed to solve.  What public policy is served here?

    There is a stark difference between the kinds of drugs that might offer temporary "relief" to the user while simultaneously creating worse problems, such as heroin, and the uniquely effective and non-debilitating relief found in Kratom.  This distinction should be honored. Many lives are at stake.  This, it seems, is a unique situation wherein scheduling will create the very harm it is intended to prevent, by forcing suffering Americans to turn to much worse substances if they cannot have access to a rather miraculously harmless and helpful one: Kratom.

Thank you for your time, and willingness to receive public comments on this matter.

documents.commentText:
My story is a simple one. I'm almost 68 years old.  I learned about kratom about four years ago after a lifetime of seeking energy and clarity of mind and a positive mood that didnt involve sugar or large doses of caffeine. Katom supports my energy and a healthy positive mood. It contains no caffeine and also has helped defeat the sugar and alcohol cravings, which were a poor source of energy and alertness, anyway.


Kratom may also be helping with my 40 year history of chronic back pain by keeping my muscles relaxed and supple. I give most of the credit for that to the high-quality nutritional supplements that I began taking about the same time I learned about kratom.


I am semi-retired now and in very good health. After a long career of doing a variety of work to pay my bills while pursuing my deeper personal interests of health and athletics, I have settled down to write &


Why is the DEA trying to ban an herb that is mostly being consumed to help people permanently withdraw from narcotic addiction and habituation? All at a great cost savings to ourselves and our insurance programs!


Wouldnt it be a better investment of DEA funding to prevent heroin, fentanyl, and other synthetic drugs from entering the country on the basis of # of lives saved?


Why does the FDA and DEA both say that kratom causes respiratory depression? Several researchers have found no evidence of that in new experimentation or in reviews of the medical literature.


See this recent study: https://d3n8a8pro7vhmx.cloudfront.net/americankratomassociation/pages/21/attachments/original/1467415534/Journal_Of_The_American_Chemical_Society_6-6-16_Report.pdf?1467415534


Please also see this review, which mentions the lack of respiratory depression produced by kratom: 
The pharmacology and toxicology of kratom: from traditional
herb to drug of abuse, 2015, Marcus L. Warner, Nellie C. Kaufman, Oliver Grundman


See also this patent by Drs. McCurdy and Boyer, who have done the most research into kratom of any American researchers, where they say in [0098], section (i) Kratom use has never been associated with respiratory depression. https://www.google.com/patents/US20100209542 


What proof do you have that kratom causes hallucinations? No-one in the kratom community of tens of thousands of responsible consumers of kratom have ever mentioned having hallucinations.


Why do the DEA and the FDA always assume that the public is full of idiots who abuse herbs? Has it ever occurred to you that the majority might be taking kratom in moderate, even tiny doses because they have learned thats what works best and avoids the side effects that only appear at very large doses? 


I am not aware of anyone in the U.S. kratom community who has experienced hyperpigmentation of the face. Can you show me some proof of this in the U.S., where there is no other likely cause? I have met kratom consumers who have been taking the herb for ten years and they look and act happy and normal.


How did the DEA get the idea that kratom was a threat? Your agency seems to have a very negative perspective of the many middle-class people, with a surprising number of nurses and even a few doctors, who consume kratom to support their health and well-being.


If youre comparing studies done from the Ramathibodi Poison Control Center in Thailand and are expecting to find that level of multidrug abuse throughout the U.S. kratommunity, you will be disappointed. That was a very sloppy study, with no blood testing done on intake to determine what these wigged out patients had been taking besides kratom. No consideration of their diet or whether they had been eating or hydrating at all (which could cause hallucinations and delusions, by themselves). Very sloppy reporting of the facts.


In conclusion, it would be unfair and unwise to ban or otherwise schedule an herb that is being used successfully by millions of Americans to support & promote their health and wellbeing in order to protect the small minority who will always seek out and abuse virtually any available substance. In fact, the very language the DEA uses to describe kratom, portraying it as a drug of abuse causing hallucinations, delusions, and classic symptoms of opioids, only serves to invite abuse by this minority of chronic drug abusers.


Kratom is helping many people, including myself, to enjoy a better quality of life -- without impairment -- and producing few significant problems, even among those who intentionally misuse it out of ignorance or a desire to pursue the legal high that the DEA and the media have led them to believe it offers. Why not leave kratom alone and pursue the truly dangerous substances your agency was created to defend us against?

documents.commentText:
I can't think of a more succinct and thorough way to offer my thoughts on banning Kratom, so I will simply include the points already made by the Drug Policy Alliance. Banning Kratom would be a mistake.

-Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
-If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
-Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
-Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
-Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
-Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
My name is Jessica Neal. I'm 37 and work in the accounting office at Walmart. I have worked there for 15 years. I'm married, have a daughter, and two sweet kitties. 

My journey with Kratom started in July. I did a ton of reading up on it, because I am very careful about stuff I put in my body. It took me two weeks to decide to give it a try. My friend suggested it,  because she has taken it for a long time. I have degenerative disk disease and was diagnosed in 2010. It has caused me to have two torn discs in my spine. The gel that cushions my vertebrae leak out and messes worth my nerves. The pain goes all the way to my feet. My legs burn and feel like they are asleep. I feel like I have a Charlie horse in my butt cheek, if I move too fast. I work 40 a week and by the time I get done fighting the pain all day, I am worthless. I lay on the couch all night. That's all I do on my days off too. I used to be so active before this. I ran 50 miles a week, fished every weekend,  and loved to hike. Now,  I weigh 230 pounds, because I can't be active at all. It kills me mentally. Thank God I have a wonderful husband. I'm on all sorts of prescriptions, but all it does is takes the edge off the pain. 

Then I tried kratom. I honestly didn't believe it would do anything. I couldn't get that lucky that something natural would work. Well, I did. It takes the majority of my pain away workout making me out of it. I was so happy that I was getting my life back. All it took was a couple of teaspoons a day. Then,  less than a month later news of the DEA ban came. I couldn't believe this was happening. I finally got my life back and it was being taking away from me again. I got a slight taste of what life could be like. I was so upset. I still am. Please don't take this way from people who really need it. Chronic pain is such a horrible thing. To find something that helps and doesn't affect your brain is amazing. I should have a choice in taking something natural without the fear of it being taken away. Please, please reconsider. Look at all the good stuff that it's given to those of us that had no hopes. I don't want to go back on all those pills again.

documents.commentText: It is highly unlikely Kratom is a real threat to public health; it has been used for centuries in Southeast Asia with minimal health repercussions. There is mounting anecdotal evidence that kratom provides significant relief from debilitating illnesses that modern medicine has thus far a very limited capacity to treat (fibromyalgia, interstitial cystitis are just two notable examples). It would be a mistake to take measures that would stall proper scientific research on something that may prove to help millions. However, more importantly, it would be potentially disastrous to the many lives that are currently finding help via kratom where other treatment options have failed. Removing this option will further devastate the lives of many people who have been unable to find relief elsewhere. Banning kratom would be the real threat to public health.

documents.commentText:
DEA,

  My Name is Matthew J and I would like to start with a little history about myself. May 24th 2004, 3 days before high school graduation, my life changed in a big way. I was in a car accident involving fire. Being burned over 68% of my body, put in a medical induced coma for one month, and spent about 5 months in the hospital has been hard. I have had countless surgeries that have caused me to have severe nerve pain. A few years later I was hit by a drunk driver acquiring a prosthetic hip and a few pins in my ankle. The ankle over time started dying because of the placement of the pins, restricting blood flow causing arthritis. Multiple doctor visits later they suggested pain management. I have now been going to pain management over 2 years now and my tolerance has sky rocketed. I believe the first hospital stay caused me to have such a high tolerance. Initially I was given two hands full of Intravenous pain killers twice a day including, Midazolam, Morphine, Fentanyl, and Dilaudid for the excruciating dressing changes they had perform on me. Eventually they had to wean me off of all of that using methadone. Now back to present time. Having the ankle pain plus nerve pain I was prescribed a two-day fentanyl patch and 6, 15 mg Oxycodones a day. I became highly addicted to prescription pain medication and what they were prescribing me was not helping. I have known people who have started out with pain meds and led them to using heroin. I feel like I am possibly in route for the same mistakes. For the last year I have been running out of pain medication early causing me to go through horrible withdrawals. I am only 30 years old and dont want to be a slave to this pain management system anymore but at the same time I truly need something to help with the pain. 
A friend of mine introduced me to Mitragyna speciose about 8 months ago, I have been using it ever since. I used it to curb the opioid withdrawal at first and now am using it in place of the opioid medication. This new form of medication I only need to take 3 times a day opposed to the pain meds every 2- 4 hour. Kratom has not only helped me with my every day wellbeing, but it has also helped with the pain I endure on a 24 hr basis. I definitely feel like kratom has helped me become more of a productive person and has allowed me to overcome my personal struggles with pain and unfortunately the addiction that comes with the pain management.
If Kratom was banned tomorrow I feel like I would be taking a step back in my efforts to fight the pain struggles and live a normal life. I guarantee my overall quality of life will suffer including, taking care of my children, maintaining  With pain management I was constantly missing work because I would run out of medication early, I was at a higher risk of overdosing, going through bad anxiety on a constant, and had the feeling of being a slave to the prescriptions has made me look into Kratom. In my opinion Kratom has saved me from a dark path I do not want to take. Not only would the ban on Kratom cause me to search out for other alternatives I would be in a lot of horrible pain in the process. I would not be able to work or even sleep for that matter. I feel like I would have no other options but to go back to self-medicating again with alcohol and whatever else I can find to cure the agonizing pain I deal with on a daily basis.  I do not want to get back on Opioids because of the risk of overdosing and going through the pain of constant withdrawals.
Kratom has Not caused me serious side effects. I also personally feel like kratom is a lot safer than prescription medication. I have been taking it daily for over half a year now. I have never felt like I have taken too much, unlike the opioid medicine. I do not feel like I am addicted to Kratom but I do feel like I need it for the reasons I have stated above. From the multiple studies and articles I have read about Kratom it is suggests this plant is safer at such a higher level than opioids. Its fatal respiratory slowdowns that have turned opioid abuse into a massive epidemic is significantly lower in Kratom.  My digestive system is back on tract opposed to when I was using opioids, my appetite has increased as well as my overall physical health. My pain has almost felt like it has decreased with the use of Kratom opposed to the use of Opioids.  Even though a scientist may obtain a license to study Kratom if it is banned, that doesnt mean we the people will have the same authority. Also from what I understand, it is hard to obtain that license. That means if our scientists are on the verge of ground breaking discoveries and cant obtain the license they will have to scrap the entire study. 
I am writing this letter in hopes of stopping the Kratom ban. I can honestly say I am fearful of what my life will become without Mitragyna Speciosa. I ask you to reconsider the decisions of banning this plant. 

Matthew J.
