documents.commentText:
I am a 49 year old woman, married to a retired military officer for 20 years.  I am a stay at home mom and we have 5 beautiful daughters.  Approximately 11.5 years ago, I began suffering from severe lower back pain.  After 7 years of misdiagnosis, it was finally determined I was suffering from severe  SI joint dysfunction.  My right side was all but fused and my left side, hyper mobile, never staying in tact. This simply occurred because after the birth of our last child, my joints didn't go back into proper place.  For 3 years I went to physical therapy and endured more than 22 procedures to try and mask the pain and was prescribed everything from Percocet, to Morphine, to Methadone, all to function at some level and perform daily tasks to care for my family and our home.  Procedures were never successful, at times, developing severe neuritis, unable to tolerate any touch, even running water from a shower left me whaling in agony.  Upon moving from Florida to Texas, I made attempt after attempt to find care to manage the pain and live with a reasonable quality of life.  I was refused treatment, refused care, and treated like an absolute criminal, all because of a stigma associated with narcotics, It was humiliating and embarrassing.  With quite a bit of due diligence, I finally sought out and found a physician that was interested in healing the joints and not masking or hiding the pain.  After 8 very uncomfortable treatments, I was able to tolerate a more comfortable life and participate in regular activities without dread or embarrassment.  While researching treatment options, I came across several articles about Kratom and the success, not only alieving the misery that accompanies no longer taking prescribed narcotics, but allowed controlled and healthy relief from the pain I continued to contend with.  I have now been taking Kratom for more than a year, and have not had any adverse effects.  I function without being in a fog, with manageable comfort and am able to participate in most activities with my family.  I have never felt unsafe or concerned and am absolutely thankful for this plant and all of the benefits Kratom offers me; pain relief, mood stability, and restful, regular sleep) .  I can not predict my outcome had I not discovered Kratom, but I can assure you my quality of life and the lives of our family have improved tremendously compared to the 4 years of synthetic medication with adverse effects and procedure after procedure which offered no relief or end in sight.

Rene' Schutt

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I am writing out of concern over the proposed reclassification of kratom as a Schedule I controlled substance.

Schedule I drugs, substances, or chemicals are defined as drugs with no currently accepted medical use and a high potential for abuse.

This is definition is simply NOT applicaple to kratom. It is not addictive or dangerous. Furthermore, there have been multiple studies confirming beyond any doubt kratoms's effectiveness helping people suffering from opiate addition, and people suffering from depression and axiety. 

Opiate addiction in particular is a problem plaguing every corner of our country. I personally have lost a close family member to opiate addiction. I know that if he had access to kratom, there is a chance Michael may have been able to beat his addicition and he would still be with us today.

Opiate drugs like oxycontin have killed tens of thousands of people in this country, and has directly contributed to the heroin epidemic sweeping the nation. It is an absolute disgrace that this prescription drug that has caused so much pain and death remains legal and easilly accessible, while kratom, a substance that could help many such people recover, is being threated with a schedule 1 status.

In Alamaba, which banned kratom at the state-level, deaths from opiate use went UP afterwards. I must ask- do you WANT more Americans to die from opiate overdose?

Please do the right thing. Stop the DEA from ennacting this senseless reclassification of kratom, and contributing to more opiate-related deaths.

Thank you,
Joseph G.

documents.commentText:
To Whom This May Concern,

I discovered kratom in December of 2012. At the time, I was struggling with an addiction to prescription pain pills, oxycodone in particular, but I would take anything I could get that was an opiate. I was a new father, very stressed and struggling at work. The pills were my crutch. I was self-medicating, and buying them off the street, sometimes even putting myself in dangerous situations. 

I knew what I was doing was wrong, and I was on a path that could easily lead me to being in jail or on heroin. My tolerance was building and my addiction was getting worse. 

I tried to stop several times, but the withdrawal was unbearable, both physically and mentally. 

In researching ways to get off opiates, I learned about kratom. I purchased some and found that it really helped take away much of the discomfort of withdrawal. This plant was a miracle plant to me!   It truly helped me get clean. In many ways, it's fair to say that Kratom saved my life. Who knows how bad I would have gotten? 

I found no side effects with kratom, aside from it not tasting very good. It made me life better. And, I did not become addicted to it.  

I also found that kratom worked as a mild pain reliever and helped with some anxiety issues I have.  Without being addicted, I am able to take it from time to time, and it improves my quality of life. 

I am better father and husband, as well as a better employee at my job. And It's because of this plant. 

Should kratom become illegal, I truly believe it will result in making the heroin and opiate epidemic much worse. 

Please keep kratom legal and readily available. 

Sincerely,

Steve Katz

documents.commentText:
As a senior citizen, I have become increasingly aware over the years of friends who are dealing with chronic pain and the 
challenges they face in the process of finding appropriate remedies. Although I do not have some of these same challenges to my
own health, I am aware that many solutions to chronic pain and serious illnesses come to us from other cultures, including Asian
medicine and from natural sources found and used successfully in other parts of the world.  
I am grateful that the DEA allows public comment periods in its decision-making before imposing rules and regulations, an
approach that permits caution while remaining open-minded in its consideration of anecdotal evidence about new and previously 
unknown substances. The public respects the balance that must be maintained between preventing harm to the public while not closing the
door to finding possible disease cures or helpful interventions using supplements or natural substances now or in the future.

Everyone is now aware that help with the Opioid epidemic surging through the US is desperately needed, and I believe the ability to assist with the
withdrawal process is a key element to success.  Having said that, I trust you will thoroughly investigate and consider all sides to
the issues about these substances, excluding, wherever possible, political, Big Pharma, and/or religious objections as barriers to approving viable solutions.

.

Dear DEA:

I have great respect for what you do.  I am a government worker as well.  I write today to provide input regarding Docket No. DEA-442W, the potential for the Schedule I Listing of Kratom.

I live with chronic pain - always - in my mouth because of Dental malpractice that resulted in the cutting of the front buckle of my upper palate, and subsequently my fifth cranial nerve.

I have tried Lyrica, Gabbepentin (sp), and several other nerve pain medicines.  Although none give any relief - they do all come with extensive adverse side-effects work. This includes oxycodone, a highly addictive drug that simply cannot be taken long-term and is already the subject of its own listing - and justifiably so.

I cannot smoke marijuana (again, I am a government employee), and cannot drink it away with alcohol - which gives some relief but (again) in return for horrible adverse health effects.   

Kratom is the single herb that gives me relief without any side effects.  None of the studies that I have seen reporting adverse health effects or death could reasonably be attributed to attributed to Kratom alone.  I am older and will simply suffer my chronic pain until I cannot deal with it any longer.  Younger folks with similar chronic pain conditions will be driven into the arms of heroin. It is already happening.  

I encourage you not to follow through with the Schedule I listing of Kratom.

Signed - "A US Government Worker, Tax Payer, and Patriot."

Sincerely,

William Johns

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern, 

There are several reasons why I disagree with the DEA's attempt to classify Kratom as a schedule 1 controlled substance. Kratom is plant  found in nature and used for many different reasons by a plethora of cultures. The benefits of Kratom are abundant. The beneficial properties are anxiety relief, pain relief, mood stabilizer, sleep aid, and mood stimulant. 

 I work in south Florida as a Plumber, The days are hot, the job gets very stressful, and my body hurts when i'm home. I am only 26 and have already had a hernia and had to undergo surgery. Kratom is a great alternative to drinking a beer at the end of the day to relax and wind down after a hard days work.  I am a former heroin addict and alcoholic, so I understand what addiction is, how it acts, and what does to your body. I remember when I was actively using how sick I became physically, Kratom has none of the characteristics of an addictive substance. In the years I have been taking it, not once did I feel as though I lost control (as I did with drugs and alcohol) not once did I ever have withdrawal symptoms nor do I have to have it everyday without exception, the way I did with drugs and alcohol. It is not the same thing as other schedule 1 drugs and it is absurd to classify as the same. It is the only alternative I have to drugs and alcohol, which I can no longer take. 

As an addict, I have abused prescription medications, so for my anxiety and work related pain, prescriptions are out of the question. Kratom has helped me maintain a healthy lifestyle and helped me be a productive member of society, which I was not when I was drinking and using drugs. Kratom is quite literally the only thing I can safely take in order to manage my pain and anxiety. If i were to get a prescription for anti anxiety  medication or a narcotic of any kind, the possibility of addiction is far too great, and the benefits do not outweigh the risks. With Kratom, the benefits certainly outweigh the risks.

 I sincerely hope that my government does not take away the only option for people like me who struggle with addiction. I do not want to believe that in America, for people with a past like mine, the only option for treating anxiety and pain are pharmaceutical drugs. If I were to go that route, that would only exacerbate my problems and lead me down a path I do not want to travel. I have tried the "Big Pharma" route, it did not work and only made me worse. It is not a solution for people like me. Kratom is. I wish to believe that I live in a country that values the welfare of its citizen more than the bottom line of big business. It seems as though that is the only way our society wants to see anyone get any releif and citizens should have more options to mange their situations than "popping a pill." . The public outcry regarding the ban of Kratom, and the adamant pleas to keep it legal speaks for itself.

Sincerely,

Cody Ulrich

documents.commentText: I am writing to you as a member of law enforcement to suggest that you not schedule kratom as a controlled substance.  As someone who has worked in law enforcement for almost two decades, I can tell you that I have never encountered any problems with anyone using this plant.  In fact, most of us have never even heard of it until recently, and that is only because of the DEA action.  All of us have been scratching our heads about this.  You would think if it was as dangerous as you claim, we'd see it all the time-- like we do with heroin and fentanyl and oxy.  Those are what are really dangerous, not some plant that seems to actually help people stay off of the really bad stuff.  I'd suggest that you focus your attention and resources where they belong-- on fighting against heroin and fentanyl.  Honestly you should ban fentanyl if anything-- that is leading to more deaths than I guess you realize.  Why bother turning it into a crime to ingest this stuff when those of us who are sworn to uphold the law haven't seen a single problem with it yet?  Focus your attention on what really matters here-- stopping heroin and fentanyl from getting smuggled into the country and killing more Americans.  I'd also encourage you to think about the fact that you'd be creating another black market for the cartels, which are seeing a big cut into their profits from the legalization of marijuana in a number of states (including the one I work in).  As I'm sure you're aware, they are starting to branch into manufacturing and smuggling pills into the country now, and they're looking for more opportunities for profit from what I understand. Why give them yet another product they can smuggle into our country and kill our citizens over?  If it were really harmful, I'd agree with you.  But 15 deaths that are questionably related to this plant are frankly a drop in the bucket compared to the real killers, like heroin and even alcohol and cigarettes.  I suspect that many more people die from products that are legal, like tylenol, so why even waste your resources on this?  And why should the rest of us in law enforcement waste our resources on it as well?  It just doesn't make sense.

I am a 41 year old IT Technician and I believe a ban on kratom would do more harm than good.  Personally, I am no longer dependent on prescription benzodiazepines which were having a negative impact on my health and well-being after long-term use. Kratom helps to relieve my crippling anxiety and helps to prevent panic attacks in which the benzodiazepines were prescribed for. 

Kratom is known for being a life-saver for those dependent on both non-prescription and prescription opioids.  With today's opioid epidemic, taking away the greatest known harm-reduction tool for opiods just doesn't make much sense to me.  Kratom has only a few minor side-effects, if any, when used properly, and is very safe shown by numerous anecdotal reports over the many centuries it has been in use.

I am not for banning this substance but for the regulation of Kratom, similar to the way alcohol is regulated currently.  I feel it should be the people's choice as to what they put in their bodies and we should have an alternative to the sometimes dangerous prescription drugs that are prescribed to us by doctors.

I also feel you should honor the FOIA request being presented to you and am having a hard time understanding why you won't release the information to the public if your sources are valid.  We have the right to see the information leading to your decision to ban this substance.  

I sincerely hope you do the right thing.  Thank you for taking the time to listen to the voice of "We the People".

documents.commentText:
I have never written a letter like this, but I want to address the pending possible ban on the plant, Kratom. I am 41 years old. About 16 months ago, I got a prescription for an opioid based pain medication due to pain from work, past injuries, and just plain advancing age. The medication works wonderfully, and does exactly what it's supposed to do, making it possible for me to work as hard as I do.  A few months ago my doctor told me that I may not be able to keep receiving this medication without jumping through a multitude of hoops and convincing a pain specialist that I need it. So in case I lost my prescription, I began researching natural alternatives to opioid medication, and I found Kratom. It is an incredible plant. Although not half as effective as the medication for pain, it DOES help pain, and is an amazing anti -inflammatory. It is amazing how well it works for me and millions of others. I was very relieved to find that if I am found unworthy of keeping my prescribed pain medication that I had an alternative. And now, after just two months, I find out that the FDA/DEA plan to ban Kratom and make it an illegal Schedule 1 drug. I don't know if the drug companies are paying the right people to ban real alternatives to their products, or what, but you are making life miserable for people in real pain. First you make it harder to get relief from your doctor, then you ban any alternatives to prescription drugs. Left without any options, you wonder why people turn to illegal drugs. This plant is natural and harmless if used correctly. Anyone can abuse anything if they want to bad enough. But Kratom is about to be classified more dangerous than Cocaine? Ridiculous.  Also, another use for this plant: Withdrawal. Anyone whose ever ran out of their opiate based medication, or not filled it on time and had to wait a weekend for a refill, will tell you that the 72 hours after you run out are very uncomfortable. This plant is not an opiate, but it binds to the same receptors in the brain. Taking Kratom absolutely negates the symptoms of withdrawal, and that is a miracle in itself. This plant is safe and works wonders. If Marijuana is slowly being made legal in the US, it is just not understandable that Kratom could be made illegal. Please consider taking steps to prevent this from happening. As I said above. I have never used an illegal drug and I never will. Which means if I can no longer buy Kratom, and cannot convince the right Doctor that I need my prescribed pain meds in his opinion, I'll be left in pain with only meager alternatives for relief. PLEASE stop micro- managing everything that actually works. Please do not make this Kratom ban possible. Thank you for your time and consideration. 

Melvin Cloud

documents.commentText:
Thank you for opening up this comment period. I appreciate the opportunity to comment on the regulatory future of kratom.

I'm an unexceptional and average person: middle-class, decent education, parent of small children, suffering no chronic pain or ongoing health challenges. I have not misused prescription opioids or street opiates, but I do occasionally enjoy legal recreational drugs such as caffeine, alcohol, and cannabis. I do not consider myself someone who would likely consume kratom on a regular basis.

Since my time in high school, I have witnessed dear friends become hooked on prescription painkillers. A car accident, a surgery, chronic endometriosis, a kidney infection, a mastectomy... They have been prescribed with strong painkillers, developed a dependency, and gotten hooked. Vicodin, percocet, hydrocodone, oxycontin. Familiar names. The stuff begins to lose its effectiveness, the body compensates by developing a tolerance, and they have to up the dosage. They go back to the doctor's office, pleading, trying to justify their pain to get another refill. They get grilled and side-eyed by the pharmacist when they fill their prescription. They are self-conscious. Street drugs are discreet and much more easy to obtain. No justification required, no accusatory glances, no limit. Where do they go from there? That road is not pretty. It's no exaggeration to say that it destroys lives.

Now you have kratom, a natural herbal remedy. It's a nasty bitter-tasting leaf that is straight-up dried and powdered. It's not patented by a pharmaceutical company. It's not modified in a lab. It's (yet) unregulated by the government. You can easily walk into a shop and buy a bag. There's no gate, there's no shame, and it's (comparatively) cheap. It has painkilling effects, some mild euphoria, little-to-no risk of overdose, and has been used _responsibly_ by thousands of individuals to mitigate their pain and overcome dependency to much more dangerous opioids. It binds to the same receptors in the brain as the opioids, so there are few feelings of withdrawal or craving. Don't you see how this is a win, how this is could be a key to solving the current crisis?? 

I have watched this herb transform the lives of my friends, helped them manage their pain, kick their habit, and normalize their lives. I have talked with smoke shop staff who have witnessed similar and even more transformational stories from their distinct vantage. By our collective understanding, kratom is about as benign and beneficial as coffee -- with an additional superpower to kick dependency to opioids. That's a winning combination. They should be passing this out to patients in rehab clinics. Doctors should be able to suggest it as an alternative for managing chronic pain. It should be on the shelves of the drug store and on the menu at the smoothie shop along with the bee pollen, kava root, and protein powder.

Kratom is the unexpected SOLUTION to the opioid crisis. It is the deus ex machina of the story. There would be few superlatives strong enough to describe how stupid the DEA would be were they to decide to classify kratom as a Schedule I drug without a proper investigation.

Study it. Investigate its effects, side-effects, benefits, and drawbacks. Get opinions from independent neuropharmacologists and pain management specialists. You can see from the thousands of comments that many of us -- consumers and non-consumers alike -- are confident in the redeeming medical and societal value of this drug. We hope your investigation leads you to a similar conclusion.

Thank you for your consideration.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
    If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
    Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
    Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
    Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
    Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern:

My name is Cody, and I am a 26 year old CPA who has struggled with attention and focus disorders for the majority of my life. I am writing to request that you make every effort within your power to keep kratom legal and available within the United States.

After using a variety of prescription stimulants to overcome my focus challenges, I was introduced to kratom as an alternative treatment. I immediately noticed that the energy and focus that came from kratom felt more natural and therapeutic than the prescription amphetamines typically used to treat attention disorders. I have incorporated the use of kratom into my routine by taking a few small, stimulating doses throughout the week to improve my focus and performance at work, and I have been able to abandon the use of prescription amphetamines entirely. For me, kratom has been a safer, healthier alternative that has allowed me to escape from a confining amphetamine addiction, and I hope to be able to continue to use it in this manner to stay off of medications indefinitely.

The ban of this substance does not come at a net benefit to the public, and I hope that your help will make an impact in postponing or reversing the legislation that will eliminate access to this plant. I plead that you hear my message below and consider pushing to retain the legality of kratom in support of the people in this country in need of this herb.

Thus far, not a single death has been conclusively attributed solely to kratom, and its benefits greatly outweigh its costs. As the only widely accepted herb that allows people to break free from crippling heroin and opiate addictions, kratom has saved far more lives than it has worsened if any. Opiate and amphetamine addictions continue to be a significant threat to public safety, and have become far more lethal in recent times due to the dealers on the black market cutting drugs with dangerous research chemicals. Placing kratom on Schedule I will undoubtedly make a negative impact on the heroin/opiate addiction epidemic, ultimately endangering thousands of lives. This is a matter of life and death to certain people, an infringement of liberty to many others, and a negative step in scientific progress, so please use your voice to support this cause.

Kratom has stimulating effects similar to coffee and analgesic properties similar to prescription painkillers, with a fraction of the negative side effects (temporary nausea at most). Anybody who has tried kratom would understand that it has great potential for health benefits upon further research, and in the meantime provides a safe, effective way for people to break addictions or deal with chronic pain. It does not impair people's cognitive abilities, motor skills, or judgment. It is simply incorrect to claim that it has no medical use, and it has not been given the chance for such a conclusion to be made. There is no benefit to the ban of this substance, because it is not a threat to public health, nor is it widely-abused for its very mild psychoactive properties. 

Please help this cause by being part of the movement that protects the plant, as well as the people who rely on it and the future of medical progress that it will inevitably provide. I hope you hear this message among the many others that are fighting for this cause and take action on behalf of all of us.

Thank you very much for reading this message. I wish you a great week!

 I discovered this herbal tea several years ago after hip surgery. I had some serious complications after surgery that required I take medication for pain. After a year I had a corrective procedure that finally fixed my hip, days after this surgery I was no longer in the pain I had been in for over a year so I no longer needed any pain medication. I was shocked to find that after a day or so without pain medication I started feeling bad like I had the flu and after a bit of research i realized I was in physical withdrawal. I read about kratom and began to drink the tea  the next day. I drank the Kraton tea for a couple of weeks but I was 100% medication free with no discomfort whatsoever from the moment I I got the herb.  I fear without this herb I would have been  very uncomfortable, or worse, forced to tapper off of a pain medication I no longer needed for pain. I think it would be a real shame to take this useful herb away from folks who are struggling with addiction and trying to get off drugs. I continue to turn to kratom for any periodic discomfort I may have. I have found it to be useful for cramps, upset tummies and sore muscles and would hate not having this in my cupboard the next time it was needed.  
I hope the DEA will not choose to schedule kratom. I simply cannot imagine why the agency would want to take this supplement away from the millions of consumers who enjoy the benefits of this herb.

My life consists of managing the pain and preventing further compression. Narcotics prescribed controls the pain for 5 minutes, when the drug

I know what my life would look like had I not found Kratom.  My life was lived based on my pain level and I never committed to any activity longer than 30 minutes. I basically stayed at
Home. Yes I had a fear of pain. Then one can add depression to my lists of diagnosis, side effect of narcotics. I don't crave Kratom which is very important to me. Narcotics  don't work well for chronic pain, they are more suitable for acute pain but there is an algorithm for prescribing narcotics.  I take Kratom 2 times a day and have yet to feel any narcotic like haziness, it doesn't effect my cognition.  I know you have read those internet discussions on effects of Kratom from those trying to get High.   There are discussions on getting high from taking antidepressants, yet they  aren't controlled.  The point is people will try anything.  I don't have to sit through those ridiculous pain clinics that all chronic pain patients HAVE to go to.  They are the new pill mills.  Kratom gave me my life back. Should Kratom be a scheduled drug, I would be forced to return to a life centered around the monotony of pain and the pills prescribed, and subsequently lose control of my life.

documents.commentText:
Kratom should not be listed as schedule 1.  Based on my experience and knowledge, Kratom can be used for legitimate reasons by adults 18 and older.  

I am confident that it can be used effectively for pain management by people with chronic pain where they cannot receive proper medical care or where there is no immediate known or affordable cure for the condition that is causing their pain.  I am very concerned that without this legal product, people that I care about will have to resort to dangerous drugs, either legal or illegal, in order to manage pain.  Kratom offers an opiate-like effect without the "high", side-effects, and long term damage of actual opiates (both synthetic and naturally derived).

I believe there are minor side effects (such as constipation) that can occur with the use of Kratom, which will adequately prohibit casual abuse of this substance.  I believe that there is little chance that this substance would be used recreationally on a large scale.  I think that casual/recreational use of this product can be discouraged without DEA control.  If it is within the scope of governmental over-sight to ensure that children do not ingest this product, and that cautions are made known to adults, then I can support such over-sight.

I also believe that this substance can be used as an aid to opiate addiction recovery in professional/clinical environments.

As a nation, I believe we need to focus our resources on limiting the abuse of dangerous drugs that are becoming pervasive in our communities, such as fentanyl, meth, heroin and "designer drugs".

I also believe that drug abuse should be dealt with more as a health problem and less as a crime problem.

respectfully submitted,
Daniel J Bosworth

documents.commentText:
I'm a dotcom CEO who was prescribed 10mg/3x daily methadone for spine and joint issues, for 5 years.  This dosage was never increased, and I saw a doctor every month to renew.  I have never taken recreational drugs, nor am I a drinker.

After a surgery earlier this year improved my spine issue, my doctor and I made the decision last month that I was ready to migrate off daily opiates.  I heard about kratom from a nurse friend and started reducing my opiate intake while taking 3mg6mg of red kratom before bed, to calm the terrible restless leg syndrome that accompanies withdrawal.

One month later, I am comfortably down to 5mg/1x daily methadone.  The kratom is not psychoactive to any significant degree that I can appreciate, and it is a godsend for enabling sleep and eliminating RLS.  I have every confidence that, in another month, I will be off methadone entirely.

Please, please do not ban or place kratom in Schedule 1 or 2.  This is an unbelievably useful and efficacious tool for overcoming withdrawal, with no deleterious side effects that I have discerned.  If it were removed from the market, I suspect you would see a significant uptick in harm expansion.

Finally, based on the research I have seen thus far on the few kratom-associated deaths, which seem to feature coincident alcohol and/or drug use, I would be highly skeptical of an FDA decision to schedule kratom at level 1.  That would suggest a degree of danger that is just not present given the massive denominator of users under the few claimed fatalities.  Were such a schedule to be announced, it would tend to reinforce the unfortunate stereotype of the current FDA as a rubber stamp for the pharmaceutical industry and compromise my positive impression of the organization's commitment to ensuring safe, efficacious products are available to the public.

I trust I won't be disappointed,

documents.commentText:
Kratom, a tree grown in southeast Asia grows plentiful, and has been used for thousands, if not millions of years. Leaves are hand picked, crushed into a fine powder, and then, if consumed, create an analgesic effect that prevents or significantly reduces the need for serious painkillers that belong in the opiate family (hydrocodone, oxycodone, oxymorphone, morphine, fentanyl). The Food and Drug Administration works closely with the Canadian Health Center. In Canada, they have legalized Kratom. 

The main active alkaloid is 7-hydroxymitragynine, and the Drug Enforcement Agency is attempting to make it a Schedule 1 Controlled Substance. Not only is this extremely ignorant, as this plant is related to the coffee plant, has no confirmed deaths from the alkaloids alone, has many researchers looking into its potential medical benefits, and creates a large economic growth potential within the US and between other countries whom grow and export it. Scheduling it as a Controlled Substance will halt the vast majority of all scientific research and create many people to revert back to using opiate painkillers their doctors prescribe them. In 2014 alone, the death toll from Prescription Opiates was approximately 25,000 individuals. 25,000 individuals lost their lives because the drugs either fell into the wrong hands due to being sold by individuals prescribed it (likely because healthcare is disgustingly expensive in the United States, which is another story) or individuals were over-prescribed, combined their narcotic analgesics with benzos or alcoholics or another CNS depressant.

Narcan, referred to as an opiate antidote, is now legal to purchase over the counter. This means that the Government has finally realized and accepted opiates are an epidemic in the United States. This brings us to the question as to why the DEA would want to Schedule a leaf with a few active alkaloids that reduce pain, yet cause no respiratory depression and has no confirmed deaths with kratom alkaloids alone. 

Kratom is used daily by individuals across the country, for lethargy, pain, depression, insomnia, and a slur of other personal issues. With the expense of health care, lack of GOOD healthcare (10 minutes with a doctor and you have a piece of paper with some chemical written on it), and the danger of many pharmaceuticals, a lot of individuals prefer to use a natural leaf to treat minor symptoms. It does not replace real medical advice by any stretch of the imagination, but if it saves 1 life from an opiate overdose, and at the same time improves the lives of many, many individuals across this beautiful country of ours, causes economic growth and increases trade between countries, why would the DEA want to schedule this leaf?

Keep Kratom legal.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name is Emily, and I'm a 34 year old digital media executive (Chief Digital Officer) from Seattle, Washington. I was first introduced to kratom two years ago by one of my employees, who had been using the herb to help offset his back pain and sore muscles. I'd recently undergone a spinal surgery myself, and decided to try kratom to see if it would help with my general soreness. I was pleased to discover that not only was it quite helpful with alleviating my pain, but it also provided me with an additional energy boost that was very similar to an excellent cup (or two) of coffee. It's wonderful!

Since I discovered kratom, I've found that it's been extremely beneficial for both my personal and professional life. As a person with chronic back problems who works a job that requires 8+ hours a day of sitting, its pain-reducing qualities are a life saver. I also find that kratom helps keep my energy and focus sharp, which is incredibly useful in my high-stress profession.

As an executive who certainly would NOT consider using illegal drugs, I admit that I was baffled (and a little insulted) when I read that the DEA was considering scheduling the herb as a controlled substance.  I've been using kratom daily for years, and have never experienced any side-effects from the herb -- no dependencies or negative effects. 

I'd be extremely disappointed if I'm no longer able to enjoy kratom, and ask that you reconsider your position on the matter of scheduling it as a controlled substance. From my personal experience and the experience of many other individuals I know, kratom is a highly beneficial plant that positively affects lives. Treating it otherwise would be a huge misstep, and would negatively impact the thousands of Americans currently enjoying its benefits.

Thank you for your consideration,

Emily

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA, 
I oppose scheduling mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, constituents of the Kratom plant (or in binomial nomenclature Mitragyna speciosa), as Schedule I drugs. It does not belong there. It is a very mild stimulant and mild sedative but a very helpful plant, with many uses. We need to conduct clinical trials and studies before making any kind of decision. After years of study, who knows what wonderful things we could find? It could be even more important than what the community believes it to be. However, we will never find out if it becomes a Schedule I drug. We should base all our decisions on hard scientific evidence before making rash decisions. The leaves have been used in South-East Asia for 100's of years. It is used as a mild stimulant, mild sedative, pain killer, and helps ease opiate withdrawal. Many people report that Kratom helps them with arthritis, restless legs syndrome (RLS), and fibromyalgia.

I am Steven Isaac Carroll, I am currently a hard working Sophomore at Weber State University majoring in Botany and Minoring in Chemistry. Throughout my college career I have been taking Kratom regularly and I average between a 3.5-4.0 GPA every semester which demonstrates that Kratom is not affecting my memory, thinking or judgement.  I am 22 years of age. I have used Kratom for 4 years now, starting when I was 18 after I had a surgery to remove an osteocyte that was pinching my nerve cord in my elbow which was causing chronic pain and discomfort. It is an injury I received when playing Lacrosse in High School. The removal of that piece of bone just made the pain and discomfort worse as now the nerve cord in my arm easily slides over where that bone used to be and causes pain, on top of it being constantly strained. Because of this I don't have full movement with my left hand fingers, especially my small finger and a lot of the time my finger feels numb. This constantly causes pain and discomfort and I had an important choice to make after the surgery; take prescription opiates every day with adverse health effects but feel no pain OR find a healthier alternative that will help enough to alleviate at least some degree of the chronic pain and discomfort that I have without the negative health effects. I chose the latter and I am SO happy I did. Kratom has changed my life and the lives of many others for the better. Many veterans, the people who we should treat with the utmost respect use Kratom for various reasons and need it. Kratom does not ruin lives, it saves them. Without Kratom I would have to live with that chronic pain and discomfort daily or I would have to use prescription painkillers, which I do not have any desire to do. 

Kratom is safe, you cannot OD on it, although there are reports of people dying with Kratom in their system along with other drugs, ultimately Kratom was not the cause of death, to say as much is like saying those people had caffeine in their system so the caffeine must be the cause of death. It is safer than alcohol and tobacco, which are both legal. The worst that can happen with Kratom is to throw up if you take too much, just as you would if you ate too much food for dinner. There are very few negative side effects, I only experience one on occasion and that is nausea. Other than that one negative side effect, everything else is positive. 

Ways that I benefit from Kratom are the following: pain relief, anti-oxidant, anxiolytic, anti-depressant, weak sedative properties which helps me sleep, and more. While I realize that prescription opiates have their place in medicine, Kratom offers a much milder, safer option for people who do not wish to gamble with the risks that are often inherent in using prescription opiates. According to the CDC 1,000 people are treated for prescription opiate overdoses and abuse every day. Opiates do ruin lives, let there be a healthy alternative, keep Kratom legal. Kratom is known to be useful for recovering opiate addicts to get off of opiates, and stay off of opiates. While I have never been addicted to opiates and am careful of what I put in my body, I personally know recovering addicts that have used Kratom to help them with their addiction, let me tell you, it helps. We are in an opiate epidemic, a serious drug abuse issue in the United States, we need to do something about that. Kratom can help.

In conclusion, we need to study and regulate the use of the plant, not outright ban it. Banning it will hurt millions of Kratom users including honest hardworking Americans just like me and veterans of our armed forces. Please do not progress the war on drugs, it has been going on long enough and has caused a lot of damage.  Prohibition does not work, we witnessed that in the 1920's with alcohol. Thank you for lifting the ban and allowing a comment period. You have no idea how important that was for you to do. I appreciate the work you guys do, and I hope that someone reads this and it helps them change their mind.

documents.commentText: Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars. Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement. Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down. Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids. Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Kratom has greatly enhanced my life by lifting my mood when I am going through a hard time without the need for pharmaceutical drugs which are often addictive and have side effects.  Kratom use gives me no negative effects and I do not feel the need to eat it every day.  It is indeed non-addictive and non-habit forming for me.  It has also replaced opiate pain medications on a few occasions where I had severe pain from recurring throat infections.  I was becoming dependent on the opiates and found kratom to be as effective but not addictive.  I hope that by sharing my first hand experience with this useful plant you may reconsider your ban on this medicine plant that should remain unregulated for all to use as they please and politely stay out of our business when it comes to what we choose to heal our bodies with.

Thank you very much for listening.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I have Crohn's disease and lost my colon seven years ago and have had Jpouch surgery. 

Lacking a large intestine I have to suffer through many more painful trips to the bathroom than regular people. The pharmaceuticals that I was prescribed before were harsh on my system and I could hardly go out for 30 minutes before I would be in significant pain. 

Utilizing small doses of Kratom, 1-2 grams, twice daily,  I am able to go out for hours at a time. I am not currently taking any pharmaceutical products and have been doing better than ever thanks to this wonderful supplement! 

Just recently my family came to visit me in Colorado and I was able to go on 4-6 hour hikes  with them at elevations of up to 12,000 feet. This would have been impossible for me without Kratom! My family was overjoyed to see me doing so well. The trip from my house into the mountains had never been so easy.  It's nice to be able to relax instead of worrying where the next bathroom is all the time. 

Please don't remove Kratom. If you do my quality of life will drastically decrease. It would mean much less time that I can spend away from home and less wonderful memories out and about with my loved ones. 

Sincerely, 

Brian Joseph Lueb

documents.commentText: To whom it may concern I have been using Kratom regularly for 5 years. Though I would hope that this alone may sway the reader towards a pro kratom stance, my quality of life is not my major concern, but instead that of my childrens.I have always been uncomfortable in social situations where there are large crowds and become so extremely anxious I have to force myself through every second feeling awkward and withdrawn. This on its own though less than ideal would not be as bad if I did not have the large family of 5 that I work everyday (4*10 hr days a week + every spear moment of my time I dedicate to my children) to support. Please I urge you not to bring an end to the sale of this amazing botanical and allow me to carry on with this American dream I am living without the limitations I used to have to regretful accept.

documents.commentText: When I was younger I became addicted to pain pills (opiates).  This addiction progressed until I was faced with complete desolation or a change so I changed.  That was 20 years ago, I now own a successful business & I don't drink or do any type of drugs.  As I've grown older, into my senior years the aches & pains of age have caused a need for some type of pain mgt.  taking over the counter remedies help some but can't be taken all the time due to damage to kidneys & liver (& you can imagine my fear of opiates) so a friend suggested Kratom.  This has been a lifesaver, I have been using kratom for about 2 years with no ill effects. It is a mild pain reliever & has not been addictive. It does not "knock me out & I prefer a natural solution to the aches & pains of growing old, this has been it.  Please do not regulate this herbal remedy.  I have heard of more problems with Caffeine than with this.  At a time when natural remedies such as Cannabis (something I can't & don't use) is being placed on the ballot for legalization among more & more states it seems backward to restrict another helpful natural remedy.  Please don't restrict use of this substance It is my view you would do more harm than good.  Thank you

documents.commentText:
This comment is from a father whose son is a Kratom addict and is currently in a 2yr recovery program. My son who was your classic football/baseball player with lots of potential. He worked part-time at a local restaurant and began to buy pills from people at work. Once this was found out we were able to get him out of that environment to a more healthy part time job. Well my son began to take Kratom because the Indian/Pakistani ran Marathon gas stations and head shops said it was good for him and "Natural". We were oblivious to the Kratom addiction for a good year. The only thing we saw was he was always broke and needed money for gas. Over this year our son began to have extreme mood swings. Kratom turned my son into a Zombie in one year. His addiction to this caused him to burn threw his savings account of about 8,000 dollars as well as his paychecks. My son was making 17.00 an hour and was lucky to have .50 cents to his name by the next paycheck. (He lived at home and his only bill was the gas it took to drive to work)

My son began to exhibit mood disorders such as chronic insomnia with manic tendencies when he was on kratom and when he was off kratom he would go into severe angry depressive stupors with lots of nausea. He began to lie about everything and resorted to sealing my wife's jewelry and my garage power tools to pay for his addiction. Just before my son went into rehab he would have to go to the store to buy a foil packet of Matrix/Kratom just to get through his shift at work. He also began to complain constantly that he was in pain yet nothing was wrong with him. It was just the withdraw symptoms of the Kratom. Work would regularly drug test my son but because Kratom is a synthetic he would always show clean. (It wasn't until later that we found out you had to test specifically for Kratom. And to make matters worse Kratom was and is still legal. 

The reason that the head shops and gas stations don't want to ban this is because they are making a huge profit. A single serving of the Matrix brand of Kratom which is a foil packet with 4-5 pills in it is purchased off the internet for $3.00-$4.00 a packet and sold for $20.00 - $25.00 retail. This 400%-500% profit is the sole reason that the head shops and gas stations call is a natural healthy way to fight pain. Its nothing but greed. Don't be mistaken Kratom is just as addictive as Heroin but just doesn't have the same analgesic strength as Heroin. 

In short Kratom has no business on the retail market. It is just as addictive as heroin and will result in kratom "Zombies" if it continues to be allowed in stores. The businesses that want to keep it legal for retail could care less about who buy's it. They are in it for the 400% - 500% profit that they are making by selling it. Kratom causes the same withdraw symptoms as Heroin. I have been a police officer for 10yrs now and the symptoms my son exhibited being on kratom are the same as any heroin addict I run across on the street. It will not help you get off of Heroin it will only delay your recovery by keeping you dependent.

documents.commentText:
Kratom has been a tremendous help to me in pain management! I have found it to be safe, inexpensive, and to be virtually without adversse side effects. 

I am a 47 year old man who has chronic arthritis in my left knee due to a failed ACL implant surgery. Due to this surgery I have a broken fibula bone that never healed (non-union). Also I have a torn rotator cuff in my right shoulder. I have used prescription pain medicines before, but because of the expensive cost of these meds, and the side effects, including dependency, I have had to stop using these medications. 

I discovered Kratom a year ago and was so happy to have found something natural, safe, and inexpensive that I could use to relieve my chronic pain. 

Before using Kratom, I had researched Kratom extensively, inquiring for scientific reports on Kratom as well as personal testimonies from Kratom users as well as from those who are critical of Kratom. I decided to try Kratom for pain relief based on my research. 
Since then, I have been so very pleased with the results I get from using Kratom. I have had no adverse issues whatsoever from regularly using Kratom. In fact, not only has kratom helped with my chronic pain, but it has also been a wonderful sleep aid (I also have mild insomnia). 

I am a mature, responsible law abiding citizen, who is employed full time, and the proud father of two sons who are adult now. I have no interest in using illicit drugs, nor do I abuse alcohol or any other substances. I simply find Kratom to be a useful aid in my struggle to manage my physical pain, and it works for me. To have Kratom taken away from me would be terrible and counter productive as far as my pain management is concerned. 
For the government to ban Kratom is totally unjustified! Kratom is safe and can in no way be compared to the "legal" drugs out there that are far and away more dangerous than Kratom! 

Please do not take Kratom away from those of us who are being helped by it! The science is clear enough that it is safe, non-addicting, and non-lethal! Especially in comparison to other pain medicines, tobacco, alcohol et al. The benefits of Kratom out weigh any slight side effects that are sometimes associated with using it.
